Mechanical Leg was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Mechanical Leg

emojiDetailList.description:
A human leg, shown detached from a human body. Displayed from the thigh and may include the foot .

Leg was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Leg

emojiDetailList.description:
A human foot shown with five toes and may include part or all of the ankle. Shown on Apple platforms as the sole of a foot.

Foot was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Foot

emojiDetailList.description:
A single human ear. May be used in the context of listening, or hearing something.

Ear was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ear

emojiDetailList.description:
An ear shown with a hearing aid, worn by a person with hearing loss. The style shown in Behind The Ear (BTE), but this can represent any form of hearing aid.

Ear with Hearing Aid was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Ear with Hearing Aid

emojiDetailList.description:
A human nose. May be used to indicate smelling, or something that smells.

Nose was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Nose

emojiDetailList.description: Brain was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Brain

emojiDetailList.description: Tooth was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Tooth

emojiDetailList.description:
A bone which may be used for a dog to chew on, or as a part of the human body. The type of bone is not specified.

Bone was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Bone

emojiDetailList.description:
A pair of eyes, glancing slightly to the left on most platforms. The Google version of this emoji previously showed only a single eye , despite the name of this character being eyes (plural).

Sometimes used to indicate ‘pervy eyes’ to indicate approval of an attractive photo posted online; or ‘shifty eyes’ to convey a deceitful act.

Eyes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eyes

emojiDetailList.description:
A single human eye, looking forward. This eye is in a different shape and style to the pair of eyes , which are more rounded, and looking to one side.

Eye was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eye

emojiDetailList.description:
A tongue, sticking out. May be used as a childish sign of defiance.

Tongue was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tongue

emojiDetailList.description:
A human mouth which is generally displayed as a pair of lips and a top row of teeth, instead of the inside of the mouth.

May be used to indicate the spoken word or as an alternative to Kiss Mark .

Mouth was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mouth

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a young infant (baby). Shows the face of a baby with a small amount of hair on most platforms, while some variations show a pacifier (dummy) in its mouth. Android previously displayed this emoji as a swaddled baby.

On Snapchat , the baby emoji signifies a new friend on the service.

Baby was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baby

emojiDetailList.description:
A child with no gender specified. This may be used as a gender-inclusive alternative to the boy or girl emoji.

Child was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Child

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a boy, smiling. Previously differentiated from the man emoji on Android by wearing a cap, and on iOS by the lack of any facial hair.

Boy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Boy

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a girl, smiling. Differentiated from the woman emoji by the hairstyle which features pigtails which are not present on the woman.

Girl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Girl

emojiDetailList.description:
An adult with no gender specified. This may be used as a gender-inclusive alternative to the man or woman emoji.

Person was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Adult” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Person

emojiDetailList.description:
A person with blond hair, which tends to appear as yellow. Displayed as a man on all platforms, this emoji keeps blond hair no matter which skin tone is chosen.

Previous releases showed this emoji as a woman on Android, Windows, and Samsung.

Person: Blond Hair was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person with Blond Hair” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person: Blond Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
A man of adult age, shown on some platforms with a moustache.

Man was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Man

emojiDetailList.description:
A person with a visible beard. Generally displayed with a masculine appearance, though intended to be gender neutral from 2021. New gender-specific options for a woman with a beard or man with a beard are drafted for Emoji 13.1 .

Person: Beard was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Bearded Person” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switching to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in future releases.
emojiDetailList.title: Person: Beard

emojiDetailList.description:
A man with red hair. Sometimes described as ginger, orange, copper, or auburn.

The Man: Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man: Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man: Red Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man: Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man: Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man: Curly Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man: White Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦳 White Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man: White Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man: White Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man: Bald emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦲 Bald . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man: Bald was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man: Bald

emojiDetailList.description:
A woman of adult age. Differentiated from the girl emoji by the lack of pig-tails in her hair.

Woman was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman

emojiDetailList.description:
A woman with red hair. Sometimes described as ginger, orange, copper, or auburn.

The Woman: Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman: Red Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman: Red Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Person: Red Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦰 Red Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Person: Red Hair was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person: Red Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman: Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman: Curly Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman: Curly Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Person: Curly Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦱 Curly Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Person: Curly Hair was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person: Curly Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman: White Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦳 White Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman: White Hair was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman: White Hair

emojiDetailList.description:
The Person: White Hair emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦳 White Hair . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Person: White Hair was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.

emojiDetailList.description:

Person Pouting was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person with Pouting Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

emojiDetailList.description:
A person tipping their hand by their shoulder as if they’re carrying a tray of drinks or flipping their hair. Originally called Information Desk Person .

This emoji is commonly used to express sassiness or sarcasm.

While no gender is specified, many early designs displayed this emoji as a woman. Google’s 2014 design shows a blob wearing white gloves and a pillbox hat . Microsoft’s 2015 design shows a woman doing this gesture while winking , a facial expression that further reinforces the sassy and sarcastic uses of this emoji.

Person Tipping Hand was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Information Desk Person” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Tipping Hand

emojiDetailList.description:
A man tipping his hand by his shoulder as if he’s carrying a tray of drinks or flipping his hair.

This emoji is commonly used to express sassiness or sarcasm.

The Man Tipping Hand emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💁 Person Tipping Hand , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Tipping Hand was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

emojiDetailList.description:
A woman tipping her hand by her shoulder as if she’s carrying a tray of drinks or flipping her hair.

The earlier gender-unspecified version of this emoji, 💁 Person Tipping Hand , was originally depicted as a woman across most platforms.

The Woman Tipping Hand emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💁 Person Tipping Hand , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

emojiDetailList.description:
A person bowing deeply which is known as dogeza in Japan. Used to express a sincere apology, or to request a large favour.

Many variations of this emoji are misinterpreted as a person doing push-ups, lying down to have a massage, or doing a cute "head resting on hands" gesture.

Person Bowing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Person Bowing Deeply” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.

May be used in a similar context to the acronym SMH (shaking my head), or in relation to the Picard Facepalm meme .

Person Facepalming was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Face Palm” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

emojiDetailList.description:
A person shrugging their shoulders to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic, or a lack of care about the result of a situation.

Displays as raised shoulders, sometimes in conjunction with raised arms and flat hands. The shrug gesture in text (emoticon / kaomoji) form is known as a shruggie and typed as: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

The Unicode character Shrug ("Person Shrugging") does not specify a gender. See also Woman Shrugging or Man Shrugging .

Person Shrugging was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Shrug” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.

Man Artist was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Artist

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Artist emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👩 Woman , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🎨 Artist Palette . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Artist was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Artist

The Pilot emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ✈ Airplane . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Pilot was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Pilot

Astronaut was added to Emoji 12.1 in 2019.

A male astronaut or cosmonaut shown wearing a space suit and helmet.

The Man Astronaut emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🚀 Rocket . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

A female astronaut or cosmonaut shown wearing a space suit and helmet.

Woman Astronaut was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.

The Firefighter emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🚒 Fire Engine . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

emojiDetailList.title: Man Firefighter

emojiDetailList.title: Woman Firefighter

emojiDetailList.description:
This police officer wears a blue hat, which features a gold badge or shield in the middle.

The gender of this emoji is not specified, but is commonly shown as a man.

Police Officer was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Police Officer

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 👮 Police Officer emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Police Officer emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👮 Police Officer , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Police Officer was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Police Officer

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 👮 Police Officer emoji.

The Woman Police Officer emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👮 Police Officer , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Police Officer was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Police Officer

emojiDetailList.description:
An undercover investigator, wearing a hat, and sometimes using a magnifying glass to closely inspect evidence. This emoji did not originally recommend emoji modifiers, but a proposal was created to address this.

Detective was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Sleuth or Spy” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Detective

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🕵 Sleuth or Spy emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Detective emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🕵 Detective , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Detective was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Detective

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🕵 Sleuth or Spy emoji.

The Woman Detective emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🕵 Detective , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Detective was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Detective

emojiDetailList.description:
A British guardsman, known as a foot guard. Wears a tall black hat with a yellow chin-strap. Must look straight ahead at all times, even when tourists attempt to distract them.

Guard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Guardsman” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Guard

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 💂 Guardsman emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Guard emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💂 Guard , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Guard was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Guard

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 💂 Guardsman emoji.

The Woman Guard emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💂 Guard , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Guard was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Guard

emojiDetailList.description:
A construction worker wearing a hard-hat ( safety helmet ). Has a high visibility vest or hammer in some variations.

Some platforms display a green cross on the helmet which is used in Japan as a safety reminder in construction zones. It is also commonly seen on the Met helmet in the game Mega Man.

Construction Worker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Construction Worker

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 👷 Construction Worker emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Construction Worker emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👷 Construction Worker , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Construction Worker was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Construction Worker

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 👷 Construction Worker emoji.

The Woman Construction Worker emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👷 Construction Worker , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Construction Worker was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Construction Worker

emojiDetailList.description:
Male royalty, intended as a gender pair for the princess emoji . Shown as a man with a crown.

Not a reference to the musician Prince , however the man singer emoji on WhatsApp does show a character that bears a heavy resemblance to this artist.

Prince was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Prince

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a princess; a girl or woman wearing a small crown or tiara. Could also be used to represent a Queen or other royalty.

Princess was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Princess

emojiDetailList.description:
A man wearing a turban ; a form of customary headwear worn by Sikhs or Muslims.

Person Wearing Turban was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Man with Turban” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Wearing Turban

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 👳‍♀️ Woman Wearing Turban emoji.

The Man Wearing Turban emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👳 Person Wearing Turban , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Wearing Turban was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Wearing Turban

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 👳 Man Wearing Turban emoji.

The Woman Wearing Turban emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👳 Person Wearing Turban , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Wearing Turban was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Wearing Turban

emojiDetailList.description:
A person wearing a gua pi mao; a type of Chinese hat. Sometimes referred to as a skullcap .

Person With Skullcap was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Man with Gua Pi Mao” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Person With Skullcap

emojiDetailList.description:
A person (generally depicted as a woman) wearing a headscarf. While the type of  headscarf is not specified, this is most commonly displayed as a woman wearing a hijab.

Woman with Headscarf was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 under the name “Person with Headscarf” and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman with Headscarf

emojiDetailList.description:
A person dressed for a formal occassion, wearing a tuxedo. No gender is specified for this emoji. See also Woman in Tuxedo and Man in Tuxedo .

Person in Tuxedo was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Man in Tuxedo” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switching to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in future releases.
emojiDetailList.title: Person in Tuxedo

emojiDetailList.description:
A person in traditional western wedding dress with a veil over their head.

Person With Veil was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bride with Veil” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switching to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in future releases.
emojiDetailList.title: Person With Veil

emojiDetailList.description:
A pregnant woman, intended to complete the family emoji set. Sometimes used in jest to represent feeling full after over-eating; aka "food baby".

Pregnant Woman was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Pregnant Woman

emojiDetailList.description:
A woman shown breastfeeding a baby, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling.

This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the mother. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the mother.

See 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby for bottle feeding instead of breastfeeding.

Breast-Feeding was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Breast-Feeding

emojiDetailList.description:
A person feeding a baby with a bottle, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling.

This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the adult. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the adult.

Variants include 👩‍🍼 Woman Feeding Baby and 👨‍🍼 Man Feeding Baby . See also 🤱 Breast-Feeding .

The Person Feeding Baby emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧑 Person , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🍼 Baby Bottle . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Person Feeding Baby was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Person Feeding Baby

emojiDetailList.description:
An angelic baby with wings, and a halo above its head. Commonly known as a cherub .

Baby Angel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baby Angel

emojiDetailList.description:
Santa Claus, sometimes referred to as Father Christmas , brings joy to children at Christmas time. Displayed with a beard and red festive hat.

The Santa emoji had a frown on Android 4.4 , which was resolved in Android 5.0. See also: Christmas emoji list .

Note: Father Christmas has a different origin to Santa Claus but both are represented by this single emoji.

Santa Claus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Father Christmas” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Santa Claus

emojiDetailList.description:
Mother Christmas, more commonly known as Mrs. Claus, is the wife of Santa Claus. Displayed as an older woman with glasses and a festive red and white bonnet. See also: Christmas emoji list .

Mrs. Claus was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Mother Christmas” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Mrs. Claus

emojiDetailList.description:
A hero which may be displayed as a man,woman or gender-neutral / gender-inclusive depending on the platform. This base emoji does not specify a gender, but is used to create the emojis for Man Superhero and Woman Superhero .

The Supervillain is the nemesis of this emoji.

Superhero was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Superhero

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Superhero emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦸 Superhero , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Superhero was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Superhero

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Superhero emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦸 Superhero , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Superhero was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Superhero

emojiDetailList.description:
A villain which may be displayed as a man,woman or gender-neutral / gender-inclusive depending on the platform. This base emoji does not specify a gender, but is used to create the emojis for Man Supervillain and Woman Supervillain .

The Superhero is the nemesis of this emoji.

Supervillain was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Supervillain

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Supervillain emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦹 Supervillain , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Supervillain was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Supervillain

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Supervillain emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🦹 Supervillain , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Supervillain was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Supervillain

emojiDetailList.description:
Mage was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Mage

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Mage emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧙 Mage , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Mage was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Mage

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Mage emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧙 Mage , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Mage was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Mage

emojiDetailList.description:
Fairy was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Fairy

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Fairy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧚 Fairy , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Fairy was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Fairy

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Fairy emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧚 Fairy , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Fairy was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Fairy

emojiDetailList.description:
A vampire shown wearing a dark cape, and with pointed fangs. This emoji supports skin tones, and variations that are female or male .

Vampire was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Vampire

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Vampire emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧛 Vampire , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Vampire was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Vampire

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Vampire emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧛 Vampire , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Vampire was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Vampire

emojiDetailList.description:
A merperson who may be referred to as merfolk or merpeople in plural. May be used for the display of a mermaid, mergirl, merwoman , or merman .

Merperson was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Merperson

emojiDetailList.description:
The Merman emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧜 Merperson , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Merman was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Merman

emojiDetailList.description:
The Mermaid emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧜 Merperson , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Mermaid was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Mermaid

emojiDetailList.description:
Creatures with pointed ears and human-like faces. Female and male elves are available.

Elf was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Elf

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Elf emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧝 Elf , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Elf was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Elf

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Elf emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧝 Elf , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Elf was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Elf

emojiDetailList.description:
A supernatural being, which is generally shown to be imprisoned within a bottle or lamp. May be capable of granting wishes when summoned. Variations exist for a female genie or male genie .

Genie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Genie

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Genie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧞 Genie , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Genie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Genie

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Genie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧞 Genie , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Genie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Genie

emojiDetailList.description:
A reanimated human, often found in works of horror fiction. May have a female or male appearance.

Zombie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Zombie

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Zombie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧟 Zombie , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Zombie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Zombie

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Zombie emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧟 Zombie , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Zombie was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Zombie

emojiDetailList.description:
A person getting his or her face massaged.

Apple’s artwork for this character shows more of a head massage. Google and Microsoft display a more accurate face massage, with hands rubbing the cheeks and face.

Person Getting Massage was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Face Massage” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Getting Massage

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 💆 Face Massage emoji.

The Man Getting Massage emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💆 Person Getting Massage , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Getting Massage was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Getting Massage

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Getting Massage emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💆 Person Getting Massage , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Getting Massage was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Getting Massage

emojiDetailList.description:
A person in the process of getting their hair cut. This emoji is intended to be gender-neutral, but is commonly shown as a girl or woman smiling, with scissors shown open next to the hair on her head.

Windows previously displayed this emoji as a comb and scissors , instead of a person having their hair cut.

Person Getting Haircut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Haircut” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Getting Haircut

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Getting Haircut emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💇 Person Getting Haircut , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Getting Haircut was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Getting Haircut

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 💇 Haircut emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Woman Getting Haircut emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 💇 Person Getting Haircut , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Getting Haircut was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Getting Haircut

emojiDetailList.description:
A person going for a walk. Taking a slow-medium pace, this person would be a runner if they picked up their speed .

This emoji does not specify a gender, but is shown as a man on most major platforms.

Person Walking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Pedestrian” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Walking

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🚶 Pedestrian emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Walking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚶 Person Walking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Walking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Walking

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🚶 Pedestrian emoji.

The Woman Walking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚶 Person Walking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Walking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Walking

emojiDetailList.description:
A person standing upright. May be used to represent human in a general sense, or shown in sequence to imply holding hands.

Similar in appearance to 🚶 Person Walking , but shown facing forward and without any motion implied.

Person Standing was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Standing Person” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Standing

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Standing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧍 Person Standing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Standing was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Standing

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Standing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧍 Person Standing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Standing was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Standing

emojiDetailList.description:
A person kneeling on both knees. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.

Person Kneeling was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Kneeling Person” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.

emojiDetailList.description:
A person running, with a large stride and arms outstretched. May be wearing a running shirt .

This emoji does not specify a gender, but is shown as a man on most platforms. See also: 🏃‍♀️ Woman Running or 🏃‍♂️ Man Running .

Person Running was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Runner” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Running

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🏃 Runner emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Running emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏃 Person Running , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Running was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Running

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🏃 Runner emoji.

The Woman Running emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏃 Person Running , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Running was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Running

emojiDetailList.description:
A person dancing, most commonly displayed as woman with one arm raised wearing a red dress, while dancing the salsa or flamenco. Often used to represent a sense of fun or as a positive affirmation, e.g. "great! 💃"

This emoji did not originally specify a gender, but was canonically deemed a woman when the 🕺 Man Dancing emoji was approved . Google previously displayed this emoji as a man , then a gender-neutral blob character (in keeping with guidelines at the time).

Microsoft previously displayed this emoji as stick figure , and Samsung has displayed this over various releases as a white boy , black boy , and white girl .

Woman Dancing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dancer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Dancing

emojiDetailList.description:
A man dancing, added as a gender pair for the 💃 Woman Dancing . Shown on most platforms in a 70s-era suit, and one hand in the air in a disco-dancing style.

Man Dancing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Dancing

emojiDetailList.description:
A person wearing a suit, hovering above the ground with a shadow displayed beneath them. Generally shown wearing a fedora or similar style of hat.

This character was originally introduced into the Webdings font as an “exclamation mark in the style of the rude boy logo found on records by The Specials ". This levitating man was known as Walt Jabsco.

Person in Suit Levitating was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Man in Business Suit Levitating” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Person in Suit Levitating

emojiDetailList.description:
An iteration of the Playboy Bunny known in Japan as a Bunny Girl . Usually depicted as an attractive woman  wearing bunny ears; a bunny girl can also be seen in anime as a hybrid human/animal known as Kemonomimi .

Some versions of this emoji, such as Apple’s, display two girls dancing, each wearing a leotard and bunny ears. Other interpretations show the face of one woman wearing bunny ears.

The two-person version of this emoji is often used as a display of friendship, fun, or "let's party".

People with Bunny Ears was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Woman with Bunny Ears” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: People with Bunny Ears

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 👯 Woman With Bunny Ears emoji.

The Men with Bunny Ears emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👯 People with Bunny Ears , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Men with Bunny Ears was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Men with Bunny Ears

emojiDetailList.description:
A female version of the 👯 People With Bunny Ears emoji.

The Women with Bunny Ears emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👯 People with Bunny Ears , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Women with Bunny Ears was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Women with Bunny Ears

emojiDetailList.description:
A person in a sauna, holding a ladle for pouring water on hot stones, which creates the steamy environment.

Popular in Finland, where people sauna in the nude.

Person in Steamy Room was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.

People Holding Hands was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.

emojiDetailList.description:
A kissing gesture, shown with a pink love heart floating in the air between two people. No gender is specified for the two people, and as such this may be used to represent the concept of a couple broadly, and/or as a means of showing two non-binary people.

Previously shown with the same appearance as 👩‍❤️‍💋‍👨 Kiss: Woman, Man , but now displays two people with an ambiguous gender appearance.

Kiss was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Kiss

Kiss: Woman, Man was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Kiss: Woman, Man

emojiDetailList.description:
Two men displayed kissing, or gesturing a kiss toward each other. At small sizes this may be difficult to discern from the two women kissing .

The Kiss: Man, Man emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👨 Man , ‍ Zero Width Joiner , ❤ Red Heart , ‍ Zero Width Joiner , 💋 Kiss Mark , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 👨 Man . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

emojiDetailList.title: Speaking Head

emojiDetailList.description:

emojiDetailList.title: Bust in Silhouette

emojiDetailList.description:
Generic profile of two people. Often used in interface design to represent users.

Busts in Silhouette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Busts in Silhouette

emojiDetailList.description:
Two human footsteps,  showing the outline of both feet, including all five toes.

Footprints was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Footprints

emojiDetailList.description:
A suitcase or bag, as used for traveling. Most platforms depict gray or blue rolling luggage with an extended handle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling or taking trips, whether for business or leisure.

Apple’s design features an old-fashioned, leather, trunk-styled case with graphic luggage labels /stickers, not to be confused with 💼 Briefcase or 👜 Handbag . Google and Facebook also include such stickers.

May be stored in a 🛅 Coin Locker or inspected at 🛃 Customs .

Luggage was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Luggage

emojiDetailList.description:
An umbrella that is closed, likely as a result of collapsing it prior to going indoors.

Shows as pink on Apple devices, blue on Android, and purple on Twitter.

Closed Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Closed Umbrella

emojiDetailList.description:
An opened, dry umbrella. Generally depicted with purple fabric and a hooked handle.

Commonly used for various content concerning rainy weather. Occasionally used as a purple accent color.

Not to be confused with ☔ Umbrella With Rain Drops or 🌂 Closed Umbrella , though their applications may overlap.

WhatsApp’s umbrella is green. Google’s umbrella was previously blue, Microsoft and Samsung’s once red.

Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Umbrella

emojiDetailList.description:
An orange pumpkin carved into the shape of a face and commonly known as a Jack-o’-lantern . See also Halloween .

Jack-O-Lantern was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Jack-O-Lantern

emojiDetailList.description:
A spool of thread, as used for sewing. Thread color varies across platforms, though often depicted in red or blue and on a wooden spool. Sometimes shown with an end unraveling.

Commonly used for various content concerning sewing, knitting, arts and crafts, clothing and fashion, and metaphorical threads (e.g., a discussion thread online).

WhatsApp’s design includes a needle.

Thread was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Spool of Thread” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Thread

emojiDetailList.description:
A ball of yarn, as used to knit a scarf . Color varies across platforms, but often depicted in green, blue, or magenta and shown with an end unraveling. Sometimes depicted with a pair of knitting needles stuck in the ball.

Commonly used for various content concerning knitting and needlework (e.g., sewing , crocheting), clothing and fashion, arts and crafts, cold weather, and cats.

Yarn was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Ball of Yarn” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Yarn

emojiDetailList.description:
Prescription glasses, shown with a variety of frames, depending on platform.

Glasses was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Eyeglasses” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Glasses

emojiDetailList.description:
Sunglasses that can be worn outside for protection from the sun. Often association with connotations of being "cool", or leisurely in sunny places.

This emoji shows only the sunglasses, which differs from the smiling face with sunglasses emoji.

Sunglasses was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Dark Sunglasses” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sunglasses

emojiDetailList.description:
Goggles of a type that are not specified, but implied to be safety goggles instead of swimming goggles.

Goggles was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Goggles

emojiDetailList.description:
A white coat worn in a science laboratory.

Lab Coat was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Lab Coat

emojiDetailList.description:
A brightly colored vest generally worn on construction sites or areas requiring high visibility.

Safety Vest was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Safety Vest

emojiDetailList.description:
A necktie commonly worn at work or formal occasions.

Sometimes displayed as a shirt and tie . Colors and patterns vary by platform.

Necktie was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Necktie

emojiDetailList.description:
A plain t-shirt, that can be worn by men or women. Displayed as a blue polo shirt on iOS, Facebook and Firefox OS. A white t-shirt on Android and Windows, and yellow or green on other platforms.

The Facebook version of this emoji has a capital H on the front.

T-Shirt was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: T-Shirt

emojiDetailList.description:
Denim jeans, worn by men or women. A popular form of casual trousers worn by the runner emoji in Apple's emoji artwork

Jeans was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Jeans

emojiDetailList.description: Scarf was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Scarf

emojiDetailList.description: Gloves was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Gloves

emojiDetailList.description:
A winter jacket, shown in a variety of colors and styles.

Coat was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Coat

emojiDetailList.description: Socks was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Socks

emojiDetailList.description:
A pretty dress, suitable for a ball, party or other similar occasion.

Dress was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dress

emojiDetailList.description:
A traditional Japanese robe that can be worn by women or men.

Kimono was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Kimono

emojiDetailList.description:
Sari was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Sari

emojiDetailList.description:
One-Piece Swimsuit was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: One-Piece Swimsuit

emojiDetailList.description:
Underwear or swim briefs (aka "Speedos"), in a style most often associated with men.

Briefs was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Briefs

emojiDetailList.description:
Shorts was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Shorts

emojiDetailList.description:
A two-piece bikini, worn at the beach, pool, or on vacation at a tropical destination .

Shown in a variety of colors and patterns across different platforms.

Bikini was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bikini

emojiDetailList.description:
A blouse worn by women in a neat-casual setting.

Shown in pink on Apple devices, yellow on Android, and purple on Twitter.

Similar to the top worn by the Information Desk Person Emoji .

Woman’s Clothes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womans Clothes” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman’s Clothes

emojiDetailList.description:
A small pouch with a clasp, generally used to hold coins. Sometimes called a “coin purse.”

Color varies by platform, though most platforms have a pink, blue, or turquoise bag with a silver or gold (gray or yellow) clasp.

Not to be confused with 👝 Clutch Bag , which can look like a coin person on some platforms, due to lack of relative scale in emoji designs.

Purse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Purse

emojiDetailList.description:
A bag or purse, used to carry personal items, often doubling as a fashion accessory.

The design of this emoji varies, with most platforms opting for leather-looking styles in brown or orange. Samsung’s design used to be pink , but is now light brown. Twitter’s purple design stands out among the other platforms.

Not to be confused with the smaller and handleless pouch emoji sometimes referred to as 👝 Clutch Bag .

Handbag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Handbag

emojiDetailList.description:
A small pouch, somewhere between the size of a handbag , and a purse .

Clutch Bag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Pouch” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Clutch Bag

emojiDetailList.description:
A school bag Emoji (also called a satchel) used by children attending school to carry books, lunch, and other personal belongings.

Backpack was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “School Satchel” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Backpack

emojiDetailList.description:
A shoe worn by a man, to work, dinner, or another occasion that requires footwear. Unlike womens shoes, this shoe is likely to be comfortable.

Man’s Shoe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Mans Shoe” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Man’s Shoe

emojiDetailList.description:
A sneaker – a comfortable shoe used in sports such as tennis or golf , or for fashion purposes.

Running Shoe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Athletic Shoe” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Running Shoe

emojiDetailList.description:
A style of boot commonly worn on long walks or for hiking. Generally distinct from other footwear-related emojis by the considerable grip on the sole of the shoe.

Hiking Boot was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Hiking Boot

emojiDetailList.description:
A flat shoe, in a style generally worn by women. More practical than a high-heeled shoe .

Flat Shoe was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Flat Shoe

emojiDetailList.description:
A high-heeled shoe, primarily worn by women. Generally found in a context which requires formal dress, such as social occasions, or some work places.

Displayed in red on most platforms, though the color may vary.

High-Heeled Shoe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: High-Heeled Shoe

emojiDetailList.description:
A sandal worn by a woman in summer, spring, or other weather that suits open-toed footwear. Has a heel at the back providing additional height to the wearer.

Woman’s Sandal was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womans Sandal” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman’s Sandal

emojiDetailList.description:
A pointe shoe worn by ballet dancers when performing pointe work .

Ballet Shoes was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Ballet Shoes

emojiDetailList.description:
A tall boot generally featuring a slight heel, shown in brown or red on most platforms.

Some platforms display this emoji with two boots, while most display a single boot.

Woman’s Boot was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womans Boots” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman’s Boot

emojiDetailList.description:
A gold crown with jewels on the sides. Representative of a King, Queen, or other form of Royalty.

Crown was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Crown

emojiDetailList.description:
A hat worn by women for sun protection, or for fashion.

The Apple version of this hat is made of straw and has a green bow on the front. Google shows a yellow hat on Android (with a ribbon in the latest version), while Windows and Twitter both feature a flower on the front of the hat.

Woman’s Hat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womans Hat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman’s Hat

emojiDetailList.description:
A top hat, worn in traditional British weddings and other formal occasions. This is also a popular playing piece in the game of Monopoly .

Top Hat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Top Hat

emojiDetailList.description:
A graduation cap, worn on the head of students graduating from college or university. Known in some locations as a mortar board with tassel.

Graduation Cap was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Graduation Cap

emojiDetailList.description: Billed Cap was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Billed Cap

emojiDetailList.description:
A construction helmet, which is worn by the construction worker emoji in some emoji sets.

The cross on the helmet (shown in the Apple version of this emoji) is used in Japan as a safety reminder in construction zones. It is also commonly seen on the Met helmet in the game Mega Man.

Rescue Worker’s Helmet was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Helmet with White Cross” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rescue Worker’s Helmet

emojiDetailList.description:
Lipstick shown with the lid removed. Displays in a shade of red on most platforms, except Android which has a pink color.

Lipstick was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Lipstick

emojiDetailList.description:
A ring with displaying a gem stone of some kind on the top, most likely a diamond. This piece of jewellery is often associated with a proposal and subsequent engagement to be married .

Ring was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ring

emojiDetailList.description:
A place to store notes and other office materials. Primarily used by older people.

Generally shown as a brown case with a handle on top, and a silver or gold colored clasp on the front. Facebook shows two leather straps on the front.

Briefcase was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Briefcase

emojiDetailList.description:
A drop of blood shown in red. May be used to signify a blood donation, bleeding, injury or menstruation.

Drop of Blood was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Drop of Blood

emojiDetailList.description:
The see no evil monkey , called Mizaru (Japanese for “see not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys . Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with tan or pinkish hands covering its eyes.

The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil , frequently interpreted as a call to discretion or figure for willful ignorance.

Often used as a playful way to convey a laughing, disbelieving, or cringing I can’t believe what I’m seeing! or I can’t bear to look!

See also 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey .

See-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: See-No-Evil Monkey

emojiDetailList.description:
The hear no evil monkey , called Kikazaru (Japanese for “hear not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys . Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with tan or pinkish hands covering its ears.

The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil , frequently interpreted as a call to discretion or figure for willful ignorance.

Often used as a playful way to convey I can’t believe what I’m hearing! or, more generally, express astonishment or disbelief.

Google’s design features scrunched, X-shaped eyes.

See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey .

Hear-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hear-No-Evil Monkey

emojiDetailList.description:
The speak no evil monkey , called Iwazaru (Japanese for “say not”), one of the Three Wise Monkeys . Depicted as the brown 🐵 Monkey Face with its tan or pinkish hands covering its mouth.

The Three Wise Monkeys represent the proverb see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil , frequently interpreted as a call to discretion or figure for willful ignorance.

Often used as a playful way to convey I can’t believe what I just said! , express a mischievous Oops! , or communicate a secret-keeping I won’t say a word . May be used to similar effect as 🤭 Face With Hand Over Mouth or 🤐 Zipper Mouth .

See also 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey and 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey .

Speak-No-Evil Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speak-No-Evil Monkey

emojiDetailList.description:
A cartoon-styled representation of a collision. Depicted as a star-like, orange-and-yellow fiery burst, generally with one point extending to the bottom right, as if from the source of the collision.

May be used to represent various types of bangs, explosions, or crashes. Like 🔥 Fire and 💯 Hundred Points , commonly used to represent something is excellent or exciting in some way.

Apple implements a version of 💥 Collision in its 🧨 Firecracker and 📸 Camera With Flash .

Collision was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Collision Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Collision

emojiDetailList.description:
A cartoon-styled representation of dizziness . Generally depicted as one or more yellow stars swirling in a yellow or blue circle.

Resembles squeans , stylized stars and circles over the heads of characters in comics and animation to show they are dizzy, disoriented , intoxicated, or sick .

Commonly used for emphasis and flair or to indicate various positive sentiments. Like 🌠 Shooting Star , sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.

Not to be confused with ⭐ Star , 🌟 Glowing Star , and ✨ Sparkles , though their applications may overlap.

Facebook’s design features two stars spinning along two intersecting purple circles, though it previously only featured one yellow ring. Samsung’s design previously displayed several yellow circles and stars.

Dizzy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dizzy Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dizzy

emojiDetailList.description:
Three, light blue droplets, as sweat beads, splashing down to the right. Resembles plewds , stylized sweat droplets used in comics and animation to show characters working hard or feeling stressed.

May be used to represent various types of liquids, including sexual fluids. May also be used to represent various liquid-based slang expressions (e.g., drip , “exceptional style, swagger").

Not to be confused with 💧 Droplet , though their applications may overlap.

Google , Microsoft , and Samsung's design previously featured two, upwardly directed droplets.

Sweat Droplets was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Splashing Sweat Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sweat Droplets

emojiDetailList.description:
A cartoon-styled gust of air. Depicted as a small, gray cloud with motion lines, rushing to the left.

Resembles briffits , a stylized cloud of dust used in comics and animation to indicate someone or something has dashed away (e.g., leaving someone in the dust ).

May be used to represent speed, smoking, and various types of wind, blown or broken. May precede other emoji, such as 🏃Runner or 🚗 Automobile , to indicate something is fast or fleeing: 🏃💨, 🚗💨.

Not to be confused 🌬️ Wind Face , though their applications may overlap.

Dashing Away was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Dash Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dashing Away

emojiDetailList.description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a monkey, looking straight ahead. Depicted as a brown-haired monkey with a tan or pinkish face, round ears, nostrils, and open-mouthed smile.

As with the full-bodied 🐒 Monkey , often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey .

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac . Available as an Apple Animoji .

Vendors implement the same or similar monkey face in their Three Wise Monkeys emojis: 🙈 See-No-Evil Monkey , 🙉 Hear-No-Evil Monkey , and 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey .

Facebook’s monkey previously resembled 🐻 Bear Face .

Monkey Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Monkey Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A monkey, a small primate with long limbs and tail for climbing trees. Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled, brown monkey with a cheeky facial expression, shown in full profile facing left, sitting on its hind legs with a long, curled tail and round ears.

As with 🐵 Monkey Face , often used with a playful tone or for metaphorical senses of monkey .

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac .

WhatsApp’s monkey is facing right, Facebook’s has shaggy hair.

Monkey was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Monkey

emojiDetailList.description:
A gorilla, the powerful, black-haired great ape. Variously depicted in full profile on all fours facing left or as a friendly, cartoon-styled gorilla face looking straight ahead.

Apple, WhatsApp, Facebook, and Microsoft’s designs feature a full gorilla, as a silverback , with strong shoulders and reddish forehead. Google, Samsung, and Twitter’s designs feature a black and gray gorilla face with a neutral expression and prominent forehead and jaw.

Facebook’s design previously featured only a gorilla face.

Gorilla was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Gorilla

emojiDetailList.description:
An orangutan, the orange-haired ape with long arms. Depicted facing forward, with a long broad face and sitting with its legs bent. Often shown scratching its head. Skin color varies across platforms, ranging from light to dark.

Google’s orangutan has purplish skin, Twitter's is smiling.

Orangutan was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Orangutan

emojiDetailList.description:
What a good doggo! A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a dog, looking straight ahead. Depicted as the face of a dog of various breeds, generally light-brown and white, with pointed or floppy ears and its tongue hanging out.

May be used with a more playful tone than the full-bodied 🐕 Dog , though their applications generally overlap. See also 🐩 Poodle .

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac . Available as an Apple Animoji .

Many vendors implement the same or similar dog as their full-bodied 🐕 Dog , such as Google and Facebook, which feature a Shiba Inu . Apple, Microsoft, and WhatsApp’s dogs have a white face with brown, floppy ears and a brown patch over one eye.

Included in the earliest Japanese emoji sets from Softbank , Docomo , and au by KDDI .

Dog Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dog Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A dog, a faithful, beloved pet canine. Depicted as a light-brown dog, of various breeds, in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long, curled tail held upright and pointed or floppy ears.

Google and Facebook’s dogs resemble a reddish-brown Shiba Inu , a popular Japanese breed featured in the Doge meme .

See also 🐩 Poodle and 🐶 Dog Face , whose applications may overlap. Some vendors implement the same or a similar dog in their 🦮 Guide Dog and 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog .

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac .

Google and Facebook previously featured puppies with collars, Apple’s dog previously resembled an Akita Inu , another popular Japanese breed.

Dog was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dog

emojiDetailList.description:
A guide (or Seeing Eye) dog , trained to help lead a person who is blind or visually impaired. Generally depicted as a yellowish-brown Labrador Retriever on all fours facing left, equipped with a harness and handle. Many platforms additionally include a collar.

Not to be confused with 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog , though their popular applications may overlap.

Twitter implements the same dog as its 🐕 Dog . Samsung and Twitter’s guide dogs have green harnesses.

Guide Dog was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Guide Dog

emojiDetailList.description:
A service animal displayed with a safety vest and lead. Differs from the guide dog as this animal is intended for detection of seizures or other “hidden disabilities”, according to the proposal from Apple .

The Service Dog emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🐕 Dog , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🦺 Safety Vest . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Service Dog was added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Service Dog

emojiDetailList.description:
A poodle , a popular dog breed with curly hair, often groomed in an ornamental pattern.

Generally depicted as a grayish-white poodle in full profile on all fours facing left, with a shaved torso, legs, and face with fuller, pom-pom-like hair on its head, ears, chest, feet, and tip of tail (as the Continental Clip ).

Like 🐕 Dog , may be used to represent a variety of dog breeds (often fluffy or long-haired). See also 🐶 Dog Face .

With an upturned snout, Google’s poodle bears an endearingly haughty expression.

Google , Samsung , and Facebook’s design previously featured pink poodles.

Poodle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Poodle

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a wolf, a howling canine that hunts in packs. Generally depicted as a cartoon-styled face of a gray wolf with pointed ears, white cheeks and muzzle, and black nose.

Its expression is variously neutral, friendly, or slightly menacing, as in Google and Samsung’s designs. Apple’s design features the head of gray wolf, facing left.

Occasionally used to represent metaphorical senses of wolf , e.g., lone wolf , wolf pack .

Apple and SoftBank’s designs previously resembled a reddish-brown canine, resembling a dog or fox .

Wolf was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Wolf Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wolf

emojiDetailList.description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled faced of a fox, the cunning canine, looking straight ahead. Depicted as an orange fox  face with a black nose, pointed ears, and shaggy, white cheeks.

Often used with an affectionate or playful tone (e.g., slang, foxy ). Does not have a full-bodied fox emoji counterpart.

Available as an Apple Animoji .

Fox was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Fox Face” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Fox

emojiDetailList.description:
A raccoon, a nocturnal mammal with a mask around its eyes. Generally depicted as a friendly, cartoon-styled, gray raccoon face looking straight ahead, with black-and-white markings around its eyes and pointed ears and cheeks.

Apple and WhatsApp’s designs feature a raccoon in full profile on all fours facing left with a striped, bushy tail.

Raccoon was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Raccoon

emojiDetailList.description:
Meow! A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a cat, looking straight ahead. Generally depicted as a yellowish-orange cat face with pointed ears and whiskers.

May be used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐈 Cat , though their applications generally overlap.

Available as an Apple Animoji .

Vendors implement the same or similar cat in their 🐈 Cat as well as in their cat-faced variants of smileys:

  • 😼 Cat Face With Wry Smile
  • 😹 Cat Face With Tears of Joy
  • 🙀 Weary Cat Face
  • 😾 Pouting Cat Face
  • 😿 Crying Cat Face
  • 😻 Smiling Cat Face With Heart-Eyes
  • 😺 Grinning Cat Face
  • 😸 Grinning Cat Face With Smiling Eyes
  • 😽 Kissing Cat Face

Google’s cat face was previously orange, Samsung’s gray, and Facebook’s once gray and white. Included in the earliest Japanese emoji sets from Softbank , Docomo , and au by KDDI .

Cat Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cat Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A domestic cat, beloved as a pet. Generally depicted as a light-orange cat with stripes, as a tabby , in full profile on all fours facing left, with its long tell held upright.

See also 🐱 Cat Face .

Google’s cat is cartoon-styled, shown sitting on its hind legs with a friendly expression and whiskers. Facebook’s cat is a gray tabby, though previously was orange. Microsoft and Samsung’s cats were previously gray, Twitter’s brown.

Cat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cat

emojiDetailList.description:
The Black Cat emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🐈 Cat , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ⬛ Black Large Square . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Black Cat was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Black Cat

emojiDetailList.description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a lion—the large cat and king of the jungle—looking straight ahead. Depicted as a golden-yellow lion face with a light- or dark-brown mane, white muzzle, and neutral expression.

Often used with an affectionate tone. Does not have a full-bodied lion emoji counterpart. A lion is represented as ♌ Leo in the Western zodiac.

Available as an Apple Animoji .

Apple's lion previously featured a timid-looking expression.

Lion was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Lion Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Lion

emojiDetailList.description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a tiger looking straight ahead. Generally depicted in yellowish-orange with black stripes on its forehead and cheeks, a white muzzle, and neutral expression.

Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied 🐅 Tiger .

Available as an Apple Animoji .

Tiger Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tiger Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A tiger, a large cat with an orange coat and black stripes. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long tail, its distinctive stripes, and, on some platforms, white patches.

See also 🐯 Tiger Face . Not to be confused with 🐆 Leopard .

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac .

Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled, as Facebook’s previously was. Microsoft’s design previously featured a yellow, forward-facing tiger, as if on the prowl.

Tiger was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tiger

emojiDetailList.description:
A leopard, a large cat with a yellowish-brown coat and black-and-gold spots. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a long tail and its distinctive pattern.

Sometimes used to represent jaguars, panthers, cheetahs, and related cats. May also be used to indicate leopard prints in fashion. Not to be confused with 🐅 Tiger .

Google’s design is noticeably more cartoon-styled. Microsoft’s design was previously solid yellowish-brown in color, resembling a cougar or mountain lion.

Leopard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Leopard

emojiDetailList.description:
The face of a horse, generally facing left. Depicted as a light or reddish-brown horse with a dark brown or black mane, and, on many platforms, a light-colored muzzle.

Not to be confused with the full-bodied 🐎 Horse or 🏇 Horse Racing , though their applications may overlap. Some vendors implement a similar design in 🦄 Unicorn Face and 🦓 Zebra .

WhatsApp’s horse is facing left, as Facebook’s previously was. Microsoft’s horse was previously looking straight ahead, as was Samsung’s , shown with a goofy, full-toothed grin. Softbank previously featured a full-bodied horse.

Horse Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Horse Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A horse, a hoofed mammal used for riding and racing. Depicted as a brown horse in full profile galloping to the left, with a dark, flowing mane and tail.

May be used to represent various types of horses and their metaphorical senses (e.g., mustang , stallion ).

One of the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac .

Not to be confused with 🐴 Horse Face , 🎠 Carousel Horse , and 🏇 Horse Racing , which features a jockey on its back.

Apple’s horse is wearing a green saddle blanket, Facebook’s a blue blanket with saddle. SoftBank’s design previously featured a racing horse with a jockey.

Horse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Horse

emojiDetailList.description:
