See also 🌒 Waxing Crescent Moon .

Google’s moon once resembled a waning crescent moon, Twitter and Facebook's moons were previously silver.

Crescent Moon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Crescent Moon

emojiDetailList.description:
A new moon with a smiling face, as the Man in the Moon . Generally depicts the moon as a dark disc with a slightly smiling human face and nose.

See also 🌑 New Moon . May be used to represent the moon more generally. Popularly perceived as creepy , used to throw shade (express disapproval), or convey various suggestive or ironic sentiments.

Apple and WhatsApp’s eyes are looking left, as if giving the side-eye . Samsung and Facebook’s faces are looking straight ahead. Google’s facial expression resembles 😏 Smirking Face , Twitter’s 🙂 Slightly Smiling Face .

Google’s face previously evoked Lenny Face , Microsoft’s eyes appeared closed, and Facebook’s face was a simple smiley.

New Moon Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “New Moon with Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: New Moon Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A first quarter moon with a human face, as the Man in the Moon . Generally depicts a wide, golden crescent moon with the profile of a slightly smiling human face with a nose, facing left.

May be used to represent the moon more generally and saying good night.

See also 🌓 First Quarter Moon and 🌙 Crescent Moon . Not to be confused with 🌜 Last Quarter Moon Face , though their applications may overlap.

WhatsApp’s eyes are looking back. Facebook’s moon is silver but was previously golden; Twitter’s was previously silver. Google’s eyes were previously closed.

First Quarter Moon Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “First Quarter Moon with Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: First Quarter Moon Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A last quarter moon with a human face, as the Man in the Moon . Generally depicts a wide, golden crescent moon with the profile of slightly smiling human face with a nose, facing right.

May be used to represent the moon more generally and saying good night.

See also 🌗 Last Quarter Moon and 🌙 Crescent Moon . Not to be confused with 🌛 First Quarter Moon Face , though their applications may overlap.

WhatsApp’s eyes are looking back. Facebook’s moon is silver but was previously golden; Twitter’s was previously silver. Google’s eyes were previously closed.

Last Quarter Moon Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Last Quarter Moon with Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Last Quarter Moon Face

emojiDetailList.description:
The sun, the star at the center of our solar system. Generally depicted as a golden-yellow disc radiating eight triangular rays, representing the sun’s heat and light.

Commonly used to represent sunny, warm, or hot weather, light, heat, energy, life, outer space, astronomy, and various positive and happy ( sunny ) feelings.

See also 🌞 Sun With Face . Not to be confused with 🔆 Bright Button or 🔅 Dim Button.

Google’s sun was once red, Samsung’s previously gray. See the glossary for the term black in Unicode character names.

Sun was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Sun with Rays” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun

emojiDetailList.description:
A full moon with a smiling face, as the Man in the Moon . Generally depicts the moon as a dark disc with a slightly smiling human face and nose.

See also 🌕 Full Moon . May be used to represent the moon more generally. Commonly used a smiley. Occasionally used for irony and sarcasm.

Apple and WhatsApp’s eyes are looking left, as if giving the side-eye . Samsung and Facebook’s faces are looking straight ahead. Google’s facial expression resembles 😏 Smirking Face , Twitter’s 🙂 Slightly Smiling Face .

Google’s face previously evoked Lenny Face , Microsoft’s eyes appeared to be closed, Twitter’s resembled its 🌚 New Moon Face , and Facebook’s face was a simple, yellow smiley.

Full Moon Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Full Moon with Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Full Moon Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A sun with a smiling face, as a Sun of May . Generally depicted as a golden-yellow disc with a smiling, often human face with a nose, radiating triangular rays, representing the sun's heat and light.

May be used to represent the sun more generally. Also used to represent sunny, warm, or hot weather and various positive and happy ( sunny ) feelings.

See also ☀️ Sun . Not to be confused with 🔆 Bright Button or 🔅 Dim Button .

Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook's suns feature human faces. Other platforms, including Twitter, feature a simple smiley, as 🙂 Slightly Smiling Face .

Microsoft's eyes previously appeared closed, Facebook's expression resembled 😁 Beaming Face With Smiling Eyes .

Sun with Face was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun with Face

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic, five-point gold star.

Commonly used for various metaphorical senses of star (e.g., for fame, success, excellence, reviews). Also used for emphasis or flair. Occasionally used for astronomical stars.

Not to be confused with 💫 Dizzy , 🌟 Glowing Star , 🌠 Shooting Star , or ✨ Sparkles , though their applications may overlap.

Samsung and Facebook’s stars were once silver.

See the glossary for the term white in Unicode character names.

Star was approved as part of Unicode 5.1 in 2008 under the name “White Medium Star” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Star

emojiDetailList.description:
A glowing, five-point gold star. Depicted as ⭐ Star with stylized bursts in between its points, representing glowing or twinkling.

Commonly used to represent various senses of glowing as well for as for a sense of flourish. Not to be confused with 💫 Dizzy , ⭐ Star , 🌠 Shooting Star , or ✨ Sparkles , though their applications may overlap.

On Snapchat , this emoji displays next to a contact who has had their snaps replayed in the past 24 hours.

Microsoft’s bursts are blue lines, though were previously yellow. Apple’s star previously resembled its ⭐ Star . Samsung’s star previously displayed a burst radiating out from its center.

Glowing Star was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Glowing Star

aliases: When You Wish Upon A Star
emojiDetailList.description:
A stylized representation of a shooting star , a small, fast meteor that burns up in the atmosphere. Generally depicted as a gold, five-point star trailing yellow motion lines against a night sky, as if moving down to the left.

May be used for astronomical stars and other content concerning space. Also may be used for flair or flourish. Sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.

Not to be confused with 💫 Dizzy , ⭐ Star , 🌟 Glowing Star , or ✨ Sparkles , though their applications may overlap.

Google’s star is trailed, without backdrop, by yellow lines, though they were previously blue. Microsoft’s star is trailed, without backdrop, by blue lines, though they were previously yellow.

Shooting Star was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shooting Star

emojiDetailList.description:
A fluffy, white cloud, as a cumulus . May be used as a weather icon to represent a cloudy or overcast day.

Google’s cloud is bluish, Twitter’s design features two clouds.

Cloud was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cloud

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow sun half covered by a white cloud. Position of the sun varies across platforms.

May be used as a weather icon to represent a partly cloudy day.

Not to be confused with 🌤️ Sun Behind Small Cloud or ⛅ Sun Behind Large Cloud , though their applications may overlap.

Microsoft’s cloud was previously gray, Samsung’s bluish.

Sun Behind Cloud was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun Behind Cloud

emojiDetailList.description:
Blue raindrops falling from a white cloud with a lightning bolt flashing.

May be used as a weather icon to represent thundershowers.

Not to be confused with 🌩️ Cloud With Lightning , though their applications may overlap.

Cloud with Lightning and Rain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Thunder Cloud and Rain” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cloud with Lightning and Rain

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow sun partially covered by a small, white cloud. Position of the cloud varies across platforms.

May be used as a weather icon to represent a mostly sunny day.

Not to be confused with ⛅ Sun Behind Cloud or 🌥️ Sun Behind Large Cloud , though their applications may overlap.

See the glossary for the term white in Unicode character names.

Sun Behind Small Cloud was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “White Sun with Small Cloud” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun Behind Small Cloud

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow sun mostly covered by a large, white cloud. Position of the sun varies across platforms.

May be used as a weather icon to represent a mostly cloudy day.

Not to be confused with ⛅ Sun Behind Cloud or 🌤️ Sun Behind Small Cloud , though their applications may overlap.

Samsung’s cloud was previously bluish.

See the glossary for the term white in Unicode character names.

Sun Behind Large Cloud was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “White Sun Behind Cloud” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun Behind Large Cloud

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow sun half covered by a white rain cloud with blue raindrops. Most platforms depict the raindrops falling to the left. Position of the sun varies across platforms.

May be used as a weather icon to represent a mix of sunshine and scattered showers.

Not to be confused with ⛅ Sun Behind Cloud .

Samsung’s cloud was previously bluish.

See the glossary for the term white in Unicode character names.

Sun Behind Rain Cloud was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “White Sun Behind Cloud with Rain” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sun Behind Rain Cloud
emojiDetailList.unicodename: White Sun Behind Cloud with Rain

emojiDetailList.description:
A rain cloud. (Keep dry with ☔ Umbrella With Rain Drops .) Depicted as blue raindrops falling from a white cloud. Most platforms depict the raindrops falling to the left.

May be used as a weather icon to represent rain showers or a rainy day.

Samsung’s cloud was previously bluish.

Cloud with Rain was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cloud with Rain

emojiDetailList.description:
A snow cloud. Depicted as blue snowflakes falling from a white cloud.

May be used as a weather icon to represent snow showers or a snowy day.

Not to be confused with 🌧️ Cloud With Rain .

Cloud with Snow was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cloud with Snow

emojiDetailList.description:
A thundercloud. Depicted as a yellow lightning bolt flashing from a white cloud.

May be used as a weather icon to represent thunderstorms.

Not to be confused with ⛈️ Cloud With Lightning and Rain , though their applications may overlap.

Samsung’s cloud was previously bluish with two lightning bolts.

Cloud with Lightning was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cloud with Lightning

emojiDetailList.description:
A tornado, a destructive column of air. Depicted as a gray, funnel-shaped cloud, rotating in contact with the ground.

May be used as a weather icon to represent a tornado. May also be used to represent a metaphorical tornado (e.g., a powerful force or violent outburst).

Google’s tornado was previously blue and white. Microsoft and Samsung’s designs previously depicted tornadoes defending from a cumulus cloud .

Tornado was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Cloud with Tornado” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tornado

emojiDetailList.description:
Fog, as obscures visibility. Generally depicted as a square of a gray, hazy, cloud-like mass.

May be used as a weather icon to represent foggy conditions. May also be used to represent metaphorical fog (e.g., a daze).

Not to be confused with 🌁 Foggy , though their applications may overlap.

Microsoft’s design is a stylized depiction of fog, featuring three, wavy lines, as Google’s previously did. Samsung’s fog previously resembled three clouds. Twitter’s design previously resembled its 🌁 Foggy emoji, showing fog obscuring the Golden Gate Bridge.

Fog was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fog

emojiDetailList.description:
A face blowing the wind, as a personification of nature (e.g., Mother Nature , the North Wind ) who creates the wind by blowing air from its mouth. Depicted as a gray, profile of a human face, generally with a feminine appearance, blowing swirls from her mouth to the right.

May be used to represent windy weather. Occasionally used to represent clouds, fog, smoke, and smoking. Not to be confused with Dashing Away, though their applications may overlap.

Microsoft’s design is blue, as is Facebook’s, whose design most clearly suggests a woman’s face. WhatsApp’s design depicts a cloud with a face, as Samsung’s previously did.

Wind Face was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Wind Blowing Face” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wind Face

emojiDetailList.description:
The colorful arc of a rainbow, as may appear after rain. Generally depicted as the left half of a full rainbow, showing six bands of color: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet.

Commonly used to express gay pride . Also commonly used to convey various feelings of love and happiness. See also 🏳️‍🌈 Rainbow Flag .

WhatsApp’s design shows the right arc of rainbow disappearing into a cloud. Facebook’s rainbow is displayed on a blue sky, as Apple , Samsung , and Twitter’s previously were. Google and Microsoft previously displayed full rainbow arcs with clouds.

Rainbow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rainbow

emojiDetailList.description:
An opened, dry umbrella. Generally depicted with purple fabric and a hooked handle.

Commonly used for various content concerning rainy weather. Occasionally used as a purple accent color.

Not to be confused with ☔ Umbrella With Rain Drops or 🌂 Closed Umbrella , though their applications may overlap.

WhatsApp’s umbrella is green. Google’s umbrella was previously blue, Microsoft and Samsung’s once red.

Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Umbrella

emojiDetailList.description:
An umbrella, opened to provide cover from rain. Generally depicted with purple fabric and a hooked handle with several rain droplets falling on its top.

Commonly used for various content concerning rainy weather.

Not to be confused with ☂️ Umbrella or 🌂 Closed Umbrella , though their applications may overlap.

WhatsApp’s umbrella is green. Google’s umbrella was previously blue, Microsoft and Samsung’s red, and Facebook’s once pink.

In 2016, a Durex poll voted this emoji to (unofficially) represent condoms and safe sex for World AIDS Day.

Umbrella with Rain Drops was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Umbrella with Rain Drops

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol for high voltage , as warns against injury from electricity. Depicted as a jagged yellow bolt.

Commonly used to represent lightning , electricity, and various flashes. Also used to represent metaphorical energy and signal attention online.

Samsung’s bolt was previously white on a blue square, as an icon for high voltage.

High Voltage was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “High Voltage Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: High Voltage

emojiDetailList.description:
The unique, feathery ice crystal of a snowflake. Depicted as a bluish-white snowflake with six, intricate, symmetrical branches.

Like 🌨️ Cloud With Snow , may be used as a weather icon to represent a snowstorm or a cold, snowy day. May also be used for various content concerning wintertime, cold climates , and winter activity, such as skiing .

Snowflake was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Snowflake

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic snowman, as Frosty the Snowman , with snowflakes falling on it. Depicted as a snowman, facing forward, made from two or three large snowballs and stick arms, dressed with a top hat , a carrot nose, coal eyes, and two or three buttons on its torso. Sometimes shown with a smile and a red scarf .

Often used for various content concerning winter fun and Christmastime .

Vendors implement the same figure for their ⛄ Snowman Without Snow , which does not have snowflakes.

Google’s snowman is wearing green gloves , thoguh its snowman previously lacked any attire. Samsung's previously lacked a hat.

This snowman predates Unicode emoji support, which explains why it may display as the black-and-white outline of a snowman.

Snowman was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Snowman

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic snowman, as Frosty the Snowman . Depicted as a snowman, facing forward, made from two or three large snowballs and stick arms, dressed with a top hat , a carrot nose, coal eyes, and two or three buttons on its torso. Sometimes shown with a smile and a red scarf .

Often used for various content concerning winter fun and Christmastime.

Vendors implement the same figure for their ☃️ Snowman , but which has snowflakes falling on it.

Google’s snowman is wearing green gloves , though its snowman previously lacked any attire. Samsung's previously lacked a hat.

Snowman Without Snow was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Snowman Without Snow

emojiDetailList.description:
A comet , an icy, rocky space object that can form a tail of gas and dust when near the sun. Generally depicted as an icy-blue comet, as if streaking downwards in a night sky.

May be used for meteors and other celestial bodies, as well as for content concerning space more generally. Also occasionally used for flair or flourish.

Not to be confused with 🌠 Shooting Star , though their applications may overlap.

Samsung’s comet is fiery-red, as is Apple’s, which appears to be ascending. WhatsApp’s comet is depicted in a starry, night sky, Apple’s comet was previously descending and blue.

Comet was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Comet

emojiDetailList.description:
A flame, as produced when something is on fire. Depicted as a red, orange, and yellow flickering flame.

Commonly used for various metaphorical expressions related to fire, including the slang hot (“attractive”) and lit (“excellent”).

Snapchat displays 🔥 Fire next to two users who are on a snapstreak , or have been messaging for more than three consecutive days.

Fire was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fire

emojiDetailList.description:
A single, light blue droplet, as of water, sweat, or tears.

May be used for various types of liquid. May also be used to expression sadness, as in 😢 Crying Face , or for various liquid-based slang expressions (e.g., drip , “exceptional style, swagger").

Not to be confused with 💦 Sweat Droplets , though their applications may overlap.

Droplet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Droplet

emojiDetailList.description:
A wave of water, as breaks at the beach. Depicted as a blue wave with a foamy, white crest, curling to the right.

May be used to represent water in general, various bodies of water like oceans, and water activities, such as swimming , surfing , and sailing . May also be used to represent metaphorical waves.

Apple’s design resembles the iconic wave in Japanese artist Hokusai’s famous woodblock print, The Great Wave off Kanagawa (ca. 1830).

Water Wave was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Water Wave

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic Christmas tree, an evergreen tree decorated with lights and ornaments to celebrate Christmas .  Depicted with round, variously colored ornaments and topped with a yellow star .

Used for various content concerning the Christmas holiday and season as well as for wintertime more generally.

Not to be confused with 🌲 Evergreen Tree , though their applications may overlap.

Google and Samsung's trees were previously adorned with tinsel, Microsoft's previously lacked ornaments.

Christmas Tree was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Christmas Tree

emojiDetailList.description:
The glittering flashes of sparkles. Generally depicted as a cluster of three, yellow four-point stars, with one large sparkle and two small ones to its left or right.

Commonly used to indicate various positive sentiments, including love, happiness, beauty, gratitude, and excitement. May also be used to convey newness or cleanliness.

Not to be confused with ⭐ Star , 🌟 Glowing Star , or 💫 Dizzy , though their applications may overlap.

Microsoft’s sparkles are multicolored, as Twitter’s previously were. Samsung’s sparkles are depicted on a night sky, suggesting firework sparklers .

Twitter's mobile app uses ✨ Sparkles as a button users can tap to toggle between latest and top tweets on their timeline.

Sparkles was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sparkles

emojiDetailList.description:
A Tanabata tree, a type of wish tree on which people hang wishes written on paper and other decorations during Tanabata , a Japanese festival celebrating two heavenly lovers. Depicted as one or two stalks of green bamboo, on which hangs one or more slips of paper, generally red.

Often used to represent various plants or as a green accent color.

Apple’s design includes a yellow star decoration. Microsoft’s design previously displayed a green branch with three, variously colored pieces of paper.

Tanabata Tree was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tanabata Tree

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese kadomatsu , composed of pine leaves and bamboo shoots. Traditionally placed outside homes in Japan around the New Year to welcome spirits for a plentiful, happy year ahead.

Depicted as three shoots of bamboo , arranged vertically at different heights in a wooden container, arrayed with pine leaves.

Often used to represent various plants or as a green accent color.

WhatsApp’s kadomatsu is adorned with red berries, as is Facebook’s, which also includes pink cherry blossoms .

Pine Decoration was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pine Decoration

emojiDetailList.description:
A grape bunch, as cut from the vine and used to make wine . Depicted as red (purple-colored) grapes.

Grapes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Grapes

emojiDetailList.description:
A melon fruit in a light greenish-brown rind. Depicted as a cantaloupe by most platforms, but can resemble a honeydew at a distance.

Melon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Melon

emojiDetailList.description:
A slice of watermelon, showing its rich pink flesh, black seeds, and green rind.

Watermelon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Watermelon

emojiDetailList.description:
An orange-colored citrus fruit with a green leaf or leaves and stem. Officially depicting a tangerine, a type of mandarin ( mikan in Japan). Often used as a garden-variety orange. Either way, a good source of vitamin C.

Tangerine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tangerine

emojiDetailList.description:
The sour, yellow-colored citrus fruit of the lemon, usually with a stem and green leaf or leaves.

Spiked in use thanks to Beyoncé’s 2016 album, Lemonade .

Lemon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Lemon

emojiDetailList.description:
A ripe banana, peeled and ready to eat on major platforms. Great snack for a child or monkey .

Banana was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Banana

emojiDetailList.description:
The tropical fruit of a pineapple, shown in spiky, golden-brown skin and with a pointed, green crown. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle.

Pineapple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pineapple

emojiDetailList.description:
The ripe fruit of a tropical mango. Variously depicted in shades of yellow, red, orange, and green with a single, green leaf and stem.

Mango was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Mango

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic red apple, shown with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms. Commonly associated with doctors , teachers , and New York .

Red Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Red Apple

emojiDetailList.description:
A common green apple, tarter counterpart to the Red Apple . Displayed with a stem and single, green leaf on major platforms.

Green Apple was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Green Apple

emojiDetailList.description:
A light-green variety of a common pear, shown with a stem and sometimes green leaf.

May be used for its namesake expression, pear-shaped (“prominent hips” or “failure”).

Pear was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pear

emojiDetailList.description:
The fleshy, pinkish-orange fruit of the fuzzy peach, shown with green leaves and sometimes a stem.

Thanks to its distinctive cleft, the emoji is most commonly used for “buttocks.” In certain contexts, the peach emoji may refer to impeachment .

Peach was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Peach

emojiDetailList.description:
Two rich red cherries with a green leaf and joined at their long stems.

May be used to refer to male or female genitalia.

Cherries was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cherries

emojiDetailList.description:
The fruit of a rich red strawberry dotted with seeds and crowned with green leaves. Google previously depicted the fruit in orange.

Strawberry was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Strawberry

emojiDetailList.description:
Blueberries was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Blueberries

emojiDetailList.description:
A kiwifruit, or Chinese gooseberry, with its fuzzy, brown skin sliced open to show its light-green flesh, white core, and black seeds.

May be associated with New Zealand , whose residents are nicknamed Kiwis, after the bird.

Kiwi Fruit was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Kiwifruit” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Kiwi Fruit

emojiDetailList.description:
A plump, red garden tomato topped with a leafy green stem. May resemble the red apple at small sizes.

Tomato was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tomato

emojiDetailList.description:
Olive was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Olive

emojiDetailList.description:
The hairy shell of a tropical coconut, cracked in a half to show its milky-white meat. Google displays a whole coconut alongside a half-shell.

Coconut was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Coconut

emojiDetailList.description:
A pear-shaped avocado, sliced in half to show its yellow-green flesh and large brown pit. Ready for toast, guacamole, or millennial jokes.

Avocado was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Avocado

emojiDetailList.description:
A long, bulbous, bright purple eggplant, or aubergine in British English, shown with a leafy stem. Considered lucky in Japan to dream of an eggplant the first night of the New Year .

Widely used to represent a penis. Due to its phallic use, the hashtag #🍆 was once banned (2015) on Instagram's search function.

Eggplant was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Aubergine” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eggplant

emojiDetailList.description:
A whole potato—such as a russet, used for baking, mashing, or frying—shown with a few eyes on its golden-brown skin. Not to be confused with the roasted sweet potato .

Potato was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Potato

emojiDetailList.description:
A whole, bright orange carrot, topped with long green leaves, as if freshly plucked from the garden. Some platforms feature a longer, thinner carrot, others a shorter, more bulbous one.

Carrot was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Carrot

emojiDetailList.description:
An ear of corn, or maize, partially husked to show its buttery-yellow kernels.

Ear of Corn was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Ear of Maize” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ear of Corn

emojiDetailList.description:
A bright red Mexican chili pepper, slightly curled and with a green stem. May be used to represent something “hot and spicy,” figuratively or literally, as a dish on a restaurant menu.

Hot Pepper was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hot Pepper

emojiDetailList.description:
Bell Pepper was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Bell Pepper

emojiDetailList.description:
A long, green cucumber with bumpy skin. Resembles its derived product, a pickle or gherkin, on many platforms, except on Apple and WhatsApp, which depict it with light-green, seed-y slices.

Cucumber was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Cucumber

emojiDetailList.description:
A head of a rich green leaf vegetable, usually shown with white stalks. May be used to represent a variety of greens, including romaine lettuce, chard, and Chinese cabbage like bok choy, as commonly cooked in Asian cuisines.

Leafy Green was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Leafy Green

emojiDetailList.description:
A rich green, tree-like head or floret of broccoli.

Broccoli was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Broccoli

emojiDetailList.description:
Garlic was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Garlic

emojiDetailList.description:
Onion was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Onion

emojiDetailList.description:
The edible fungus of the mushroom, depicted as a toadstool with a white-spotted red cap and stem.

Mushroom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mushroom

emojiDetailList.description:
The pod of the peanut, shown in its rounded, grooved, light-brown shell. Apple depicts a pair.

May be used for peanut butter as well as other edible nuts (e.g., almonds) or metaphorical ones, including slang for “crazy” and “testicle.”

Peanuts was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Peanuts

emojiDetailList.description:
The reddish-brown, acorn-shaped chestnut, tapering to a sharp tip from its light brown base on most platforms. A popular roasted snack associated with autumn and Christmas.

May be used for other edible nuts (e.g., walnuts) or sexual slang.

Chestnut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Chestnut

emojiDetailList.description:
A loaf of white or wheat bread, as before it is sliced for toast or sandwiches.

Bread was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bread

emojiDetailList.description:
The flaky, golden-brown crescent of a croissant, a breakfast pastry associated with France and Austria .

Croissant was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Croissant

emojiDetailList.description:
The long, thin loaf of a baguette, with scoring on its golden-brown crust. A bread commonly associated with France .

Baguette Bread was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Baguette Bread

emojiDetailList.description:
A flat type of cornbread with common types including arepa or gordita.

Flatbread was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Flatbread

emojiDetailList.description:
The heart-shaped twist of a hard or soft golden-brown pretzel, seasoned with grains of salt. A snack commonly associated with Germany .

Pretzel was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Pretzel

emojiDetailList.description:
The brown bread of a bagel, shown sliced in two halves. Some platforms depict seeds, as sesame or poppy, and a schmear of cream cheese, with the bagel assembled as a sandwich. May resemble the Doughnut at small sizes.

After complaints, Apple updated the bagel emoji design during the iOS 12.1 beta cycle.

Bagel was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Bagel

emojiDetailList.description:
A stack of breakfast pancakes, topped with a pad of butter and maple syrup oozing down its golden-brown sides, onto a plate on some platforms. Associated with the Christian observance of Shrove Tuesday , or "Pancake Day."

Pancakes was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Pancakes

emojiDetailList.description:
Waffle was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Waffle

emojiDetailList.description:
A wedge of yellow-orange cheese with holes, like a Swiss, but used for the food in general. May be used for various cheese-related slang expressions (e.g., “cheesy,” “say cheese,” “big cheese”).

Cheese Wedge was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cheese Wedge

emojiDetailList.description:
A hunk of unspecified meat on a white bone, as associated with cartoon cavepersons or food in anime and manga (Japanese ano niku , “that meat”).

This emoji was shown as a steak in Android 4.4.

Meat on Bone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Meat on Bone

emojiDetailList.description:
A crispy brown leg (drumstick) of chicken , duck , turkey , or other poultry on the bone, as roasted at Thanksgiving or Christmas dinner or fried at fast-food restaurants.

Poultry Leg was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Poultry Leg

emojiDetailList.description:
A cut of uncooked red meat, as a T-bone or rib-eye steak, with the light, white marbling of fat.

May be used for sexual slang.

Cut of Meat was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Cut of Meat

emojiDetailList.description:
Strips of crispy, fatty, reddish-brown bacon, as fried for breakfast. Depicted as a pair on most platforms.

Bacon was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Bacon

emojiDetailList.description:
A burger with a beef patty, usually depicted on a sesame bun with cheese, lettuce, and tomato—making it a cheeseburger, though officially called Hamburger by Unicode.

Platforms stack the ingredients in various orders. Google previously placed the cheese under the patty, a "controversy" CEO Sundar Pichai addressed in 2018.

Hamburger was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hamburger

emojiDetailList.description:
Thin-cut, golden-brown French fries, served in a red carton, as at McDonald’s. Apple features Smiling Face With Smiling Eyes on its carton.

French Fries was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: French Fries

emojiDetailList.description:
A slice of pepperoni pizza, topped with black olives on Google. WhatsApp adds green pepper, Samsung white onion.

Pizza was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Slice of Pizza” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pizza

emojiDetailList.description:
The cooked sausage of a hot dog in a sliced bun and drizzled with yellow mustard, as eaten at a baseball game.

Hot Dog was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hot Dog

emojiDetailList.description:
A sandwich, as eaten at lunch, made with lettuce , tomato , and cheese on slices of white or wheat bread . Apple, Google, and WhatsApp add a deli meat that resembles ham.

Sandwich was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Sandwich

emojiDetailList.description:
A Mexican or Tex-Mex taco on a hard or soft corn tortilla, filled with such ingredients as beef , lettuce , tomato , cheese , and onion. Apple’s design resembles a carne asada taco, with cilantro and white onion.

Taco was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Taco

emojiDetailList.description:
A Mexican or Tex-Mex burrito, featuring a wrapped flour tortilla filled with such ingredients as beef , rice , beans, cheese , tomato , lettuce , and sour cream. Served in foil on several major platforms, suggesting a Mission burrito associated with San Francisco. Not to be confused with the Stuffed Flatbread .

Burrito was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Burrito

emojiDetailList.description:
Tamale was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Tamale

emojiDetailList.description:
A flatbread, like pita, stuffed with lettuce , tomato , and/or meat . Resembles a doner kebab, falafel, shawarma, or gyro sandwich, popular in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. Apple and WhatsApp add red onion and cucumber . Not to be confused with the Burrito .

Stuffed Flatbread was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Stuffed Flatbread

emojiDetailList.description:
Falafel was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Falafel

emojiDetailList.description:
An egg, displayed as a chicken egg with a white or light brown shell. Commonly used at Easter time. See also: 🍳 Cooking .

Egg was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Egg

emojiDetailList.description:
An egg with yolk frying in a skillet, as prepared sunny-side up. Though associated with breakfast, the emoji represents the general action of cooking and related concepts.

Cooking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cooking

emojiDetailList.description:
A flat, shallow, black pan with side handles, containing saffron-colored rice , vegetables, a leg of poultry , and/or shrimp and lemon slices. Commonly associated with paella , a traditional dish from Spain . May be used for eating, cooking , dining, and meals more generally.

Apple's version of this emoji is considered to be representative of the traditional ingredients from Valencia. Samsung previously displayed this emoji as a Korean hot pot .

Shallow Pan of Food was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Shallow Pan of Food

emojiDetailList.description:
A pot, as a casserole dish, filled with a warm and hearty beef or vegetable stew on most platforms. Samsung’s design resembles a bowl of ramen or other noodle dish, with chopsticks . Generally used for eating and cooking (“a meal”), and commonly associated with soup or Japanese nabe .

Pot of Food was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pot of Food

emojiDetailList.description:
Fondue was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Fondue

emojiDetailList.description:
A bowl with a silver spoon inside, as used to eat cereal or soup. Bowl color varies across platforms, as do contents. Android depicts breakfast cereal, WhatsApp tomato soup; Apple’s is empty.

Bowl with Spoon was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Bowl with Spoon

emojiDetailList.description:
An undressed garden salad in a bowl with leafy-green lettuce and other ingredients such as tomato , red onion, and black olives. Commonly associated with healthy eating and living.

Google previously displayed a hard-boiled egg, removed in 2018 to make the salad vegan-friendly.

Green Salad was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Green Salad

emojiDetailList.description:
The buttery-white snack of popcorn brimming in a classic red-and-white-striped carton, as enjoyed at a movie theater .

May be used to express engagement (“edge of one’s seat”).

Popcorn was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Popcorn

emojiDetailList.description:
Butter was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Butter

emojiDetailList.description:
A clear glass shaker of salt with a silver cap, as paired with pepper to season food when eating at a restaurant.

Salt was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Salt Shaker” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Salt

emojiDetailList.description:
A can or tin of food, depicted as tomatoes or a generic green vegetable. May be also used to represent sauce or soup.

Canned Food was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Canned Food

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese bento , a lunch box divided into portions of rice , vegetables, and meat or seafood, such as sushi or fried shrimp .

Bento Box was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bento Box

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese senbei , or rice cracker, wrapped with a sheet of nori , or seaweed, a snack commonly enjoyed with green tea .

Rice Cracker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rice Cracker

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese onigiri , a cone-shaped ball of white rice , a snack wrapped with a sheet of nori , or seaweed.

Rice Ball was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rice Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
A bowl of steamed white rice, a staple component of cuisine throughout Asia. Bowl color varies across platforms, though is often white.

Cooked Rice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cooked Rice

emojiDetailList.description:
A plate of orange-brown curry with vegetables or meat , served with a mound of white rice . May represent kare-raisu , or Japanese curry , though commonly associated with India and other Asian cuisines.

Curry Rice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Curry and Rice” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Curry Rice

emojiDetailList.description:
A bowl of steaming-hot food. Depicted as Japanese ramen (noodles in broth) with chopsticks on most platforms, though it can represent a warm meal more generally. Samsung’s design resembles Pot of Food .

Steaming Bowl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Steaming Bowl

emojiDetailList.description:
A plate of Italian spaghetti with tomato sauce, as a bolognese , with a fork twirling its long, thin noodles. Garnished with a green herb, as parsley, on some platforms.

Spaghetti was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Spaghetti

emojiDetailList.description:
A sweet potato depicted with textured purple, orange, or brown skin and sliced in half to show its golden-brown flesh. Sometimes called a yam, though they are unrelated. Not to be confused with the Potato .

Commonly roasted as a snack in East Asia during winter , much as squash and pumpkin are popular in the United States during fall/autumn . Used as an offering to the full moon in Japan during the Moon Viewing harvest festival.

Roasted Sweet Potato was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Roasted Sweet Potato

emojiDetailList.description:
A skewer of three bites of Japanese oden , a winter dish made with fishcakes , tofu, konnyaku, and a variety of other ingredients, including boiled eggs . Often served as a stew or skewered and dipped into soy sauce. Resembles the Dango and may be used for other skewered foods (e.g., shish kebab , roasting marshmallows) or spears.

Oden was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oden

emojiDetailList.description:
Japanese sushi , generally depicted as two pieces of raw pinkish-orange fish , as tuna or salmon, on white rice ( nigiri ). Some platforms show the cylindrical maki , a piece of seafood, vegetables, and white rice wrapped in seaweed ( nori ).

Sushi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sushi

emojiDetailList.description:
A prawn or shrimp breaded and deep-fried golden-brown. Known as ebi furai in Japan but commonly called shrimp tempura and served in a bento box . Not to be confused with the Shrimp .

Fried Shrimp was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fried Shrimp

emojiDetailList.description:
A slice of Japanese narutomaki , a ridged fishcake of processed whitefish with an iconic pink swirl , often served in ramen or oden . Thanks to its distinct swirl, may be used for flair.

Fish Cake with Swirl was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Fish Cake with Swirl Design” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fish Cake with Swirl

emojiDetailList.description:
The round, golden-brown pastry of a Chinese mooncake, a traditional delicacy and lunar symbol of the Mid-Autumn Festival . Many platforms feature a design or character imprinted on the crust, and depict a slice cut out to show a brown paste with a duck egg yolk inside. Twitter displays the Chinese character for “fall/autumn” or “harvest” (秋) on top.

Moon Cake was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Moon Cake

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese sweet dumpling made from rice flour and served on a skewer. Depicted as a botchan dango , comprising a pink, white or light yellow, and green ball, as colored by red beans, egg , and green tea . Resembles the Oden and featured in the Moon Viewing Ceremony , used in the Japanese festival to celebrate the full moon .

Dango was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dango

emojiDetailList.description:
A dumpling of dough and filling, as folded and pinched closed for steaming or frying. Associated with cuisines around the world, including China ( jiaozi ), Japan ( gyoza or dango ), Poland ( pierogi ), and Spain and Latin America ( empanada ). Facebook's design resembles a xiaolongbao , a Chinese soup dumpling.

Dumpling was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Dumpling

emojiDetailList.description:
A golden-brown, crescent-shaped, vanilla-flavored fortune cookie. Usually depicted with a strip of paper—on which a wise saying, lucky numbers, or Chinese vocabulary is written—peaking out of its hollow shell. Given at the end of meals at Chinese restaurants in the West.

Fortune Cookie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Fortune Cookie

emojiDetailList.description:
A tall, folded, paper carton, usually white, as used for takeout/takeaway food at Western Chinese restaurants. Most platforms depict chopsticks inside its open lid, labeled with a red, multi-tiered, traditional Chinese building. Also called an oyster pail .

Takeout Box was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Takeout Box

emojiDetailList.description:
An oyster, a mollusk used for food or pearls. Depicted as half of an opened oyster with a pinkish body in a rough, brown-and-white shell, bearing a pearl on many platforms.

Oyster was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Oyster

emojiDetailList.description:
A swirl of soft-serve ice cream atop a wafer-style cone, white or cream-colored, as vanilla, on most platforms. Facebook’s design suggests strawberry . May be used more generally for ice cream , frozen yogurt, and frozen treats.

Soft Ice Cream was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Soft Ice Cream

emojiDetailList.description:
A mound of shaved ice (snow cone) served in a dessert bowl with a short spoon, flavored with a cherry-red syrup on many platforms. Associated with Hawaiian shave ice or Japanese kakigori .

Shaved Ice was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shaved Ice

emojiDetailList.description:
One or more scoops of ice cream in a dessert bowl, variously topped with sprinkles, wafer rolls, or cherry and syrup. Flavors vary from vanilla , chocolate , and/or strawberry across platforms.

Ice Cream was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ice Cream

emojiDetailList.description:
A chocolate-glazed donut (or doughnut) with rainbow sprinkles. WhatsApp features a pink glaze associated with The Simpsons . May resemble the Bagel at small sizes.

Doughnut was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Doughnut

emojiDetailList.description:
A golden-brown chocolate chip cookie, or biscuit, though representing the baked treat more generally. Samsung, which features a pair of cookies, previously displayed this as two saltine crackers .

Cookie was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cookie

emojiDetailList.description:
A frosted cake with lit candles, as presented for a birthday celebration. The style of cake widely varies across platforms. With white frosting and strawberries , Apple and Google’s designs suggest a Japanese Christmas cake . Other vendors depict a chocolate, pink, and/or sponge cake.

Birthday Cake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Birthday Cake

emojiDetailList.description:
A slice of strawberry shortcake, layered with whipped cream and topped with a whole strawberry . Like the Birthday Cake , may be used to represent birthday celebrations or cake in general.

Shortcake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shortcake

emojiDetailList.description:
An individual cupcake in a liner topped with a swirl of frosting and sprinkles. The style of cupcake widely varies across platforms. The cake may be sponge or chocolate, the frosting pink or white, and the sprinkles rainbow or red.

Cupcake was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Cupcake

emojiDetailList.description:
A baked dish with a pastry crust, filled with sweet or savory ingredients. Appearance widely varies by platform. Apple depicts a whole pie in a tin, its crimped crust scored to let out steam. Google shows a slice of pumpkin pie as served at Thanksgiving , WhatsApp and Twitter a slice of cherry pie.

Pie was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Pie

emojiDetailList.description:
A block of dark chocolate, usually shown in a red foil wrapper peeled back to show squares of the candy. WhatsApp displays the wrapper in purple, a color commonly associated with Cadbury chocolate.

Chocolate Bar was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Chocolate Bar

emojiDetailList.description:
A small piece of round, hard sugar candy, as handed out on Halloween , wrapped with two twists on its ends. Candy and wrapper color vary widely by platform. Facebook’s design resembles a classic, unwrapped red-and-white peppermint. May also be called sweets or lollies.

Candy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Candy

emojiDetailList.description:
A colorful swirl of hard candy on a stick, called a lollipop. Color varies widely by platform: Google displays rainbow colors, Android shades of pink, and Samsung a candy-cane-colored pinwheel.

"Lollipop" was the name of version 5 of Google's Android operating system .

Lollipop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Lollipop

emojiDetailList.description:
A golden-yellow custard dessert, as a crème caramel or flan , topped with a layer of caramel. Shown on a plate, molded in a ramekin-shape and often in a pool of caramel sauce.

Custard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Custard

emojiDetailList.description:
A golden-yellow pot of honey, as made by bees and desired by bears . Shown with the sweet substance oozing down its sides, often with a honey dipper inside the small vessel.

May be used figuratively, as the term of endearment “honey.”

Honey Pot was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Honey Pot

emojiDetailList.description:
A bottle of milk or formula, as or fed to a baby , with a bluish cap and rubber nipple or teat. Positioned upright or at a 45° angle, and filled to various levels, sometimes showing fill lines. Often used for newborns and childrearing. See also Breast-Feeding .

Baby Bottle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baby Bottle

emojiDetailList.description:
A tall glass of white milk, as from a cow but also other mammals, nuts, or plants. Most platforms depict a glass filled near to the brim, but some show a glass half-full—or half-empty.

Glass of Milk was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Glass of Milk

emojiDetailList.description:
A cup of a steaming-hot beverage, usually taken as coffee or tea . Sometimes shown on a saucer. Samsung features a foamy-white tulip latte art design.

May be paired with the Frog Face to represent the snarky But That's None of My Business meme .

Hot Beverage was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hot Beverage

emojiDetailList.description:
Teapot was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Teapot

emojiDetailList.description:
A cup of green tea, as the minty-colored Japanese matcha , usually shown on a wooden mat. Matcha is traditionally served in a small bowl that resembles a cup without a handle. Often taken as a bowl of soup, such as a split pea.

Teacup Without Handle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Teacup Without Handle

emojiDetailList.description:
Japanese sake , an alcoholic beverage made from rice. Shown as a sake set with a carafe ( tokkuri ) and drinking cup ( choko ). Color varies widely by platform, with Apple, WhatsApp, and Twitter featuring blue, a traditional ceramic color. Samsung displays the Japanese script for “sake” in red.

Sake was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sake Bottle and Cup” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sake

emojiDetailList.description:
A green bottle of champagne or sparkling wine with label, its cork popping to shoot out its bubbly contents. Used for a range of celebratory occasions, such as New Year's Eve , birthdays, weddings, or other life accomplishments.

Bottle with Popping Cork was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bottle with Popping Cork

emojiDetailList.description:
Red wine served in a stemmed glass. Google previously displayed an orange-colored drink that resembled cognac.

Wine Glass was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wine Glass

emojiDetailList.description:
A stemmed glass with a cone-shaped bowl, used for serving cocktails. Depicted as a martini garnished with an olive. Might be gin or vodka, shaken or stirred. See also Tropical Drink .

Cocktail Glass was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cocktail Glass

emojiDetailList.description:
A sunset-orange-colored tropical beverage in a stemmed glass, as a rum punch or mai tai . Served with a straw and fruit garnish. Many platforms include a cocktail umbrella, hence umbrella drink . Samsung previously featured an electric-blue concoction. See also Cocktail Glass .

Tropical Drink was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tropical Drink

emojiDetailList.description:
A beer, as a golden-colored lager , in a frosty mug. Depicted with a frothy head spilling over the brim. Clinking Beer Mugs is a variation that displays two such beer mugs.

Beer Mug was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Beer Mug

emojiDetailList.description:
Two frosty mugs of beer with frothy heads being clinked together, as done at a celebratory or convivial toast (“Cheers!”). Several platforms include stylized lines to mark the clinking. See also Clinking Glasses .

Clinking Beer Mugs was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Clinking Beer Mugs

emojiDetailList.description:
Two flutes of champagne or sparkling wine being clinked together, as done at a celebratory or convivial toast (“Cheers!”). Samsung’s design suggests two glasses of white wine. Some platforms include stylized links to mark the clinking. See also Clinking Beer Mugs —and Bottle With Popping Cork for a refill.

Clinking Glasses was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Clinking Glasses

emojiDetailList.description:
A short, flat glass, as used for brown liquors like whiskey or Scotch whisky . Apple and WhatsApp serve theirs neat, while other platforms include ice ("on the rocks"). Samsung's glass features the faint initials ONI , an apparent in-company easter egg .

Tumbler Glass was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Tumbler Glass

emojiDetailList.description:
A drinking cup with a straw. Depicted on many platforms as a disposable cup with a lid and bendy straw, as used to serve soft drinks at fast-food restaurants. May be used for a range of non-alcoholic beverages, including milkshakes, smoothies, juice, and to-go beverages.

Color and design vary by platform. Twitter's design suggests a glass of water , Samsung displays Slightly Smiling Face on a red label.

Cup with Straw was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Cup with Straw

emojiDetailList.description:
Bubble tea is a tea-based drink invented in Taiwan which general contain tea, flavored mlk, and sugar. Commonly served with tapioca pearls, also known as boba, in a plastic cup with a wide straw.

Bubble Tea was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Bubble Tea

emojiDetailList.description:
Beverage Box was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Beverage Box

emojiDetailList.description:
Mate is a caffeinated beverage popular in many South American countries. Green in color (from a key ingredient: the dried leaves of yerba mate ) and consumed via a metal straw.

This drink is commonly referred to as yerba mate in English, and sometimes spelled maté (to distinguish from a mate, as in friend).

Mate was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Mate Drink” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Mate

emojiDetailList.description:
Ice was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Ice Cube” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Ice

emojiDetailList.description:
A pair of equal-length chopsticks, an eating utensil used throughout East Asia. Design and color vary widely by platform, though often red or wood-colored and with tips angled together. Featured in many platforms' Steaming Bowl of Food and Takeout Box . A counterpart to utensils such as Fork and Knife and Spoon .

Chopsticks was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Chopsticks

emojiDetailList.description:
A silver fork and knife on either side of a white plate, as set for dinner or another meal. Often used more generally for eating and dining. May be paired with Spoon .

Fork and Knife with Plate was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fork and Knife with Plate

emojiDetailList.description:
A silver fork to the left of a knife, silverware or cutlery used to eat a meal. Often used more generally for eating and dining. May be paired with Spoon or used with Fork and Knife With Plate .

Fork and Knife was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fork and Knife

emojiDetailList.description:
A silver spoon, as used to eat soup, cereal, or ice cream as well as serve food or stir drinks. Positioned at various angles across platforms. May be paired with Fork and Knife , Fork and Knife With Plate , and Bowl With Spoon .

Spoon was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Spoon

emojiDetailList.description:
A person wearing a suit, hovering above the ground with a shadow displayed beneath them. Generally shown wearing a fedora or similar style of hat.

This character was originally introduced into the Webdings font as an “exclamation mark in the style of the rude boy logo found on records by The Specials ". This levitating man was known as Walt Jabsco.

Person in Suit Levitating was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Man in Business Suit Levitating” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Person in Suit Levitating

emojiDetailList.description:
A rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet and/or rope. The Emojipedia Sample image was created with assistance from World Champion Rock Climber Sasha DiGiulian .

Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing .

Person Climbing was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Climbing

emojiDetailList.description:
A male rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope.

Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing .

The Man Climbing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧗 Person Climbing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Climbing

emojiDetailList.description:
A female rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope.

Variations exist for 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing .

The Woman Climbing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧗 Person Climbing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Climbing was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Climbing

emojiDetailList.description:
A person shown in the sport of fencing, with a Rapier-style sword , mask, and protective clothing.

Person Fencing was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Fencer” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Fencing

emojiDetailList.description:
A jockey riding a horse in a horse race. Shown riding to the left of screen on all major platforms. Emoji modifiers change the skin tone of the jockey on some platforms, which can be difficult to discern at small sizes.

Horse Racing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Horse Racing

emojiDetailList.description:
A person downhill-skiiing. Displayed with poles and skis , generally wearing a mask.

Platforms vary in display of scarf, helmet, and color of clothing. No gendered options are provided for this emoji. Skin tones support is not recommended for this emoji, but this is supported by some platforms.

Skier was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Skier

emojiDetailList.description:
A person snowboarding downhill at a ski resort. Wearing clothing designed for cold climates.

Snowboarder was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Snowboarder

emojiDetailList.description:
A person swinging a golf club, attempting to hit a golf ball toward the flag on the green .

Person Golfing was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Golfer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Golfing

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🏌 Golfer emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Golfing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏌 Person Golfing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Golfing was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Golfing

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🏌 Golfer emoji.

The Woman Golfing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏌 Person Golfing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Golfing was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Golfing

emojiDetailList.description:
A person on a surfboard, riding on a wave in the ocean. Wears a wetsuit or board shorts in most versions.

Person Surfing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Surfer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Surfing

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🏄 Surfer emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Surfing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏄 Person Surfing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Surfing was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Surfing

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🏄 Surfer emoji.

The Woman Surfing emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏄 Person Surfing , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Surfing was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Surfing

emojiDetailList.description:
A small rowboat suitable for a small number of people. Couples or families sometimes hire these as an activity on calm waters.

Person Rowing Boat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Rowboat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Rowing Boat

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🚣 Rowboat emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Rowing Boat emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚣 Person Rowing Boat , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Rowing Boat was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Rowing Boat

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🚣 Rowboat emoji.

The Woman Rowing Boat emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚣 Person Rowing Boat , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Rowing Boat was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Rowing Boat

emojiDetailList.description:
A person swimming in a pool, the ocean , or another body of water. Lacked goggles on prior versions of iOS.

Swims facing to the left of screen on all major platforms.

Person Swimming was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Swimmer” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Swimming

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🏊 Swimmer emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Swimming emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏊 Person Swimming , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Swimming was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Swimming

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🏊 Swimmer emoji.

The Woman Swimming emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏊 Person Swimming , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Swimming was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Swimming

emojiDetailList.description:
A person with a ball, which is generally displayed as a basketballer running and dribbling (bouncing) the basketball .

Person Bouncing Ball was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Person with Ball” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Bouncing Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the ⛹ Person With Ball emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Bouncing Ball emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining ⛹ Person Bouncing Ball , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Bouncing Ball was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Bouncing Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the ⛹ Person With Ball emoji.

The Woman Bouncing Ball emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining ⛹ Person Bouncing Ball , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Bouncing Ball was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Bouncing Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
A person lifting a barbell loaded with weights above their head.

Person Lifting Weights was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Weight Lifter” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Lifting Weights

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🏋 Weight Lifter emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Lifting Weights emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏋 Person Lifting Weights , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Lifting Weights was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Lifting Weights

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🏋 Weight Lifter emoji.

The Woman Lifting Weights emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏋 Person Lifting Weights , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Lifting Weights was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Lifting Weights

emojiDetailList.description:
A person riding a bicycle for leisure, sport or transport. Intended to be gender-neutral.

Person Biking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bicyclist” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🚴 Bicyclist emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Biking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚴 Person Biking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Biking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🚴 Bicyclist emoji.

The Woman Biking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚴 Person Biking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Biking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
A person ( cyclist ) who rides a mountain bike: a type of off-road bicycle . Intended to be gender-neutral.

Person Mountain Biking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Mountain Bicyclist” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Mountain Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
The male version of the 🚵 Mountain Bicyclist emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.

The Man Mountain Biking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚵 Person Mountain Biking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Mountain Biking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Mountain Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
The female version of the 🚵 Mountain Bicyclist emoji.

The Woman Mountain Biking emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🚵 Person Mountain Biking , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Mountain Biking was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Mountain Biking

emojiDetailList.description:
A person doing a cartwheel, representing the sport of gymnastics.

Person Cartwheeling was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Person Doing Cartwheel” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Cartwheeling

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Cartwheeling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤸 Person Cartwheeling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Cartwheeling was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Cartwheeling

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Cartwheeling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤸 Person Cartwheeling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Cartwheeling was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Cartwheeling

emojiDetailList.description:
Two people in the sport of wrestling.

People Wrestling was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Wrestlers” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: People Wrestling

emojiDetailList.description:
