The Men Wrestling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤼 People Wrestling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

🚩 This Emoji ZWJ Sequence has not been Recommended For General Interchange ( RGI ) by Unicode. Expect limited cross-platform support.
emojiDetailList.title: Men Wrestling

emojiDetailList.description:
The Women Wrestling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤼 People Wrestling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

🚩 This Emoji ZWJ Sequence has not been Recommended For General Interchange ( RGI ) by Unicode. Expect limited cross-platform support.
emojiDetailList.title: Women Wrestling

emojiDetailList.description:
A person shown in water with a ball, playing the sport of water polo.

Person Playing Water Polo was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Water Polo” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Playing Water Polo

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Playing Water Polo emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤽 Person Playing Water Polo , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Playing Water Polo was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Playing Water Polo

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Playing Water Polo emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤽 Person Playing Water Polo , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Playing Water Polo was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Playing Water Polo

emojiDetailList.description:
Person Playing Handball was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Handball” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Playing Handball

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Playing Handball emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤾 Person Playing Handball , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Playing Handball was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Playing Handball

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Playing Handball emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤾 Person Playing Handball , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Playing Handball was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Playing Handball

emojiDetailList.description:
A person juggling between three and five colored balls. The person shown in this emoji generally has the appearance of a man, and wears a hat on most major platforms.

Person Juggling was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Juggling” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Juggling

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man Juggling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤹 Person Juggling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man Juggling was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Man Juggling

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman Juggling emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🤹 Person Juggling , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman Juggling was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman Juggling

emojiDetailList.description:
Person in Lotus Position was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person in Lotus Position

emojiDetailList.description:
The Man in Lotus Position emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧘 Person in Lotus Position , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♂ Male Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Man in Lotus Position was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Man in Lotus Position

emojiDetailList.description:
The Woman in Lotus Position emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🧘 Person in Lotus Position , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ♀ Female Sign . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Woman in Lotus Position was added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Woman in Lotus Position

emojiDetailList.description:
A circular ‘big top’ circus tent, with a triangle flag on top.

Circus Tent was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Circus Tent

emojiDetailList.description:
A skateboard emoji, shown on some platforms from the top and others showing the under-side of the board.

Emojipedia's sample image was modelled after Tony Hawk's skateboard .

Skateboard was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Skateboard

emojiDetailList.description: Canoe was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Canoe

emojiDetailList.description:
An awareness ribbon , worn to show support of a cause or group.

Reminder Ribbon was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Reminder Ribbon

emojiDetailList.description:
A ticket or tickets to an event that may say "Admit One" on the front. Shown in pink or yellow on most platforms.

Admission Tickets was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Admission Tickets

emojiDetailList.description:
A paper ticket, which may be for a theatre show, sporting event, or other ticketed performance. Shown in blue, yellow or grey on most platforms.

Ticket was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ticket

emojiDetailList.description:
A ribbon and medallion generally awarded to a person in the military for heroic acts.

Military Medal was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Military Medal

emojiDetailList.description:
A trophy given as an recognition of achievement, usually in sports. The trophy emoji is a gold cup, with a engraving on the bottom detailing the award.

In Snapchat , the trophy provides access to the Trophy Case for unlocking emoji achievements .

Trophy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Trophy

emojiDetailList.description:
A gold medal, given to a person who has won a sporting event, such as a race. Not to be confused with the military medal emoji .

Sports Medal was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sports Medal

emojiDetailList.description: 1st Place Medal was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “First Place Medal” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: 1st Place Medal

emojiDetailList.description: 2nd Place Medal was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Second Place Medal” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: 2nd Place Medal

emojiDetailList.description: 3rd Place Medal was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Third Place Medal” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: 3rd Place Medal

emojiDetailList.description:
A round, black and white ball used in the game of soccer , which is known as football in much of the world. See also: emojis for the World Cup .

Soccer Ball was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Soccer Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
A white baseball, with regulation red stitching. Used in the game of the same name, baseball .

Baseball was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baseball

emojiDetailList.description:
A softball, which is differentiated from a baseball by size (it is larger, though hard to tell in emoji form) and color (yellow, not white).

Softball was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Softball

emojiDetailList.description:
An orange-colored basketball displayed with a hoop. Many versions of this emoji omit the hoop, and display only the basketball.

This emoji can be sent on Facebook Messenger to unlock a hidden basketball game .

Basketball was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Basketball and Hoop” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Basketball

emojiDetailList.description:
A volleyball emoji, showing the round ball used in the sport. Played as part of the Summer Olympic Games .

Volleyball was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Volleyball

emojiDetailList.description:
The oval ball used in the game of American football , known as gridiron in some countries.

American Football was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: American Football

emojiDetailList.description:
The oval-shaped ball used in the game of rugby . Varies slightly in shape in the two main versions of the game: rugby union and rugby league .

The appearance of this emoji varies, with a brown leather appearance in Apple and Google’s imagery, but a more popular white-with-highlight color in Twitter’s design.

Rugby Football was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rugby Football

emojiDetailList.description:
A tennis racket (racquet) with a tennis ball. Only a ball is shown on Apple, LG, Twitter, Facebook, and Mozilla platforms.

Tennis was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Tennis Racquet and Ball” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tennis

emojiDetailList.description:
A flying disc, more commonly known as a frisbee. Used in the sport of Ultimate or disc golf .

Flying Disc was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Flying Disc

emojiDetailList.description:
Ten-pin bowling emoji, showing a bowling ball and pins.

Bowling was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bowling

emojiDetailList.description:
A cricket bat, with a cricket ball also shown. May be displayed with a wicket present.

Cricket Game was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Cricket Bat and Ball” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cricket Game

emojiDetailList.description:
A hockey stick and ball, used in the sport of field hockey. Not to be confused with the ice hockey stick and puck .

Field Hockey was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Field Hockey Stick and Ball” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Field Hockey

emojiDetailList.description:
A hockey stick and puck, used in the sport of ice hockey. Not to be confused with the field hockey stick and ball .

Ice Hockey was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Ice Hockey Stick and Puck” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ice Hockey

emojiDetailList.description: Lacrosse was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Lacrosse Stick and Ball” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Lacrosse

emojiDetailList.description:
A paddle and ping pong ball used in the sport of table tennis.

Ping Pong was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Table Tennis Paddle and Ball” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ping Pong

emojiDetailList.description: Badminton was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Badminton Racquet and Shuttlecock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Badminton

emojiDetailList.description:
A padded boxing glove, used in the sport of boxing. Usually red.

Boxing Glove was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Boxing Glove

emojiDetailList.description:
A white uniform used in marital arts such as judo or karate. Held together using a material belt. Known as keikogi in Japanese.

Martial Arts Uniform was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Martial Arts Uniform

emojiDetailList.description: Goal Net was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Goal Net

emojiDetailList.description:
A red, triangular flag shown sitting in the hole of a golf course green. Some versions of this emoji also include golf balls.

Android previously displayed this emoji as the head of a putter (golf club) hitting a golf ball.

Not to be confused with the Triangular Flag on Post emoji .

Flag in Hole was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Flag in Hole

emojiDetailList.description:
A single ice skate used for ice skating. Shown in white and facing right on most platforms.

In the sport of figure skating, a white ice skate is traditionally worn by women, and a black ice skate worn by men. This emoji doesn't define the color to be used, but no major vendor currently displays this as black.

Ice Skate was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ice Skate

emojiDetailList.description:
A fishing rod (pole) with a fish caught on the end.

Fishing Pole was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Fishing Pole and Fish” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fishing Pole

emojiDetailList.description:
A singlet or running shirt. Shown with a sash.

Running Shirt was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Running Shirt with Sash” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Running Shirt

emojiDetailList.description:
A pair of skis which are shown on some platforms alongside ski poles and/or ski boots. The color and design of the skis varies by platform, with some versions also showing the skis moving at speed.

Distinct from the skier emoji which features a person skiing.

Skis was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Ski and Ski Boot” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Skis

emojiDetailList.description:
A sled, otherwise known as a toboggan or sledge.

Sled was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Sled

emojiDetailList.description: Curling Stone was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Curling Stone

emojiDetailList.description:
A dart board with dart hitting the center / bullseye region.

Direct Hit was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Direct Hit

emojiDetailList.description:
The game of billiards, of which pool is a common version. This emoji displays the black 8 ball on most platforms, which looks similar to the Magic 8-Ball toy.

Samsung displays this emoji with a cue and triangular arrangement of colored balls.

Pool 8 Ball was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Billiards” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pool 8 Ball

emojiDetailList.description:
A video game emoji, shown on major platforms as a console gamepad with D-pad , joysticks , and buttons.

Video Game was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Video Game

emojiDetailList.description:
A gambling machine generally found in casinos. Shows three wheels with a lever to the side. Most platforms display three 7 digits on this emoji.

Slot Machine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Slot Machine

emojiDetailList.description:
A six-sided die, used in a range of board and turn-based games. Commonly called dice which refers to the plural of die .

Most other platforms display this emoji as a single game die in white or red. LG shows two game dice in this emoji.

Game Die was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Game Die

emojiDetailList.description: Puzzle Piece was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Jigsaw Puzzle Piece” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Puzzle Piece

emojiDetailList.description: Chess Pawn was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Chess Pawn” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Chess Pawn

emojiDetailList.description:
Two masks often used on maps to indicate a theatre, these originate in Greek Theatre as masks of tragedy and comedy .

One mask frowns, the other smiles.

Performing Arts was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Performing Arts

emojiDetailList.description:
A palette used by an artist when painting, to store and mix paint colors.

Artist Palette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Artist Palette

emojiDetailList.description:
A spool of thread, as used for sewing. Thread color varies across platforms, though often depicted in red or blue and on a wooden spool. Sometimes shown with an end unraveling.

Commonly used for various content concerning sewing, knitting, arts and crafts, clothing and fashion, and metaphorical threads (e.g., a discussion thread online).

WhatsApp’s design includes a needle.

Thread was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Spool of Thread” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Thread

emojiDetailList.description:
A ball of yarn, as used to knit a scarf . Color varies across platforms, but often depicted in green, blue, or magenta and shown with an end unraveling. Sometimes depicted with a pair of knitting needles stuck in the ball.

Commonly used for various content concerning knitting and needlework (e.g., sewing , crocheting), clothing and fashion, arts and crafts, cold weather, and cats.

Yarn was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Ball of Yarn” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Yarn

emojiDetailList.description:
A staff (or stave) showing a treble clef and five horizontal lines.

Musical Score was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Musical Score

emojiDetailList.description:
A microphone, used to amplify a person’s voice when speaking or singing. Shown with music notes on most platforms, implying it to be used for a singer / singing.

Microphone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Microphone

emojiDetailList.description:
Headphones, used to listen to music or other forms audio, such as podcasts. Most platforms display this emoji with large over-ear headphones in shades of black, blue, and gray.

Apple previously displayed this emoji as iconic iPod/iPhone white earbuds .

Headphone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Headphone

emojiDetailList.description: Saxophone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Saxophone

emojiDetailList.description:
Accordion was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Accordion

emojiDetailList.description:
A guitar, which is mostly shown as an electric guitar and usually in generally red.

Discontinued emoji sets or such as LG and HTC displayed this as an acoustic guitar, as did previous version of Windows and Twemoji .

Guitar was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Guitar

emojiDetailList.description:
A small section of a music keyboard, which differs from a computer keyboard .

Showing white and black keys, this keyboard is played by a pianist to make music . Commonly used as a piano emoji.

Musical Keyboard was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Musical Keyboard

emojiDetailList.description:
A trumpet, a brass instrument played in jazz bands.

Trumpet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Trumpet

emojiDetailList.description:
A violin emoji. Sometimes  used in the context of the world’s smallest violin .

Violin was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Violin

emojiDetailList.description:
A drum shown with drumsticks. A percussion instrument which is likely to be displayed as a snare drum.

Drum was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Drum with Drumsticks” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Drum

emojiDetailList.description:
Long Drum was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Long Drum

emojiDetailList.description:
A board which contains the scene name, number, and film. A person ‘claps’ the board shut at the top while saying “Action” or “Cut” to indicate the start and stop of a scene that is being filmed.

This is used to synchronise the audio of the clap with the visuals.

Clapper Board was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Clapper Board

emojiDetailList.description:
A bow and arrow used in the sport of archery. May also be used by cupid .

Bow and Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bow and Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
A small rowboat suitable for a small number of people. Couples or families sometimes hire these as an activity on calm waters.

Person Rowing Boat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Rowboat” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Previously displayed a gendered appearance. Platforms switched to a gender-inclusive design for this emoji in 2019.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Rowing Boat

emojiDetailList.description:
Shows a map of the country of Japan, which is the only country to have its own emoji map. Other countries can be found on the various globe emojis , or the world map emoji .

Map of Japan was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Silhouette of Japan” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Map of Japan

emojiDetailList.description:
A mountain with snow resting at higher altitudes. Similar in appearance to the Mount Fuji emoji.

Snow-Capped Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Snow Capped Mountain” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Snow-Capped Mountain

emojiDetailList.description:
A mountain shown with two peaks and blue sky. Similar to the snow capped mountain emoji .

Mountain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mountain

emojiDetailList.description:
A volcano, erupting with smoke and lava.

Volcano was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Volcano

emojiDetailList.description:
Mount Fuji (called Fuji-san in Japan) is the largest mountain in Japan. Often seen with snow on the peak in colder months of the year.

It is considered lucky in Japan to dream of Mt Fuji in the first dream of the new year .

Mount Fuji was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mount Fuji

emojiDetailList.description:
A campsite featuring a tent and a tree , and perhaps a campfire. Similar to the tent emoji.

Camping was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Camping

emojiDetailList.description:
A beach showing sand, and an umbrella for protection from the sun .

Beach with Umbrella was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Beach with Umbrella

emojiDetailList.description: Desert was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Desert

emojiDetailList.description: Desert Island was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Desert Island

emojiDetailList.description:
A national park, generally displayed with mountains , a river or stream, and trees .

National Park was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: National Park

emojiDetailList.description:
A large capacity stadium, featuring a large amount of seating for sporting fans, or people attending other shows hosted by the stadium.

Stadium was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Stadium

emojiDetailList.description: Classical Building was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Classical Building

emojiDetailList.description:
A construction site generally depicted as a tower crane shown lifting steel or other building materials.

Building Construction was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Building Construction

emojiDetailList.description:
Multiple houses.

Houses was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “House Buildings” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Houses

emojiDetailList.description:
A house which is unoccupied, and has become derelict. In a state of disrepair.

Derelict House was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Derelict House Building” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Derelict House

emojiDetailList.description:
A house, otherwise known as a home when someone is living in it. Suitable for a couple or larger family, other perhaps housemates.

Distinct from an apartment building due to its detached form, this house is likely in the suburbs of a city or a rural area.

House was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “House Building” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: House

emojiDetailList.description:
A suburban-looking house, with a tree, flower, or shrubs around it in the garden.

House with Garden was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: House with Garden

emojiDetailList.description:
A generic, high-rise office building. Generally found in cities, and most active during business hours.

The office building shown in Twemoji 2.0 is of Twitter HQ in San Fransisco.

Office Building was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Office Building

emojiDetailList.description:
A Japanese post office, featuring the テ Japanese postal mark on the front of the building (or showing this mark instead of the building in Microsoft’s artwork).

Japanese Post Office was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese Post Office

emojiDetailList.description:
A European-style post office. A postal horn can be seen on the front, which is commonly found in the logos of European Postal Services .

Post Office was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “European Post Office” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Post Office

emojiDetailList.description:
A place where people are taken to receive medical care. This hospital has a large red cross on the front, often used as a symbol for health care.

Hospital was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hospital

emojiDetailList.description:
A retail bank branch, where people can perform money -related tasks. Also a common location to find an ATM .

This emoji came to also mean "slacking off" or evading responsibility in Japan, due to the BK letters being associated with the slang term bakkureru .

Bank was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bank

emojiDetailList.description:
A hotel building, displayed on most platforms as a building with many windows and a letter H on the front.

Can be easily confused with the Love Hotel , or Hospital emoji. Microsoft this emoji as a bed, when viewed using Windows.

Hotel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hotel

emojiDetailList.description:
A love hotel is a hotel that can be hired by the hour instead of as accommodation for the evening.

Sometimes mistaken for a get well soon emoji due to the similarity in appearance to the hospital . The Microsoft version of this emoji previously displaying a bed with a heart above it .

Love Hotel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Love Hotel

emojiDetailList.description:
A shop that is generally open for longer hours than a regular supermarket, sometimes 24 hours per day.

Sells a range of goods from snacks, meals, hygiene products and household items.

Convenience Store was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Convenience Store

emojiDetailList.description:
A school building with multiple storeys, and a clock on the front. A place that children, or teenagers attend for their education.

Displays on Windows as a collection of school-related items: an apple , ruler , and pencil .

School was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: School

emojiDetailList.description:
A large department store, selling a range of products to the general public. Shown as a large building with a billboard on most platforms, or as a shopping bag on Windows.

Department Store was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Department Store

emojiDetailList.description:
An industrial factory, with flue-gas stacks releasing exhaust into the air.

Factory was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Factory

emojiDetailList.description:
A traditional Japanese Castle, usually made from stone and wood.

Japanese Castle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese Castle

emojiDetailList.description:
A castle, in a style that can be found in France and other parts of Europe .

Castle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “European Castle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Castle

emojiDetailList.description:
An emoji to depict a wedding, displayed by most vendors as a Christian church and love hearts . Some platforms display a cross or bell on the building.

Wedding was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wedding

emojiDetailList.description:
The Tokyo Tower is the second-tallest building in Japan, located in Minato, Tokyo.

Built in 1957, the design of the Tokyo Tower  was inspired by the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France and may be confused for it due to the small size of the emoji.

Tokyo Tower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tokyo Tower

emojiDetailList.description:
The Statue of Liberty , often used as a depiction of New York City .

Statue of Liberty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Statue of Liberty

emojiDetailList.description:
A church building, generally associated with Christian denominations. In addition quiet prayer , churches hold regular worship services, weddings , baptisms and funerals.

Church was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Church

emojiDetailList.description:
A mosque building, a place of worship for followes of Islam . Shown with a domed roof and a minaret .

Mosque was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mosque

emojiDetailList.description:
Hindu Temple was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Hindu Temple

emojiDetailList.description:
A synague; a place of worship for followers of Judaism. Displayed with a Star of David on the front.

Synagogue was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Synagogue

emojiDetailList.description:
A shrine used for the Japanese Shinto religion. This emoji generally displays the torii , which is the gate to the Shinto Shrine. The torii is generally a red colored structure, with a curved roof section above two posts.

This icon is used on maps in Japan to represent the location of a Shinto Shrine, similar to how the hot springs emoji is the icon used on Japanese maps to show the location of an onsen.

Shinto Shrine was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shinto Shrine

emojiDetailList.description:
A cube-shaped building located at the centre of the Al-Masjid al-Haram Mosque in Mecca.

Kaaba was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Kaaba

emojiDetailList.description:
A water fountain, found in a park or other public space. Used for decorative purposes. A variety of styles of fountain are shown across different platforms.

Fountain was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fountain

emojiDetailList.description:
A tent, used for protection from wind and rain when camping. Often shown at night time , under stars.

Tent was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tent

emojiDetailList.description:
Foggy weather displayed as fog covering a bridge or cityscape, depending on the platform. For platforms that show a bridge, the red Golden Gate Bridge is generally displayed.

Foggy was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Foggy

emojiDetailList.description:
A night sky with stars, depicted on major platforms as a cityscape at night.

Night with Stars was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Night with Stars

emojiDetailList.description: Cityscape was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cityscape

emojiDetailList.description:
The sun rising over a mountain range, early in the morning.

Sunrise Over Mountains was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sunrise Over Mountains

emojiDetailList.description:
A sun rising, early in the morning. Can be difficult to distinguish from a sunset in some versions of this artwork.

Sunrise was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sunrise

emojiDetailList.description:
A view of city buildings as the last light disappears from the sky. An orange (or blue) glow lingers, before the stars of the night sky become visible.

Cityscape at Dusk was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cityscape at Dusk

emojiDetailList.description:
A beautiful view, featuring an orange sky, with the sun setting over the buildings of a city skyline.

Sunset was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sunset Over Buildings” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sunset

emojiDetailList.description:
A lit-up bridge, shown at night.

Bridge at Night was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bridge at Night

emojiDetailList.description:
A wooden painted horse, found on the carousel at a carnival. Faces to the left-of screen.

A previous version of Windows displayed the carousel horse facing right , which was changed to face left on Windows 10 for cross-platform consistency.

Carousel Horse was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Carousel Horse

emojiDetailList.description:
A large rotating wheel, often found at a carnival or fair.

Ferris Wheel was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ferris Wheel

emojiDetailList.description:
A roller coaster in a theme park going down a dip in the ride. Three carriages can be seen with two people in each red carriage.

Roller Coaster was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Roller Coaster

emojiDetailList.description:
A steam train, powered by coal or wood. An early type of locomotive, now mostly replaced by electric or diesel trains .

Oddly, this emoji does not show any steam coming from the train.

Locomotive was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Steam Locomotive” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Locomotive

emojiDetailList.description:
A railway ( railroad ) car (carriage) that is generally pulled along a railway line by a locomotive . Shown with a pantograph above the carriage on many platforms which makes it look more like a tram car .

Google’s artwork previously looked like a bus and Microsoft's older versions appeared similar to a minecart .

Railway Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Railway Car

emojiDetailList.description:
A high speed train, designed to cover long distances at high speed.

High-Speed Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: High-Speed Train

emojiDetailList.description:
A high speed train, designed to cover long distances at high speed. Also features a streamlined bullet nose, often used in reference to the Shinkansen in Japan.

Bullet Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “High-Speed Train with Bullet Nose” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bullet Train

emojiDetailList.description:
A train, of no specified type. Due to the presence of a steam train and fast train emoji, this is likely to be a regular electrified or diesel passenger train.

Train was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Train

emojiDetailList.description:
A metro: frequent underground train found in built-up areas with high populations.

This emoji is generally displayed as a forward-facing train, with some platforms also displaying a tunnel as a circle surrounding the train. Apple's artwork shows the characters IL2 which may be a reference to one of the more locked-down buildings at Apple's Infinite Loop Headquarters during iPhone development (IL2 = Infinite Loop 2).

Metro was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Metro

emojiDetailList.description:
A form of public transport similar to a tram , but running on a track or network separated from cars and other types of traffic.

Difficult to discern from a train at small sizes.

Light Rail was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Light Rail

emojiDetailList.description:
A station, presumed to be a train station. Displays a train alongside a platform, where passengers can board.

Station was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Station

emojiDetailList.description:
A form of public transport on rails, usually found on streets in cities or other urban areas. For short or medium-length journeys.

Trams tend to be similar to light rail , with the difference being that they don’t tend to have their own dedicated tracks.

This emoji is generally shown as the front of the tram, on tracks. The intended usage of this emoji, instead of the tram car emoji is not clear.

Tram was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tram

emojiDetailList.description:
Similar to a train , but running on a single track. Monorails are often found at theme parks , or other tourist destinations.

Monorail was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Monorail

emojiDetailList.description:
A train and railway in the mountains . Displayed as a funicular in Microsoft’s artwork, or a regular train on other platforms.

Android displays this train front-facing, leaving a tunnel , which appears similarly to the metro emoji at small sizes.

Mountain Railway was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mountain Railway

emojiDetailList.description:
A form of public transport on rails, usually found on streets in cities or other urban areas. For short or medium-length journeys.

Trams tend to be similar to light rail , with the difference being that they don’t tend to have their own dedicated tracks.

This emoji is generally shown as the side of the tram. The intended usage of this emoji, instead of the tram emoji is not clear.

Tram Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tram Car

emojiDetailList.description:
A bus used for public transport in cities and towns. Could also be used as a school bus.

Bus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bus

emojiDetailList.description:
The front of a bus , showing the windscreen, as well as wing mirrors in some versions of this emoji.

Oncoming Bus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oncoming Bus

emojiDetailList.description:
A type of bus that uses overhead electrical wires for power. Appears similar to a cross between a bus and a tram car .

Trolleybus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Trolleybus

emojiDetailList.description:
A small bus or minivan designed to carry fewer people than a full-sized bus . Displayed in white on most platforms (green on Facebook ).

Minibus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Minibus

emojiDetailList.description:
An ambulance, used to transport patients between their home and the hospital .

Ambulance was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ambulance

emojiDetailList.description:
A red fire truck, an essential part of emergency services along with a police car or ambulance .

May be on the way to put out a fire .

Fire Engine was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fire Engine

emojiDetailList.description:
A police car, shown with an emergency light on the top.

This emoji is displayed from the side, as opposed to the oncoming police car emoji, which is shown from the front.

Police Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Police Car

emojiDetailList.description:
A police car, shown with an emergency light on the top.

This emoji is displayed from the front, as opposed to the police car emoji, which is shown from the side.

Oncoming Police Car was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oncoming Police Car

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow taxicab, iconically seen in New York City . Shown from the side, as opposed to the oncoming taxi emoji.

Taxi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Taxi

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow taxicab, iconically seen in New York City . Shown from the front, as opposed to the taxi emoji which displays the side of the vehicle.

Oncoming Taxi was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oncoming Taxi

emojiDetailList.description:
A car shown from the side, facing right-to-left. Appears as a red car on most platforms (which goes faster ), except on Android where this displays as a silver car ( previously blue ).

Automobile was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Automobile

emojiDetailList.description:
A car being shown from the front. The windscreen and hood (bonnet in British English) of the car can be seen facing forward.

This car shows in red or blue on most platforms. Silver on Android.

Oncoming Automobile was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oncoming Automobile

emojiDetailList.description:
A vehicle used for recreation, which is generally understood to mean a campervan or motorhome.

May have originally been intended to represent an SUV, based on most versions of this emoji featuring a large vehicle with a spare tyre on the back.

Sport Utility Vehicle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Recreational Vehicle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sport Utility Vehicle

emojiDetailList.description: Delivery Truck was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Delivery Truck

emojiDetailList.description: Articulated Lorry was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Articulated Lorry

emojiDetailList.description:
A tractor, may be used by a farmer or other occupation on the land.

Tractor was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Tractor

emojiDetailList.description:
A racing car which appears as a formula one vehicle or rally car on most platforms. Generally displayed in red.

Apple's version of this emoji features the Swift (programming language) logo on the side.

Racing Car was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Racing Car

emojiDetailList.description:
A motorcycle, otherwise known as a motorbike used for sport/racing purposes. For a transport-based motorcycle, use a motor scooter.

Motorcycle was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Racing Motorcycle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Motorcycle

emojiDetailList.description:
A motor scooter, which may be displayed as any type of motorbike with or without a step-through frame. Distinct from the racing motorcycle , which is used for sport, not transport.

Motor Scooter was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Motor Scooter

emojiDetailList.description:
An auto rickshaw (often referred to as a tuk tuk ) is a motorized version of a cycle rickshaw, used for transport in many regions of the world. Generally has three wheels and various levels of shelter from the outside elements (some open air, some are enclosed).

Auto Rickshaw was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Auto Rickshaw

emojiDetailList.description:
A bicycle, sometimes called a push bike, used for transport or sport.

Bicycle was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bicycle

emojiDetailList.description:
A non-motorized scooter, with two wheels and handles.

Kick Scooter was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Scooter” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Kick Scooter

emojiDetailList.description:
A sign indicating the location of a bus stop by the side of a road.

Some platforms display this as a red, white and blue sign which can be found in parts of Japan. This interpretation has a slight resemblance to the Pepsi Globe .

Other platforms base this emoji design on bus stop signage of other regions .

Bus Stop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bus Stop

emojiDetailList.description:
A wide road shown from a first person perspective. Apple's artwork displays a road sign to Curpertino.

Motorway was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Motorway

emojiDetailList.description: Railway Track was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Railway Track

emojiDetailList.description:
A fuel pump, used to fill up a vehicle with gas / petrol.

Shown as red or orange on most platforms. Apple's artwork shows a droplet icon and the numbers 00322 but previously displayed the letter G on the front.

Fuel Pump was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fuel Pump

emojiDetailList.description:
A revolving red light seen on top of a police car . Often used in emergency circumstances in addition to a siren making a loud warning sound .

Police Car Light was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Police Cars Revolving Light” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Police Car Light

emojiDetailList.description:
A set of red, orange (amber) and green traffic lights, used at intersections. Less common than the vertical traffic light .

Similar in appearance to the traffic light controls in the upper-left of every OS X windows.

Horizontal Traffic Light was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Horizontal Traffic Light

emojiDetailList.description:
A set of red, orange (amber) and green traffic lights, used at intersections. More common than the horizontal traffic light .

Vertical Traffic Light was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Vertical Traffic Light

emojiDetailList.description:
A sign used to indicate roadwork or construction . Generally shown as yellow and black diagonal stripes, and often used to physically block access to a road or area. May be used to imply a website or project in progress or under construction.

Construction was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Construction Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Construction

emojiDetailList.description:
A metal device, dropped out of a boat to prevent it drifting away from the current location.

An anchor also refers to a place on a webpage that may be directly linked to, rather than simply loading a page and requiring a user to scroll to the correct location.

Anchor was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Anchor

emojiDetailList.description:
A sailboat, otherwise known as a sailing boat or yacht.  Uses wind as the source of propulsion to move around a body of water.

The color of the sails in this emoji vary by platform, with vendors displaying blue sails, orange sails, or a mix of red, yellow, orange, blue or white.

Sailboat was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sailboat

emojiDetailList.description:
A motorized speedboat used for recreation on lakes, or other bodies of water.

Speedboat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speedboat

emojiDetailList.description: Passenger Ship was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Passenger Ship

emojiDetailList.description: Ferry was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ferry

emojiDetailList.description: Motor Boat was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Motor Boat

emojiDetailList.description:
A large ship, used for transport of people or cargo across the ocean. May be a cruise ship, commonly found around tropical locations.

Ship was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ship

emojiDetailList.description:
Used either as a literal airplane, to represent an overseas vacation, or sometimes as a proxy for airplane mode on a phone or tablet.

Use of this emoji declined in April 2020 , potentially as a result of global air travel limitations.

Airplane was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Airplane

emojiDetailList.description:
A light aircraft which is shown with propellers on some platforms.

Small Airplane was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Small Airplane

emojiDetailList.description:
A plane taking off from a runway. Generally displayed left-right, with the front of the plane elevated.

Airplane Departure was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Airplane Departure

emojiDetailList.description:
A plane approaching a runway for landing. Generally displayed left-right, with the front of the plane facing toward the ground in a position that may result in a crash if attempted in the real world.

Airplane Arrival was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Airplane Arriving” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Airplane Arrival

emojiDetailList.description:
Parachute was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Parachute

emojiDetailList.description:
A seat, which could refer to any form of place to sit, with the distinction that a seat is generally fixed, and is not a chair which can be moved.

This emoji is intended to be a seat on some form of mass-transit, such as on an airplane , train or bus . Google previously displayed this as an orange wooden chair .

Seat was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Seat

emojiDetailList.description:
A helicopter, which can hover in the air. Often seen in emergency circumstances such as transporting patients to a hospital , or for police or fire-fighting activity.

Helicopter was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Helicopter

emojiDetailList.description:
Similar to a monorail, a suspension railway is elevated, but the vehicle is suspended under the track.

Suspension Railway was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Suspension Railway

emojiDetailList.description: Mountain Cableway was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mountain Cableway

emojiDetailList.description:
An Aerial Tramway, most commonly seen at ski resorts, for transport between locations on a mountain. Can also be used as a tourist attraction, or as a form of public transport.

Aerial Tramway was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Aerial Tramway

emojiDetailList.description:
A satellite which orbits the earth, and is generally used for communications, weather, and GPS.

Satellite was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Satellite

emojiDetailList.description:
A rocket being propelled into space .

Rocket was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Rocket

emojiDetailList.description:
A flying saucer, sometimes referred to as an Unidentified Flying Object (UFO). Shown on some platforms with an alien at the controls and/or a beam of light emitting from the base.

Flying Saucer was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Flying Saucer

emojiDetailList.description:
Ringed Planet was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Ringed Planet

aliases: When You Wish Upon A Star
emojiDetailList.description:
A stylized representation of a shooting star , a small, fast meteor that burns up in the atmosphere. Generally depicted as a gold, five-point star trailing yellow motion lines against a night sky, as if moving down to the left.

May be used for astronomical stars and other content concerning space. Also may be used for flair or flourish. Sometimes used as a visual reference to NBC’s More You Know public service announcement, popular in the 1990s and featuring a shooting star logo.

Not to be confused with 💫 Dizzy , ⭐ Star , 🌟 Glowing Star , or ✨ Sparkles , though their applications may overlap.

Google’s star is trailed, without backdrop, by yellow lines, though they were previously blue. Microsoft’s star is trailed, without backdrop, by blue lines, though they were previously yellow.

Shooting Star was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shooting Star

emojiDetailList.description:
The Milky Way – a galaxy of billions of stars that includes our own solar system and planet earth .

Shown by many platforms as a night sky, with silhouettes of mountains or hills in the foreground.

Milky Way was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Milky Way

emojiDetailList.description:
A large, open umbrella, as provides shade at a beach or patio. Generally depicted as a striped umbrella inserted into a patch of sand and tilted to the right.

Commonly used for various content concerning the beach, summer vacations (holidays), sunny weather, and relaxing outdoors.

The color of the stripes varies across platforms; Apple (no sand) and Samsung’s are red and yellow, Twitter and Facebook’s red and white, Google’s blue and white, and WhatsApp’s rainbow -colored.

Not to be confused with other umbrella-related emoji , such as 🏖️ Beach With Umbrella , though their applications may overlap.

Umbrella on Ground was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Umbrella on Ground

emojiDetailList.description:
Firework emoji, showing a explosion of colored light in the night sky, used for any number of celebrations such as New Year's Eve .

Colors vary by platform, and may include pink, purple, yellow, blue, and green.

Fireworks was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fireworks

emojiDetailList.description:
A  sparkler: a form of hand-held firework often used at parties and celebrations. The sparkler is lit at one end, and held at the other.

Most platforms display this with the lit end held down, as is the style for senko hanabi ("incense-stick fireworks") which is a traditional sparkler from from Japan.

Sparkler was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Firework Sparkler” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sparkler

emojiDetailList.description:
Moon Viewing Ceremonies (called Tsukimi in Japan) are held each year in autumn to celebrate the full moon and waxing moon in Japan.

This symbol shows Japanese pampas grass and dango (sweet dessert food) which are used in the ceremony, as well as the moon in the background.

Moon Viewing Ceremony was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Moon Viewing Ceremony

emojiDetailList.description:
A banded stack of yen banknotes, the paper currency of Japan . Color and detail vary across platforms, but usually shown in green, yellow, or pink with the yen symbol, ¥. Commonly used for various content concerning money and wealth, not restricted to Japan.

Apple and WhatsApp’s designs depict the ¥1,000 banknote, Facebook’s features a Japanese character for yen (円) and a cherry blossom .

Yen Banknote was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Banknote with Yen Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Yen Banknote

emojiDetailList.description:
Cash money! A banded stack of U.S. dollar banknotes, the paper currency of the United States of America . Green hue and detail vary across platforms, but shown with the dollar sign , $. Commonly used for various content concerning wealth and money, not restricted to the U.S.

Apple’s design depicts $1 bills with Cupertino and John Appleseed in the treasury signature sections. WhatsApp’s design depicts $10 bills, Facebook’s displays a Statue of Liberty torch.

Dollar Banknote was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Banknote with Dollar Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dollar Banknote

emojiDetailList.description:
A banded stack of euro banknotes, the paper currency of the European Union (EU). Color and detail vary across platforms, but shown with the euro sign, €. Commonly used for various content concerning wealth and money, not restricted to the EU.

Some vendors, including Apple and Samsung, depict green €100 bills; others, including Google, WhatsApp, and Facebook, depict blue €20 bills. Facebook additionally features the EU flag .

Euro Banknote was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Banknote with Euro Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Euro Banknote

emojiDetailList.description:
Quids in! A banded stack of pound banknotes, the paper currency of the United Kingdom ( England , Wales , Northern Ireland , and Scotland ). Color and detail vary across platforms, but widely depicted as purple £20 notes with the pound sign, £.

Commonly used for various content concerning wealth and money, not restricted to the U.K.

Samsung's design displays £10 notes.

Pound Banknote was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Banknote with Pound Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pound Banknote

emojiDetailList.description:
A moai , one of the famed, giant stone statues of human figures on Easter Island. Depicted as a gray stone carving of a stylized human head with a prominent brow and nose, most often facing left.

Sometimes used for various idiosyncratic purposes, such as conveying a stoic, deadpan, or silly expression.

Its official Unicode name of Moyai and inclusion in early Japanese emoji sets, such as from au by KDDI, suggest the emoji may represent the Moyai Statue near Shibuya Station in Tokyo, Japan; previous designs from Google and Microsoft resemble the Tokyo statue. Other Tokyo landmarks are represented in 🗼 Tokyo Tower and, formerly, Shibuya 109 .

Moai was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Moyai” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Moai

emojiDetailList.description:
A person checking passports at an international border.

Passport Control was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Passport Control

emojiDetailList.description:
A customs officer inspecting luggage . May be shown on signage at airports or other border crossings.

Not to be confused with the passport control emoji .

Customs was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Customs

emojiDetailList.description: Baggage Claim was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baggage Claim

emojiDetailList.description:
An icon representing a place to leave luggage. Most commonly found at Japanese train stations to signify coin lockers where bags can be stored for a daily fee.

This emoji displays a suitcase with a key above or below it, ususually in blue.

Left Luggage was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Left Luggage

emojiDetailList.description:
The back of an envelope , generally shown in white and sealed with a red heart . Represents a love letter or note, valentine , or affectionate greeting card. Commonly used to convey various feelings or messages of love and happiness.

Microsoft’s envelope is open, Facebook’s is pink.

Love Letter was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Love Letter

emojiDetailList.description:
A round, black, cartoon-styled hole, as a manhole or a hole (cup) in golf . May be used to represent various types of literal or figurative holes, e.g., black holes, rabbit holes.

Hole was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hole

emojiDetailList.description:
A cartoon-styled bomb, depicted as a black ball with a burning fuse.

Commonly used for various figurative bombs or explosions, e.g., slang bomb , a “home run” in baseball or softball ; "excellent" or "attractive." Sometimes applied in contexts of war, weapons, or violence.

Earlier designs from SoftBank and au by KDDI animated the bomb as exploding .

Bomb was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bomb

emojiDetailList.description:
A gender-unspecified person taking a soothing bath in a white tub with a shower head. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally. May also represent relaxation and self-care.

The appearance of the person, depicted in default yellow, varies. Apple's person is wearing a green shower cap, WhatsApp's a green washcloth. Google’s person appears to be playing in a bubble bath, with soapsuds atop their ahead. Other major vendors show the head of the bather with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone modifiers are available on supported platforms.

Vendors implement the same or a similar tub and shower head as for their 🛁 Bathtub , but with a person taking/having a bath.

Person Taking Bath was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bath” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Person Taking Bath

emojiDetailList.description:
A bed with a gender-unspecified person sleeping in it, as at a house , hotel , hostel, or other sleeping accommodation. Used especially for various content concerning sleeping as well as beds, furniture, housing, relaxing, and other bedroom activities.

Shown with a headboard at the left and footboard with a person under the covers, head on the pillow. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets.

The appearance of the person varies. Apple and Facebook's designs show only the hair of the sleeper, Apple's black and Facebook's brown and tousled. Other major vendors show the head of the sleeper in default yellow with short, brown or blonde hair. Skin tone support is not recommended for this emoji, though it is supported on some platforms .

Vendors implement the same style of bed as for their 🛏️ Bed , but with a sleeper in it.

Person in Bed was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Sleeping Accommodation” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Person in Bed

emojiDetailList.description:
A knife with a long steel blade, as a chef uses to slice meat or vegetables. Depicted with a black or brown handle and positioned at a 45° angle, often with its point at the lower right.

May be used for content concerning cooking and food preparation, but often represents various senses of cutting and stabbing. Its Unicode name, Hocho , means “kitchen knife” in Japanese and refers to a variety of knives used in Japan .

Not to be confused with 🗡️ Dagger or ⚔️ Crossed Swords .

Kitchen Knife was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hocho” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Kitchen Knife

emojiDetailList.description:
A tall, ceramic jar with two handles and a narrow neck and foot. Represents an amphora , as used by ancient Greeks and Romans to hold water and wine.

Generally depicted as brownish-red earthenware ornamented with black and a Greek meander pattern.

May represent containers like vases, pottery, museums, history, and antiquity. May also be used in relation to the zodiac sign of Aquarius , the Water-Bearer.

Not to be confused with ⚱️ Funeral Urn .

Amphora was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Amphora

emojiDetailList.description:
A rectangular map of the world. Generally depicted as a paper map creased at its folds, Earth’s surface shown in green on blue ocean.

Commonly represent maps, travel, exploration, and geography. May also represent various content concerning the world as a whole, e.g., global or international issues.

Microsoft and Samsung’s design previously depicted outlines of the continents.

World Map was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: World Map

emojiDetailList.description:
A magnetic compass, as used for navigation. Generally depicted in a silver or gold case with a compass rose and a red-tipped needle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling and exploring as well as metaphorical compasses (e.g., moral compass).

Google and Facebook’s markings include the initials of the four cardinal directions, north, south, east, and west. Not to be confused with various clock or timepiece emojis.

Compass was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Compass

emojiDetailList.description:
A red brick or bricks. Depicted in a loose stack, a single object with holes, or as built into wall, as of a house , school , or other structure.

Commonly used for various content concerning building and construction. May also be used for figurative bricks, e.g., slang brick , “extremely cold (weather).”

Brick was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Brick

emojiDetailList.description:
A pole spiraled with red, white, and blue stripes, as spins out front of a barbershop . Commonly used for various content concerning haircutting and hairstyling.

May also be associated with brothels in parts of Asia.

Barber Pole was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Barber Pole

emojiDetailList.description:
A wheelchair without any motor. Distinct from ♿ Wheelchair Symbol which is used as signage to indicate accessible facilities. See also Woman in Manual Wheelchair or Man in Manual Wheelchair .

Manual Wheelchair was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Manual Wheelchair

emojiDetailList.description:
A wheelchair with a motor. Distinct from ♿ Wheelchair Symbol which is used as signage to indicate accessible facilities. See also Woman in Motorized Wheelchair or Man in Motorized Wheelchair .

Motorized Wheelchair was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Motorized Wheelchair

emojiDetailList.description:
A barrel for transporting bulk liquids, such as oil. Generally depicted as a red or blue metal drum with holes or a stopper on its lid. Commonly used for various content concerning petroleum or hazardous waste.

Google’s design displays a yellow oil drop symbol. Samsung's design previously featured a yellow hazard sign.

Oil Drum was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Oil Drum

emojiDetailList.description:
Ding! A call bell, as pressed at a front desk or reception to alert staff for service, such as from a concierge or bellhop (porter) to carry luggage at a hotel . Generally depicted as a golden bell on a wooden stand.

Commonly represents alerts or notifications to bring attention to important content. May also be used of various content concerning the hospitality and service industries.

Microsoft’s design features a silver bell radiating yellow rays, as if ringing.

Bellhop Bell was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bellhop Bell

emojiDetailList.description:
A suitcase or bag, as used for traveling. Most platforms depict gray or blue rolling luggage with an extended handle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling or taking trips, whether for business or leisure.

Apple’s design features an old-fashioned, leather, trunk-styled case with graphic luggage labels /stickers, not to be confused with 💼 Briefcase or 👜 Handbag . Google and Facebook also include such stickers.

May be stored in a 🛅 Coin Locker or inspected at 🛃 Customs .

Luggage was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Luggage

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic hourglass, all of its sand having flowed into the bottom bulb. Indicates time has passed. Color varies across platforms.

Commonly used for various content concerning time. May also be used for hourglass-shaped figures. Not to be confused with ⏳ Hourglass Not Done , whose sand is still flowing.

Used on Snapchat to indicate a Snapstreak is soon to end.

Hourglass Done was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Hourglass” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hourglass Done

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic hourglass, its sand still flowing from the top to bottom bulb. Indicates time is still passing—but life is short. Color varies across platforms.

Commonly used for various content concerning time. May also be used for hourglass-shaped figures. Not to be confused with ⌛ Hourglass Done , whose sand has stopped flowing.

Hourglass Not Done was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hourglass with Flowing Sand” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hourglass Not Done

emojiDetailList.description:
A wristwatch, as used for telling time. Appearance varies across platforms, but widely depicted as an analog timepiece with a white face and brown or black straps.

Used for various content concerning time, including watches as accessories. Apple's design is an Apple Watch, though previously featured a traditional watch before the product’s release.

Watch was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Watch

emojiDetailList.description:
A timepiece set in advance to startle a person awake at the designated time with its two bells. That is, before hitting snooze. Appearance varies across platforms, but depicted as a classic, wind-up, bedside alarm clock, often red in color.

May be used for various content concerning alarms, alerts, sleeping , waking, and time more generally.

Alarm Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Alarm Clock

emojiDetailList.description:
An analog, handheld timepiece used to measure elapsed time, as for athletic sprints. Appearance varies across platforms, but depicted with two or more control buttons on its top.

Used for various content concerning time. Not to be confused with ⏰ Alarm Clock or other clock emojis.

Stopwatch was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Stopwatch

emojiDetailList.description:
Time’s up! A timer set to count down and sound an alarm after a designated amount of time, as used in the kitchen. Appearance varies by platform. Commonly used for various content concerning time, including countdowns and deadlines.

Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s designs resemble kitchen timers. Other designs may be confused with 🕰️ Mantelpiece Clock or other clock emojis.

Timer Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Timer Clock

emojiDetailList.description:
An antique-styled mantel clock with a flat base and rounded case, as made of wood and brass and placed above a fireplace .

Commonly used for various content concerning time. May also suggest a traditional home or old-time environment.

Samsung’s design features a more modern-looking, blue clock.

Mantelpiece Clock was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mantelpiece Clock

emojiDetailList.description:
A liquid-in-glass thermometer, as used to measure temperature. Depicted at various angles with a red liquid risen from the bulb to various levels on the scale. Commonly used for content concerning high temperatures, including warm weather , illness ( having a fever ), and various slang senses of hot .

Thermometer was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Thermometer

emojiDetailList.description:
A large, open umbrella, as provides shade at a beach or patio. Generally depicted as a striped umbrella inserted into a patch of sand and tilted to the right.

Commonly used for various content concerning the beach, summer vacations (holidays), sunny weather, and relaxing outdoors.

The color of the stripes varies across platforms; Apple (no sand) and Samsung’s are red and yellow, Twitter and Facebook’s red and white, Google’s blue and white, and WhatsApp’s rainbow -colored.

Not to be confused with other umbrella-related emoji , such as 🏖️ Beach With Umbrella , though their applications may overlap.

Umbrella on Ground was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Umbrella on Ground

emojiDetailList.description:
A firecracker, as lit on Chinese New Year , New Year's Eve , or Independence Day . Depicted as a red tube with a burning fuse, sometimes lined with gold rings at its top and base.

Often used with 🎆 Fireworks and 🎇 Sparkler for various celebrations and holidays. Also applied to figurative senses of fire , e.g., slang hot , on fire (“excellent”).

While it may resemble a stick of dynamite on some platforms, several vendor designs, such as Google and Twitter's, suggest the emoji is modeled after traditional Chinese firecrackers, as are strung together and lit on such occasions as Chinese New Year .

Firecracker was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Firecracker

emojiDetailList.description:
A balloon on a string, as decorates a birthday party. Generally depicted in red, though WhatsApp’s is pink and Google’s orangish-red.

Commonly used to convey congratulations and celebration, especially when wishing someone a happy birthday.

Microsoft and Samsung's balloons were previously blue; SoftBank's was shown floating in the sky.

Balloon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Balloon

emojiDetailList.description:
