Samsung’s design depicts a metal can/bin with a lid, as used for outdoor garbage—or lived in by Oscar the Grouch . Not to be confused with 🧺 Basket .

Wastebasket was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wastebasket

emojiDetailList.description:
A locked (closed) padlock , as used to secure a latch or chain , or as an icon for a secure internet connection , private account, or locked device. Generally depicted with a gold base and silver shackle. WhatsApp’s design is silver.

Commonly used for content concerning safety, security, privacy, and protection as well as various senses of lock , e.g., locked in / down .

This emoji does not display in page titles on Apple’s Safari web browser, presumably to prevent less reputable sites from pretending to be secure (encrypted using HTTPS ).

See also: 🔏 Locked With Pen and 🔐 Locked With Key .

Locked was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Lock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Locked

emojiDetailList.description:
An unlocked padlock , as used to secure a latch or chain, or as an icon for a non-secure connection or open access online. Generally depicted with a gold base and silver shackle, as an open 🔒 Locked .

May be used to represent a lack of or concerns about privacy and security. May also be used for figurative senses of unlocking, e.g., achievement unlocked .

WhatsApp’s design is silver, its shackle turned to the right, as Samsung’s previously was .

This emoji does not display in page titles on Apple’s Safari web browser, presumably to prevent less reputable sites from pretending to be secure (encrypted using HTTPS ).

Unlocked was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Open Lock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Unlocked

emojiDetailList.description:
A locked (closed) padlock with a fountain pen or nib positioned at various angles in front of it. Vendors implement the same design as their 🔒 Locked and the same or similar design as their 🖋️ Fountain Pen or ✒️ Black Nib .

May represent digital certificates in public-key technology . May also have similar applications as 🔒 Locked (privacy, security) and 🖋️ Fountain Pen or ✒️ Black Nib (writing, signing).

Apple’s design previously displayed a nib, Google’s a full pen.

This emoji does not display in page titles on Apple’s Safari web browser, presumably to prevent less reputable sites from pretending to be secure (encrypted using HTTPS ).

Locked with Pen was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Lock with Ink Pen” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Locked with Pen

emojiDetailList.description:
A locked (closed) padlock with an upright key at its right. Vendors implement the same designs as their 🔒 Locked and 🔑 Key .

May represent digital keys in public-key technology . May have similar applications as 🔒 Locked (privacy, security) and 🔑 Key (means of access, "crucial"). Sometimes used to represent a locket to symbolize romantic love and commitment.

Apple’s design previously featured the easter egg UM242 on its key, a reference to locks on Herman Miller office furniture . Facebook’s design once displayed a silver key, its head at the bottom.

This emoji does not display in page titles on Apple’s Safari web browser, presumably to prevent less reputable sites from pretending to be secure (encrypted using HTTPS ).

Locked with Key was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Closed Lock with Key” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Locked with Key

emojiDetailList.description:
A key, as opens a door or lock . Depicted at a 45° angle as a gold, bronze, or copper key with a round head and notched blade. Commonly used for figurative senses of key , e.g., the key to success , being key ("crucial").

DJ Khaled uses the emoji to indicate his Snapchat stories are official (verified). Apple’s design previously resembled a gold 🗝️ Old Key , which emoji has similar applications.

May also represent digital keys in public-key technology . This may explain why the emoji does not display in page titles on Apple’s Safari web browser, presumably to prevent less reputable sites from pretending to be secure (encrypted using HTTPS ).

Key was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Key

emojiDetailList.description:
An old-fashioned key, as opens an antique chest or wardrobe. Generally depicted at a 45° angle as a tarnished, silver skeleton key with an ornate, bowed head and two-toothed bit at the bottom left.

Like 🔑 Key , often used figuratively, e.g., the key to success , being key ("crucial"). May also be applied to antiques.

Microsoft’s design is gold, with the head at the upper left. Samsung and Facebook’s keys were previously gold.

Old Key was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Old Key

emojiDetailList.description:
A claw hammer, as used for driving or removing nails. Generally depicted with a metal head and wooden handle, positioned at a 45° angle with the head at the upper left.

Commonly used for content concerning tools, building, and construction as well as various senses of breaking or smashing. May also represent hard work or be applied to hammer-related expressions, e.g., nailed it .

Apple and Facebook’s designs previously displayed a gavel, Softbank’s a mallet. Not to be confused with ⛏️ Pick or Axe .

Hammer was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hammer

emojiDetailList.description:
Axe was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Axe

emojiDetailList.description:
A pickaxe, a tool with a curved spike for breaking up rocks in mining. Generally depicted with a metal head and wooden handle, positioned at a 45° angle with the head at the upper left.

May be used for various content concerning building, construction, digging, mining, or rock climbing. Not to be confused with 🔨 Hammer or Axe .

Pick was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pick

emojiDetailList.description:
A hammer and pick, as used for breaking up rocks in mining, crossed in an X shape. Generally depicted as metal, mallet- and chisel-styled hammers with wooden handles. The heads of the tools face up, with the pick usually at the right. Often used for various content concerning tools, building, and construction.

Facebook implements the same designs as for its 🔨 Hammer and ⛏️ Pick . Samsung’s design previously featured stylized, white tools on a green square, as a sign or icon of a mine.

Hammer and Pick was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hammer and Pick

emojiDetailList.description:
A hammer and wrench, as kept in a toolbox , crossed in an X shape. Depicted with metal tools facing up, the hammer positioned at the upper left. Most vendors implement the same design as for their 🔨 Hammer and 🔧 Wrench .

Commonly used for various content concerning tools, building, construction, and work, both manual and digital.

Hammer and Wrench was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hammer and Wrench

emojiDetailList.description:
A pointed knife with a steel blade, as used for thrusting in close combat. Generally depicted as double-edged with a brown or black, cross-shaped hilt and positioned at 45° angle, often with its tip at the lower left.

May represent knives and other bladed weapons (cf. ⚔️ Crossed Swords ) as well as various senses of cutting and stabbing. Often applied to medieval or fantasy content.

Microsoft’s design features a golden handle. Google’s design, featuring an icy-blue blade and sparkles , suggests a dagger elves may wield in fantasy.

May be paired with (or defended by) 🛡️ Shield . Not to be confused with 🔪 Kitchen Knife .

Dagger was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Dagger Knife” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dagger

emojiDetailList.description:
Two swords with steel blades in an X shape, as crossed for combat between two knights or warriors. Generally depicted as straight, double-edged blades with brown or black, cross-shaped hilts, points directed up. Commonly used as a symbol for battle, fighting, or a contest, as in sports.

Sometimes shown with golden handles. Several vendors implement the same design as for their 🗡️ Dagger . Samsung’s design previously featured stylized, white swords on a green square, as a sign or icon of war.

May be paired with (or defended by) 🛡️ Shield . Not to be confused with ⚒️ Hammer and Pick or 🛠️ Hammer and Wrench .

Crossed Swords was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Crossed Swords

emojiDetailList.description:
A squirt gun (water pistol), as used to spray water for fun.

On major platforms, depicted as a green or orange toy gun with an orange tip and barrel pointed left. Google, Microsoft, and Facebook’s designs include mounted reservoirs.

Originally depicted as a classic handgun, as a revolver or other pistol. In 2016, Apple switched its design from weapon to toy; other major vendors followed suit by 2018. Deprecated emoji sets or smaller platforms still display the emoji as a handgun.

Microsoft initially displayed the emoji as a toy ray gun before switching to a revolver, then squirt gun. Google once featured a blunderbuss .

Pistol was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.

🚩 Appearance differs greatly cross-platform. Use with caution.
emojiDetailList.title: Pistol

emojiDetailList.description:
A shield, as blocks swords in close combat. Color and style varies across platforms, but generally depicted in a kite shape with a metal border and simple pattern.

Commonly used to represent various content concerning battle, defense, security, and protection.

Apple and Microsoft’s designs feature a red and white sawtooth pattern, Facebook and WhatsApp’s blue and white checkers.

May be paired with (or fending off) ⚔️ Crossed Swords or 🗡️ Dagger . Not to be confused with 🔰 Japanese Symbol for Beginner .

Shield was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shield

emojiDetailList.description:
Carpentry Saw was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Carpentry Saw

emojiDetailList.description:
A metal wrench (spanner), as used for turning nuts and bolts . Depicted with two open, crescent-shaped ends or one open end and a closed, ring-shaped end. Generally positioned at a 45° angle.

Commonly used for various content concerning tools, building, maintenance, and skilled trades like car mechanics and plumbing.

Wrench was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wrench

emojiDetailList.description:
Screwdriver was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Screwdriver

emojiDetailList.description:
A metal bolt with a nut threaded around it, as by a wrench . Often positioned at a 45° angle, the head of the bolt at the upper left. Commonly used for various content concerning tools, building, and construction. May also be used for other hardware, including screws.

Apple’s bolt previously resembled a screw, Google’s a dumbbell; Microsoft’s design previously featured the nut and bolt separately.

Nut and Bolt was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Nut and Bolt

emojiDetailList.description:
A toothed, wheel-shaped metal gear, as rotates to power machines.

Commonly used for content concerning tools, equipment, and technology in a range of contexts, such as engineering, motor vehicles, and video games. May also represent hard work, e.g., grinding in sports.

Samsung’s design features a stylized, white gear on a green square, as a sign or icon of machinery.

Gear was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Gear

emojiDetailList.description:
A metal clamp or vice, as screwed to hold or compress materials like wood or metal. Depicted as a C-clamp or F-clamp , its screw in various positions.

Commonly used for various content concerning tools, equipment, and technology. May also represent file compression in computer science. An image of a clamp, for example, is featured in the WinZip icon.

Twitter’s clamp is red. Samsung’s design previously featured a clamp around a cardboard box.

Clamp was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Compression” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Clamp

emojiDetailList.description:
A balance scale, as historically used to measure weight. A symbol of justice, as held by Lady Justice , and of the zodiac sign of Libra , the Scales. Depicted as two silver or gold pans suspended from a beam and supported on a base.

Commonly used for various content concerning law and justice as well as various senses of balance and weight.

Samsung’s design previously featured a stylized, white balance scale on a green square, as an icon or symbol of legal matters or institutions.

Balance Scale was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Scales” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Balance Scale

emojiDetailList.description:
A probing cane, used by some people who are blind or visually impaired. Differs from a support cane , and is sometimes referred to as a white cane . See also 👩‍🦯 Woman With Probing Cane and 👨‍🦯 Man With Probing Cane .

White Cane was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 under the name “Probing Cane” and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: White Cane

emojiDetailList.description:
Two links of a silver chain , positioned at a 45° angle. Used as an icon for a hyperlink on computers and the internet. May also be used for metaphorical connections.

Not to be confused with ⛓️Chains , 📎 Paperclip , 🖇️ Linked Paperclips , or 🧷 Safety Pin .

Link was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Link Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Link

emojiDetailList.description:
Two parallel lengths of silver chain. Occasionally used as an icon before a hyperlink or for metaphorical connections or chains, e.g., slang off the chains .

Samsung’s design previously featured stylized, white chains in a blue square, as a sign or icon for snow chains for winter driving.

Not to be confused with 🔗 Link , 📎 Paperclip , 🖇️ Linked Paperclips , or 🧷 Safety Pin .

Chains was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Chains

emojiDetailList.description:
Hook was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Hook

emojiDetailList.description:
A red box for holding and transporting tools, such as a hammer and wrench . Generally depicted as latched shut with silver hardware and a black handle.

Commonly used for literal or metaphorical tools, toolkits, and building.

Google’s design is shown open with two wrenches and a pair of pliers; WhatsApp includes a hammer in front.

Toolbox was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Toolbox

emojiDetailList.description:
A horseshoe magnet, as used to pick up iron. Depicted at various angles in red with silver-tipped poles.

Commonly used for various content concerning literal and figurative magnetism and attraction. May also be used in various science-related contexts more generally.

Twitter’s design features two electric bolts coming from its poles. WhatsApp’s horseshoe is half blue, denoting an opposite magnetic pole.

Magnet was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Magnet

emojiDetailList.description:
Ladder was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Ladder

emojiDetailList.description:
An apparatus for distilling, as used in medieval alchemy . Generally depicted as a round flask with a neck angled down to the right. Positioned on a short stand and containing a mysterious green, purple, or blue liquid.

Commonly used for various content concerning chemistry and science more generally. May represent various liquids, such as potions or medicines, as well as metaphorical laboratories and experiments.

Thanks to the alembic’s association with alchemy, this emoji may also convey a sense of magic. And, thanks to its resemblance to a glass pipe, some use the emoji to represent a bong or other drug paraphernalia.

Samsung’s design previously featured a copper still, as used for making whiskey .

Alembic was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Alembic

emojiDetailList.description:
A test tube, as used to conduct chemical experiments in a laboratory. Depicted as a clear cylinder, open at one end and containing a green liquid. Positioned at a 45° angle.

May be used for various content concerning chemistry and science more generally. May also represent other liquids, such as potions or medicines, as well metaphorical laboratories and experiments.

Some platforms include volume markings or display the liquid as bubbling. WhatsApp’s design features a blue liquid.

Test Tube was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Test Tube

emojiDetailList.description:
A petri dish, as used to culture microbes . Depicted as a clear, shallow cylinder with a red, blue, or green growth medium, such as agar , with splotches of variously colored cells, like bacteria.

May be used for various content concerning biology and science more generally. May also be used to represent germs and other microorganisms.

Google’s design features a dropper, Samsung’s a lid.

Petri Dish was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Petri Dish

emojiDetailList.description:
The double helix of DNA , the genetic blueprint for life. Color and orientation vary across platforms, but positioned at a 45° angle and in multiple, bright colors to represent the molecule’s spiraling, ladder-like structure.

May be used for various content concerning biology, genetics, and science more generally. May also be used for various content concerning literal or figurative life and evolution.

DNA was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “DNA Double Helix” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: DNA

emojiDetailList.description:
A microscope, as used in science laboratories to magnify small objects, such as cells or insects . Depicted as a compound opitical microscope with an adjustable eyepiece, lens, arm, and slide stage mounted on a base. Generally shown as metal with the viewing apparatus facing left.

Commonly used for various content concerning science and research. May also be used for various senses of inspection (e.g., taking a closer took).

Google’s design is shown in red.

Microscope was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Microscope

emojiDetailList.description:
A telescope, as used to gaze at stars and planets in the night sky. Shown with an optical tube mounted on a tripod, positioned at various angles and generally depicted as metal.

Commonly used for various content concerning astronomy, outer space, celestial objects, and science more generally. May also be used for various concepts of sight (e.g., spying, viewing).

Google and Twitter’s designs feature red hardware.

Telescope was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Telescope

emojiDetailList.description:
A dish antenna, as used to send or receive information to or from a communication satellite —or 👽 Extraterrestrial Life . Generally depicted as a mounted, metal dish with its antenna positioned at 45° to the upper right.

Commonly used to represent satellite television , radio , and internet, as well as broadcasting, streaming, cellular, and wireless services or technologies. May also represent various concepts of signals and transmission.

Several platforms, including Samsung and Twitter, feature curved, radiating lines, as if transmitting data. Google’s design is depicted in blue.

Satellite Antenna was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Satellite Antenna

emojiDetailList.description:
A medical syringe, as used to administer a shot or draw blood . Generally depicted at a 45° angle with a needle to the upper right, emitting two droplets of the red fluid in its barrel, as blood drawn for testing or donation at a hospital .

Commonly used for content concerning health, medicine, and related professions as well as various senses of needles, drugs, and blood.

Google and Facebook’s designs previously featured green liquids, Samsung’s syringe was empty.

Syringe was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Syringe

emojiDetailList.description:
A drop of blood shown in red. May be used to signify a blood donation, bleeding, injury or menstruation.

Drop of Blood was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Drop of Blood

emojiDetailList.description:
A capsule of medicine. Generally depicted at a 45° angle, half red, half yellow. Commonly used for content concerning health, medicine, and related professions as well various types of drugs.

Samsung’s design previously featured a blue-and-white capsule with two round pills, one orange, the other white. Google and Microsoft’s designs previously featured blue in their capsules.

Pill was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pill

emojiDetailList.description:
Adhesive Bandage was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Adhesive Bandage

emojiDetailList.description:
Stethoscope was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Stethoscope

emojiDetailList.description:
A door, as to the entrance of a room, house , or new opportunity. (We’ll see ourselves out 🚪🚶.) Depicted in brown, as made of wood, with a gold handle.

May represent literal doors and related concepts (e.g., rooms, houses) but often used figuratively (e.g., opening or closing metaphorical doors).

Google’s design features a peephole and Microsoft’s a step, as if a front door.

Door was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Door

emojiDetailList.description:
A bed, made up for sleeping in a house , hotel , or other sleeping accommodation . Shown with a headboard at the left, footboard, mattress, pillow, and sheet. Most platforms suggest a wooden frame and feature blue or red sheets.

Commonly used for various content concerning beds, furniture, and housing as well as sleeping , relaxing, and other bedroom activities.

Vendors implement the same style of bed for 🛌 Person in Bed , but without a sleeper under the covers.

Bed was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bed

emojiDetailList.description:
A couch (sofa) with a floor lamp on the right, as in the living room of a house . Color and style of the couch and lamp vary widely by platform. Used for various content concerning furniture and housing as well as resting and lounging.

Couch and Lamp was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Couch and Lamp

emojiDetailList.description:
A chair for sitting at a table, or in a standalone location. Materials may vary, with wood a common choice.

Distinct from the seat emoji , which is generally fixed, as opposed to a chair which can be moved.

Chair was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Chair

emojiDetailList.description:
A white toilet, as used to deposit a 💩 Pile of Poo . (Don’t forget the 🧻 Roll of Paper . ) Most platforms depict a porcelain toilet in profile, bowl facing to the left.

Commonly used for various content concerning going to the bathroom or bathrooms more generally. May also be used figuratively, e.g., down the toilet .

Google, Microsoft, and Twitter’s designs left the seat up.

Toilet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Toilet

emojiDetailList.description:
Plunger was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Plunger

emojiDetailList.description:
A silver shower head, streaming water to the left. Pressure level varies across platforms. 🧼 Soap not provided.

Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and water. Shower heads are also featured in 🛁 Bathtub and 🛀 Person Taking a Bath .

Shower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shower

emojiDetailList.description:
A white bathtub with a silver shower head. Often depicted as a cast-iron tub with claw-foot legs. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, cleaning, and bathrooms more generally.

Several platforms, including Apple and Facebook, feature soap bubbles or suds. Samsung’s design displays streaming water from the shower head.

Vendors implement 🛀 Person Taking a Bath with the same or a similar emoji, but with a person soaking in the tub.

Bathtub was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bathtub

emojiDetailList.description:
Mouse Trap was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Mouse Trap

emojiDetailList.description:
A razor which may be displayed as a razor blade or a safety razor.

Razor was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Razor

emojiDetailList.description:
A bottle of lotion for the skin, such as moisturizer or sunscreen (sunblock). May be used for other hygienic liquids, including shampoo and body wash , as well as beauty products.

Appearance varies across platforms, but commonly depicted in white and gold colors. Some platforms, like Apple and Twitter, feature a bottle with a pump while others show a cylinder with a cap.

Lotion Bottle was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Lotion Bottle

emojiDetailList.description:
A silver safety pin or clip, as used to fasten fabric. Generally shown clasped at a 45° angle, with its spring at the lower left.

May be used for various content concerning arts, crafts, and sewing. Not to be confused with 📎 Paperclip .

Safety Pin was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Safety Pin

emojiDetailList.description:
A traditional broom, as used for sweeping—or ridden by a witch . Shown at a 45° angle, with a wooden handle and yellow bristles at the lower left.

Commonly used for various content concerning cleaning, brushing, and figurative sweeps (e.g., in sports or awards). Not to be confused with 🖌️ Paintbrush .

Broom was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Broom

emojiDetailList.description:
A basket, as used for storing or carrying such things as food or clothes. Appearance widely varies across platforms but generally depicted as woven from wicker with one or more handles. Commonly used to represent doing laundry or having a picnic.

Microsoft’s design suggests a laundry basket holding a blue garment or cloth. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs, featuring a white cloth, suggest a bread or picnic basket. Samsung’s design displays green fabric, as knitted from yarn .

Not to be confused with 🗑️ Wastebasket .

Basket was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Basket

emojiDetailList.description:
A roll of paper, as toilet paper (toilet tissue). May also be a roll of kitchen/paper towels. Depicted at various angles, with a sheet unfurling.

Commonly used for toilet paper but may also be used for various content concerning toilets , going to the bathroom, bathrooms, cleaning, or paper more generally.

Roll of Paper was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Roll of Paper

emojiDetailList.description:
Bucket was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Bucket

emojiDetailList.description:
A bar of soap, as used in the shower , bath or for hand washing. Generally shown with lathered bubbles. Depicted in various colors, often pink, and at different angles.

Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. May be used to represent the opposite of dirt or being dirty. Recommended for use to prevent the spread of COVID-19 .

Soap was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 under the name “Bar of Soap” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Soap

emojiDetailList.description:
Toothbrush was approved as part of Unicode 13.0 in 2020 and added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Toothbrush

emojiDetailList.description:
A peanut -shaped sponge, as used for cleaning or bathing. Generally depicted in yellow and at different angles across platforms. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning.

Sponge was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Sponge

emojiDetailList.description:
A fire extinguisher, as used to put out small fires . Depicted as a red tank with a black hose and pressure gauge. Most platforms include an image of a flame on a white label.

Commonly used for various content concerning fire safety, emergencies, and literal and figurative fires.

Fire Extinguisher was approved as part of Unicode 11.0 in 2018 and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Fire Extinguisher

emojiDetailList.description: Shopping Cart was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Shopping Trolley” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Shopping Cart

emojiDetailList.description:
A lit, filtered cigarette, shown burning at different directions. Commonly used to represent various forms of smoking (e.g., tobacco, marijuana, vaping) as well as metaphorical senses of smoking.

Originally intended as a sign for a designated smoking area, as contrasted to 🚭 No Smoking Symbol . This is illustrated in Samsung’s previous design of a stylized, white cigarette on a blue background.

Cigarette was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Smoking Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cigarette

emojiDetailList.description:
A traditional coffin, as used to bury the dead. Depicted at various angles as a closed, six-sided, wooden coffin, tapered at the head and foot with golden handles.

Commonly used for various content concerning literal and figurative death. May also be used for various content concerning funerals, horror, and Halloween .

Apple and Microsoft’s designs place flowers on their lids.

Coffin was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Coffin

emojiDetailList.description:
An urn, as used to hold the cremated ashes of the dead. Appearance varies, but generally depicted as a covered, bronze container with a rounded body and tapered foot.

May be used for various content concerning death and funerals. May also be used for other types of vessels, such as pots or vases.

Not to be confused with 🏺 Amphora .

Funeral Urn was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Funeral Urn

emojiDetailList.description:
A moai , one of the famed, giant stone statues of human figures on Easter Island. Depicted as a gray stone carving of a stylized human head with a prominent brow and nose, most often facing left.

Sometimes used for various idiosyncratic purposes, such as conveying a stoic, deadpan, or silly expression.

Its official Unicode name of Moyai and inclusion in early Japanese emoji sets, such as from au by KDDI, suggest the emoji may represent the Moyai Statue near Shibuya Station in Tokyo, Japan; previous designs from Google and Microsoft resemble the Tokyo statue. Other Tokyo landmarks are represented in 🗼 Tokyo Tower and, formerly, Shibuya 109 .

Moai was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Moyai” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Moai

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol for potable (drinkable) water, usually shown with a faucet filling a drinking glass. Commonly used for various content concerning water, drinking, thirst, and dripping.

Some platforms, including Apple and WhatsApp, depict the emoji as an object while others feature a stylized, white faucet on a blue square, as a sign or icon of water that is safe to drink. Compare 🚱 Non-Potable Water , which indicates water that is not safe to drink.

Apple's design previously featured a blue symbol design, Microsoft's a cup filled with water.

Potable Water was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Potable Water Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Potable Water

emojiDetailList.description:
A heart emoji with an arrow through the center, like the arrow that cupid shoots for love.

Heart with Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heart with Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
A heart-shaped box, tied with a ribbon . May be a gift box, box of chocolates, or a jewellery box.

Heart with Ribbon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heart with Ribbon

emojiDetailList.description:
A pink love heart with stars around it, making it look like it is sparkling or shimmering.

Sparkling Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sparkling Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A pink heart, inside a slightly larger pink heart, inside a larger-again pink heart. Intended to give the impression of a heart increasing in size.

Growing Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Growing Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A heart with vibration / movement lines above it, indicating it is a beating heart. Displayed in pink or red on most platforms, this emoji is intended to be used as a beating heart representing either life, or love.

Beating Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Beating Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
Hearts revolving around one or more other hearts. This emoji was originally animated on a number of Japanese devices.

Apple’s artwork for this emoji shows two hearts switching places, with a circular line simulating the action this would make. Google’s artwork previously displayed five hearts in a circle-like shape .

Revolving Hearts was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Revolving Hearts

emojiDetailList.description:
Two pink love hearts. One larger than the other. Can be used to display that “love is in the air”.

On Snapchat , this emoji next to a contact denotes that you have been #1 BFs with each other for two consecutive months. A bug in October 2019 has a yellow heart emoji showing instead of 💕 for some Snapchat users .

Two Hearts was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Two Hearts

emojiDetailList.description:
A decorative heart that displays on Apple devices as a white heart-shaped cutout in a pink or purple roundrect.

Heart Decoration was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heart Decoration

emojiDetailList.applenames: Red Heart As an Exclamation Mark
emojiDetailList.description:
A decorative exclamation mark , where a heart forms the top part of the symbol, and a circle the lower part. Similar to the way to the man in business suit levitating also creates a similar shape.

Heart Exclamation was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Heart Exclamation Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heart Exclamation

emojiDetailList.description:
A love heart, broken in two. This emoji represents the aching one feels when they are missing the  person they love.

Broken Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Broken Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A classic love heart emoji, used for expressions of love. Displayed in various shades of red on most platforms. A similar emoji exists for the heart suit in a deck of playing cards.

On Snapchat , this emoji displays next to a friend when you have been #1 BFs with each other for two consecutive weeks.

Note: the Unicode character name “Heavy Black Heart” pre-dates color emoji, when the term referred to a solid, black ❤︎ heart character. See the glossary for information on the term black in Unicode character names.

Red Heart was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Black Heart” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Red Heart

emojiDetailList.description: Orange Heart was approved as part of Unicode 10.0 in 2017 and added to Emoji 5.0 in 2017.
emojiDetailList.title: Orange Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow or gold colored love-heart. Inexplicably, this displayed as a pink hairy heart on Android 4.4.

On Snapchat , this emoji next to a contact denotes a person that you snap the most, and who also snaps you the most ( #1 best friend ). The yellow #1 BF heart turns into a red heart after two weeks. A bug in October 2019 has this yellow heart emoji showing instead of 💕 for some Snapchat users .

Yellow Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Yellow Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A green heart emoji.

The Android 4.4 artwork for this emoji appeared to show beads of sweat on an orange and pink heart.

Green Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Green Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A blue heart emoji.

Blue Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Blue Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A purple heart emoji. Shown as pink in Android 4.4.

Purple Heart was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Purple Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
Brown Heart was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: Brown Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A heart shaded completely black. May be used to express morbidity, sorrow, or a form of dark humor.

Not to be confused with the Heavy Black Heart or Black Heart Suit which are both red .

Black Heart was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Black Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
A white heart emoji to accompany other hearts such as ❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🖤 approved as part of Emoji 12.0 in 2019, and now available on major platforms.

A character known as White Heart Suit is sometimes used in its place, but this is not intended to have an emoji appearance.

White Heart was approved as part of Unicode 12.0 in 2019 and added to Emoji 12.0 in 2019.

🚩 New in 2019. Now supported on all updated systems.
emojiDetailList.title: White Heart

emojiDetailList.description:
100 emoji: the number one-hundred, written in red, underlined twice for emphasis.

Originating from the number 100 written on a school exam or paper to indicate a perfect score of 100 out of 100.  Teachers in Japan may also use a stamp in addition to the 100 mark, to indicate that a student has performed very well.

This 100 emoji is commonly used as a shorthand for 100% , with the usage meaning “keep it real” or a similar sentiment. A 100 emoji can be used to express pride or general acceptance of an idea.

In Snapchat , the 100 emoji appearing next to a fire emoji indicates a 100 day Snapstreak.

Hundred Points was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Hundred Points Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hundred Points

emojiDetailList.description:
A red symbol found in Anime/Manga and used to represent the veins popping on a very angry person.

Also used in other comic books to indicate a punch landed, perhaps next to the words “Bam” or “Pow”.

Anger Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Anger Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A cartoon-style balloon used to represent spoken word in comics. Sometimes  used in communication apps to indicate that another person is typing a message.

Speech Balloon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speech Balloon

emojiDetailList.description:
A speech bubble showing an eye inside. When using text-to-speech on Apple platforms, this emoji is read aloud as: "Eye in speech bubble representing anti-bullying campaign". This emoji was released in conjunction with the Ad Council for the I Am A Witness campaign.

The Eye in Speech Bubble emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 👁 Eye , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🗨 Left Speech Bubble . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Eye in Speech Bubble was added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eye in Speech Bubble

emojiDetailList.description:
A left-facing speech bubble, which was included in Unicode 7.0, but not considered a standard addition for the purposes of emoji presentation.

Left Speech Bubble was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 2.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Left Speech Bubble

emojiDetailList.description:
A form of speech balloon used with angular edges, used to denote angry speech in comics.

Right Anger Bubble was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Right Anger Bubble

emojiDetailList.description:
A large cloud-like shape more commonly known as a thought bubble.

Used to represent thinking, or thoughts, and commonly used in comics to display the thoughts of a drawn character. May also be used to represent a dream, or daydream.

Thought Balloon was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Thought Balloon

emojiDetailList.description:
A series of three Zs making a Zzz. Represents sleeping, snoring, dreaming, or any sleep-related state. Can also be used in some contexts to represent something that is boring.

Zzz was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Sleeping Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Zzz

emojiDetailList.description:
A stylized white flower. Generally depicted as a rosette -shaped cherry blossom in pink or red outline, often with a white fill.

Apple, WhatsApp, and Facebook's designs feature Japanese characters roughly translating to very well done , used by teachers as a stamp for students who did exceptional work, often accompanied by a score in red .

Commonly used for Valentine’s Day , Mother’s Day , and other special occasions. May be more generally used to express such ideas as love, happiness, and beauty. Also used as a pink, white, or red accent color.

Not to be confused with 🌸 Cherry Blossom and 🌺 Hibiscus , though their applications may overlap.

Apple's flower previously featured a red-outlined design, Google's an orange outline. Microsoft's flower was previously black and white, Samsung and Facebook's pink and white.

White Flower was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: White Flower

emojiDetailList.description:
Representation of hot springs with steam rising from a circular tub. This is the common symbol used to represent an onsen on maps in Japan .

Hot Springs was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hot Springs

emojiDetailList.description:
A pole spiraled with red, white, and blue stripes, as spins out front of a barbershop . Commonly used for various content concerning haircutting and hairstyling.

May also be associated with brothels in parts of Asia.

Barber Pole was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Barber Pole

emojiDetailList.description:
A red, octagonal sign. Used in many countries as a stop sign.

Stop Sign was approved as part of Unicode 9.0 in 2016 under the name “Octagonal Sign” and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Stop Sign

emojiDetailList.description: Twelve O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Twelve O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Twelve O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Twelve-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Twelve-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Twelve-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: One O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face One O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: One O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: One-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face One-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: One-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Two O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Two O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Two O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Two-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Two-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Two-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Three O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Three O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Three O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Three-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Three-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Three-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Four O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Four O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Four O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Four-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Four-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Four-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Five O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Five O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Five O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Five-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Five-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Five-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Six O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Six O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Six O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Six-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Six-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Six-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Seven O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Seven O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Seven O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Seven-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Seven-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Seven-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Eight O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Eight O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eight O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Eight-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Eight-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eight-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Nine O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Nine O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Nine O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Nine-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Nine-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Nine-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Ten O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Ten O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ten O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Ten-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Ten-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ten-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description: Eleven O’Clock was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Eleven O’Clock” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eleven O’Clock

emojiDetailList.description: Eleven-Thirty was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clock Face Eleven-Thirty” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eleven-Thirty

emojiDetailList.description:
An icon used to represent a cyclone . Some versions of this emoji show a spiral shape, which may be used for decorative purposes.

Cyclone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cyclone

emojiDetailList.description:
A spade symbol emoji, which is used in card games for the spades suit.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Spade Suit was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Spade Suit” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Spade Suit

emojiDetailList.description:
A heart symbol emoji, which is used in card games for the hearts suit. Generally shown in red, despite the name. Not to be confused with the black heart emoji .

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Heart Suit was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Heart Suit” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heart Suit

emojiDetailList.description:
A diamond symbol emoji, which is used in card games for the diamonds suit.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Diamond Suit was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Diamond Suit” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Diamond Suit

emojiDetailList.description:
A club symbol emoji, which is used in card games for the clubs suit.

Club Suit was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Club Suit” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Club Suit

emojiDetailList.description:
The joker in a deck of cards, usually appearing like a court jester .

Joker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Playing Card Black Joker” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Joker

emojiDetailList.description:
The red dragon tile in the game of Japanese Mahjong . White, with red 中 character printed on it.

Mahjong Red Dragon was approved as part of Unicode 5.1 in 2008 under the name “Mahjong Tile Red Dragon” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mahjong Red Dragon

emojiDetailList.description:
A type of cards known as hanafuda cards in Japan which are used for a range of different games that require associating pictures (there are no numbers on the cards).

The artwork for this emoji shows the Full Moon with Red Sky card, but could theoretically display any of the available cards .

Flower Playing Cards was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Flower Playing Cards

emojiDetailList.description:
A speaker with a red line through it, indicating muted volume or silencing of audio.

Muted Speaker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Speaker with Cancellation Stroke” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Muted Speaker

emojiDetailList.description:
A speaker cone displayed without any sound waves.

Speaker Low Volume was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Speaker” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speaker Low Volume

emojiDetailList.description:
A speaker cone displayed with one sound wave, generally used as an icon to indicate the decreasing of volume on a phone or computer.

Previously displayed with two sound waves on Android, instead of one.

Speaker Medium Volume was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Speaker with One Sound Wave” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speaker Medium Volume

emojiDetailList.description:
A speaker cone displayed with three sound waves, generally used as an icon to indicate the increasing of volume on a phone or computer.

Speaker High Volume was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Speaker with Three Sound Waves” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Speaker High Volume

emojiDetailList.description:
A loudspeaker used to make announcements in public areas such as schools, or sporting grounds.

Loudspeaker was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Public Address Loudspeaker” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Loudspeaker

emojiDetailList.description: Megaphone was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Cheering Megaphone” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Megaphone

emojiDetailList.description:
A postal horn (post horn). Depicted as a coiled, valveless, brass horn, like a bugle or trumpet , with two red tassels. Sometimes used to mark announcements as well as for various content concerning brass instruments, music, or mail.

In the 18–19th centuries, post horns signaled the arrival of and cleared the way for mail coaches, like a modern-day siren . Used today as a symbol on postboxes (mailboxes) and by many European postal services, as seen featured in 🏤 European Post Office .

Postal Horn was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Postal Horn

emojiDetailList.description:
A gold or yellow bell, which is commonly used on mobile phones as an icon for notifications or ringing sounds.

Bell was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bell

emojiDetailList.description:
A gold or yellow bell with a red line through it, which is commonly used on mobile phones as an icon for the silencing of notifications or ringing sounds. A mute, or silent mode .

Bell with Slash was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Bell with Cancellation Stroke” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bell with Slash

emojiDetailList.description:
A music note emoji, which can denote song lyrics, or other music related topics.

Displays as two eighth-notes ( quavers in British English) connected with a beam in the Apple artwork. A single eight-note ( quaver ) is used in Microsoft and Google’s emoji font.

Musical Note was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Musical Note

emojiDetailList.description:
Three eighth notes ( quavers in British English), used to represent music or singing. Sometimes inserted next to quoted lyrics, to make it clear that they are part of a song.

Musical Notes was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Multiple Musical Notes” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Musical Notes

emojiDetailList.applenames: Chart with Upwards Trend and Yen Sign
emojiDetailList.description:
A graph showing the current value of the Japanese Yen.

Chart Increasing with Yen was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Chart with Upwards Trend and Yen Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Chart Increasing with Yen
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Chart with Upwards Trend and Yen Sign

emojiDetailList.description: ATM Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Automated Teller Machine” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: ATM Sign

emojiDetailList.applenames: Put Litter in Its Place Symbol
emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing a person putting litter (rubbish) in the trash (rubbish bin). A more positive version of the Do Not Litter Symbol .

Litter in Bin Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Put Litter in Its Place Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Litter in Bin Sign
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Put Litter in Its Place Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol for potable (drinkable) water, usually shown with a faucet filling a drinking glass. Commonly used for various content concerning water, drinking, thirst, and dripping.

Some platforms, including Apple and WhatsApp, depict the emoji as an object while others feature a stylized, white faucet on a blue square, as a sign or icon of water that is safe to drink. Compare 🚱 Non-Potable Water , which indicates water that is not safe to drink.

Apple's design previously featured a blue symbol design, Microsoft's a cup filled with water.

Potable Water was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Potable Water Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Potable Water

emojiDetailList.description:
The international symbol of access, used to denote a facility which has been designed with accessibility or people in wheelchairs in mind. Appears as a blue sign, with a white graphic of a person sitting in a wheelchair.

Many platforms now use the Accessible Icon Project style image for this emoji, which displays the person in the wheelchair in a more active position.

Wheelchair Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wheelchair Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A stick-figure icon of a man, generally used to indicate a male restroom . The female equivalent is the Womens Symbol emoji.

Men’s Room was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Mens Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Men’s Room

emojiDetailList.description:
A stick-figure icon of a woman, generally used to indicate a female restroom . The male equivalent is the Mens Symbol emoji.

Women’s Room was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Womens Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Women’s Room

emojiDetailList.description:
A restroom symbol, depicting a iconography of a man and woman . Used to indicate the location of public bathrooms / toilets / restrooms.

Used as an alternative to the water closet symbol.

Restroom was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Restroom

emojiDetailList.description:
The symbol for a baby, usually used to indicate a room that is suitable to change a baby in. Often located in or near public restrooms.

Baby Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Baby Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A water closet is a name used for public toilet, bathroom or restroom used in some countries. Typically abbreviated to the letters WC, this may be found on signage in public buildings, as an alternative to the restroom symbol.

Water Closet was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Water Closet

emojiDetailList.description:
A triangle with an exclamation mark inside, used as a warning or alert.

Warning was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Warning Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Warning

emojiDetailList.description:
A crossing sign for children, usually positioned near schools or other areas that drivers should be cautious of young children in the area.

Children Crossing was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Children Crossing

emojiDetailList.description: No Entry was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Entry

emojiDetailList.description:
A red circle with a diagonal line through the middle, from top-left to bottom right, used to indicate that something is not permitted

Commonly shown in conjunction with other symbols to indicate No Smoking , No Bikes , or similar.

Prohibited was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No Entry Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Prohibited

emojiDetailList.description:
A bicycle with a red stroke through it, indicating that bikes are prohibited from this location.

May be seen in pedestrian malls with a bicycle restriction or crossing train tracks in some countries.

No Bicycles was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Bicycles

emojiDetailList.description: No Smoking was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No Smoking Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Smoking

emojiDetailList.description:
A person dropping litter (rubbish, trash) with a red stroke through it, indicating that littering is prohibited in this area.

Usually implied by the fact that littering is not welcome anywhere, this sign serves as a reminder in areas that are known to attract litter.

No Littering was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Do Not Litter Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Littering

emojiDetailList.description:
A water tap with a red stroke through it, indicating that water is not safe for drinking (non-potable).

May be used at a camp site or other area that has water suitable for cleaning or other non-drinking purposes.

Non-Potable Water was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Non-Potable Water Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Non-Potable Water

emojiDetailList.description:
A pedestrian symbol with a red stroke through it, indicating that pedestrians are prohibited from this location.

May be seen in dedicated bike lanes, highways, or other areas not suitable to be on-foot.

No Pedestrians was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Pedestrians

emojiDetailList.description:
A mobile phone with a red stroke through it, indicating that mobile phones should not be present. Often seen in restricted areas, such as Customs or Passport Control .

No Mobile Phones was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No Mobile Phones

emojiDetailList.description:
The number eighteen with a red stroke through it, indicating a location where a person must be aged 18 or above to enter. Often used online to indicate adult or NSFW content.

The Samsung version of this emoji previously displayed the number 19 . This may have been due to the practice of counting the first year of life as one instead of zero in parts of East Asia such as South Korea (the location of the Samsung Headquarters).

No One Under Eighteen was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “No One Under Eighteen Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: No One Under Eighteen

emojiDetailList.description:
A hazard symbol for radiation or radioactivity. May appear similar to a three-pronged fan at small sizes.

Generally displayed on an orange or yellow background.

Radioactive was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Radioactive Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Radioactive

emojiDetailList.description: Biohazard was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Biohazard Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Biohazard

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow, pointing up.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Up Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Upwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Up Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-right, or north-east direction.

Up-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “North East Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Up-Right Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow, pointing right.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Rightwards Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Right Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-right, or south-east direction.

Down-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “South East Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Down-Right Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow, pointing down.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Down Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Downwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Down Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing diagonally in an down-left, or south-west direction.

Down-Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “South West Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Down-Left Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow, pointing left.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Leftwards Black Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Left Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing diagonally in an up-left, or north-west direction.

Up-Left Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “North West Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Up-Left Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
A vertical line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing up and down.

Up-Down Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Up Down Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Up-Down Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
A horizontal line with arrowheads on both ends, pointing left and right.

Left-Right Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Left Right Arrow” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Left-Right Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing to the left, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a reply icon in an email application.

Right Arrow Curving Left was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Leftwards Arrow with Hook” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Right Arrow Curving Left

emojiDetailList.description:
An arrow pointing to the right, with a curved hook at the other end. Similar in appearance to a sideways U Turn symbol, or a forward icon in an email application.

Left Arrow Curving Right was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Rightwards Arrow with Hook” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Left Arrow Curving Right

emojiDetailList.description:
A curved arrow pointing up.

Right Arrow Curving Up was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Upwards” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Right Arrow Curving Up
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Upwards

emojiDetailList.description:
A curved arrow pointing down.

Right Arrow Curving Down was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Downwards” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Right Arrow Curving Down
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Arrow Pointing Rightwards Then Curving Downwards

emojiDetailList.description: Clockwise Vertical Arrows was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Clockwise Vertical Arrows
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Clockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows

emojiDetailList.description:
Two arrows forming a circle, pointing in an anticlockwise direction. Similar to symbols sometimes used for refresh or rotate . May also be used to indicate a task is in progress.

Previously showed in a clockwise direction on Windows.

Counterclockwise Arrows Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Anticlockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Counterclockwise Arrows Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Anticlockwise Downwards and Upwards Open Circle Arrows

emojiDetailList.description: Back Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Back with Leftwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Back Arrow

emojiDetailList.description: End Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “End with Leftwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: End Arrow

emojiDetailList.description: On! Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “On with Exclamation Mark with Left Right Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: On! Arrow
emojiDetailList.unicodename: On with Exclamation Mark with Left Right Arrow Above

emojiDetailList.description:
The word "soon" with an arrow above it, pointing to the right.

Soon Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Soon with Rightwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Soon Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
The word "top" with an arrow pointing up above it.

Top Arrow was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Top with Upwards Arrow Above” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Top Arrow

emojiDetailList.description:
A building used for worship by people of any faith or religion. Examples include a church , mosque , or synagogue . A person is shown on their knees praying, in this symbol.

Multi-faith places of worship are commonly found at airports .

Place of Worship was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Place of Worship

emojiDetailList.description: Atom Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Atom Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol often used in relation to the religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism.

Om was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Om Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Om

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol often used in relation to the religion of Judaism. Not to be confused with the Six Pointed Star With Middle Dot emoji .

Star of David was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Star of David

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol often used in relation to the Indian religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and Jainism.

Wheel of Dharma was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wheel of Dharma

emojiDetailList.description: Yin Yang was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Yin Yang

emojiDetailList.description:
A latin cross, otherwise known as a Christian cross. This cross symbol is often used as a symbol of Christianity. Similar in appearance to the Orthodox cross .

Latin Cross was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Latin Cross

emojiDetailList.description: Orthodox Cross was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Orthodox Cross

emojiDetailList.description:
The crescent moon and star is a symbol often associated with the religion of Islam. This symbol can be found on the flags of many countries, such as Algeria , Azerbaijan , Malaysia , Pakistan and Turkey .

Star and Crescent was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Star and Crescent

emojiDetailList.description:
A circular symbol, commonly used as a representation of peace. Alternatives include the Victory Hand , or the Dove of Peace .

Peace Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Peace Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A menorah showing nine lit candles, used on the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah .

Menorah was approved as part of Unicode 8.0 in 2015 under the name “Menorah with Nine Branches” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Menorah

emojiDetailList.applenames: Six Pointed Star with Middle Dot
emojiDetailList.description:
A star with six points, and a dot in the center. Similar to the Star of David emoji .

Dotted Six-Pointed Star was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Six Pointed Star with Middle Dot” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dotted Six-Pointed Star
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Six Pointed Star with Middle Dot

emojiDetailList.description:
The Aries astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Ram.

Aries was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Aries

emojiDetailList.description:
The Taurus astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Bull.

Taurus was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Taurus

emojiDetailList.description:
The Gemini astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents Twins.

Gemini was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Gemini

emojiDetailList.description:
The Cancer astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Crab.

Cancer was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cancer

emojiDetailList.description:
The Leo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Lion.

Leo was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Leo

emojiDetailList.description:
The Virgo astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Maiden.

Virgo was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Virgo

emojiDetailList.description:
The Libra astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents weighing scales .

Libra was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Libra

emojiDetailList.description:
The Scorpius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Scorpion.

Scorpio was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Scorpius” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Scorpio

emojiDetailList.description:
The Sagittarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents an Archer.

Sagittarius was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sagittarius

emojiDetailList.description:
The Capricorn astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Goat.

Capricorn was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Capricorn

emojiDetailList.description:
The Aquarius astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Water-bearer.

Aquarius was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Aquarius

emojiDetailList.description:
The Pisces astrological sign in the Zodiac. This Zodiac Symbol represents a Fish.

Pisces was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pisces

emojiDetailList.description:
Ophiuchus is used by some as a 13th sign in the Zodiac. The symbol for ophiuchus appears a U shape with a wavy line through it.

Ophiuchus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Ophiuchus

emojiDetailList.description:
Two arrows pointing right while crossing over one another. Used to indicate putting music on shuffle: randomizing the order of tracks in the upcoming playlist. May also be used to indicate two items switching places.

Shuffle Tracks Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Twisted Rightwards Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Shuffle Tracks Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Circular arrows pointing in a clockwise direction. Used in music player applications to loop a track or album continuously. Commonly used to repesent a retweet on Twitter.

Repeat Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Repeat Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows

emojiDetailList.description:
