Arrows pointing in a clockwise direction, with a number 1 badge in the lower corner.  Used in music player applications to loop a track or album once.

Repeat Single Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows with Circled One Overlay” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Repeat Single Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Clockwise Rightwards and Leftwards Open Circle Arrows with Circled One Overlay

emojiDetailList.description:
A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing right. Commonly used as a symbol for play.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Play Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Play Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Two triangles pointing to the right. Most commonly used as a symbol for fast forwarding media such as video tapes , CDs , or digital audio and video.

Fast-Forward Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fast-Forward Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the next track (or scene). Shown as two triangles pointing right followed by a vertical bar.

Next Track Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Next Track Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Black Right-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar

emojiDetailList.description:
A play-pause icon, showing a right-pointing triangle (play) next to a double vertical bar (pause).

Play or Pause Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Right-Pointing Triangle with Double Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Play or Pause Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Black Right-Pointing Triangle with Double Vertical Bar

emojiDetailList.description:
A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing left.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Reverse Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Reverse Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Two triangles pointing to the left. Most commonly used as a symbol for rewinding media such as video tapes , CDs , or digital audio and video.

Fast Reverse Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fast Reverse Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol used in media players to indicate skipping to the first or previous track (or scene). Shown as a vertical bar followed by two triangles pointing left.

Last Track Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Left-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Last Track Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Black Left-Pointing Double Triangle with Vertical Bar

emojiDetailList.description:
A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing up. Styled similarly to the left and right pointing triangles on iOS, but shown in red on Windows, and orange on Android.

Upwards Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Up-Pointing Small Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Upwards Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Two triangles pointing up. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° clockwise.

Fast Up Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Up-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fast Up Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A triangle-shaped arrow, pointing down. Styled similarly to the left and right pointing triangles on iOS, but shown in red on Windows, and orange on Android.

Downwards Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Down-Pointing Small Red Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Downwards Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Two triangles pointing down. Similar to rewind icon, rotated 90° counter-clockwise.

Fast Down Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Down-Pointing Double Triangle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fast Down Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A pause icon, displayed as two vertical bars.

Pause Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Double Vertical Bar” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Pause Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A stop icon, displayed as a square.

Stop Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Black Square for Stop” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Stop Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A record icon, displayed as a circle.

Record Button was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Black Circle for Record” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Record Button

emojiDetailList.description:
An eject symbol, displayed as an upward-pointing triangle above a horiztonal bar. May be used as a physical button or an icon in a user interface. Represents the action of ejecting physical media such as a floppy disk , videocasette or DVD on a computer or media player.

Eject Button was approved as part of Unicode 4.0 in 2003 under the name “Eject Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eject Button

emojiDetailList.description:
An emoji representing the cinema: a large screen showing the latest movies, available to the public. Displayed by most platforms as a film projector symbol, and previously by Google and Microsoft as a cinema screen with curtains.

Cinema was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cinema

emojiDetailList.description:
An icon of a outlined sun, used when decreasing the brightness of a screen. Appears smaller than the High Brightness Symbol .

Dim Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Low Brightness Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Dim Button

emojiDetailList.description:
An icon of a outlined sun, used when increasing the brightness of a screen. Appears larger than the Low Brightness Symbol .

Bright Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “High Brightness Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Bright Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Bars increasing in height, showing the strength of the mobile (cellular) phone signal. More bars signifies better reception.

Antenna Bars was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Antenna with Bars” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Antenna Bars

emojiDetailList.description:
An icon representing vibration mode on a mobile phone , indicating that a phone should be switched to silent and/or vibrate mode.

Displayed as a phone with either zig-zag lines or muted-bell icon on most platforms. Early versions of this emoji often used a heart alongside a mobile phone , as commonly seen in Japan .

Vibration Mode was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Vibration Mode

emojiDetailList.description:
A sign indicating that mobile phones should be turned off. Used in situations such as a cinema or live performance.

Displayed as a mobile phone with the word OFF. Shown with a cross instead of the word OFF on Windows .

Mobile Phone Off was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Mobile Phone Off

emojiDetailList.description:
A circle shown with a crossed vertical line beneath it, used as a representation for women.

Female Sign was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Female Sign

emojiDetailList.description:
A circle shown with a diagonal arrow pointing out the top-right, used as a representation for men.

Male Sign was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Male Sign

emojiDetailList.description: Multiply was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Multiplication X” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Multiply

emojiDetailList.description: Plus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Plus Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Plus

emojiDetailList.description: Minus was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Minus Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Minus

emojiDetailList.description: Divide was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Heavy Division Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Divide

emojiDetailList.description:
The symbol for infinity enclosed within a circle or square.

Originally encoded as a symbol to represent acid-free paper , this permanent paper sign was later given emoji presentation to form an infinity emoji.

Infinity was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Permanent Paper Sign” and added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Infinity

emojiDetailList.description: Double Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Double Exclamation Mark

emojiDetailList.applenames: Red Exclamation Mark and Question Mark
emojiDetailList.description: Exclamation Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Exclamation Question Mark

emojiDetailList.description: Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Black Question Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Question Mark

emojiDetailList.description: White Question Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Question Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: White Question Mark

emojiDetailList.description: White Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Exclamation Mark Ornament” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: White Exclamation Mark

emojiDetailList.description: Exclamation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Heavy Exclamation Mark Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Exclamation Mark

emojiDetailList.description:
Just like a regular dash (hyphen), sometimes used in Asian character sets in the same way a – or — is used in latin character sets.

Wavy Dash was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Wavy Dash

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol for exchanging of two currencies. Most commonly displayed as a dollar symbol , with arrows to and from a yen symbol .

Some platforms instead show banknotes and coins in yen , dollars , euros and pounds .

Currency Exchange was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Currency Exchange

emojiDetailList.description: Heavy Dollar Sign was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Heavy Dollar Sign

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol displaying of a rod with a snake entwined around the outside in a downward-spiral shape.

Associated with medicine and health care services such as doctors or hospitals. A similar and related symbol called the Caduceus is frequently used in the United States .

Medical Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 under the name “Staff of Aesculapius” and added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Medical Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
The universal recycling symbol, featuring three arrows pointing clockwise in a triangular formation.

The word “black” in the official name is due to this emoji existing as a unicode character before the current standardized emoji set.

Recycling Symbol was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 under the name “Black Universal Recycling Symbol” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Recycling Symbol

emojiDetailList.description:
A decorative symbol that appears like a golden flower, but found in all manner of logos, symbols, and patterns. This symbol forms part of the World Scout Emblem , amongst other uses.

Fleur-de-lis was approved as part of Unicode 4.1 in 2005 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Fleur-de-lis

emojiDetailList.description:
A trident is a three-pronged spear, that appears similar to a pitchfork. Often held by Greek or Roman Gods in statues.

Trident Emblem was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Trident Emblem

emojiDetailList.description:
A name badge, used to identify oneself in a location that others may not know your name, such as a school trip, or a work conference.

This tulip -shaped name badge is one of many designs commonly found at kindergartens in Japan.

Name Badge was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Name Badge

emojiDetailList.description:
A yellow and green shield symbol, called a Shoshinsha Mark . Must be displayed by drivers in Japan for one year after they receive their drivers licence.

Similar to L-Plates used to identify learner drivers in other countries.

Japanese Symbol for Beginner was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese Symbol for Beginner

emojiDetailList.description:
Used as an alternative to a check (tick) in Japan for a something that is correct. The opposite of an X ( cross mark ) for something wrong.

Hollow Red Circle was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Heavy Large Circle” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Hollow Red Circle

emojiDetailList.description:
A check mark that displays with a white outlined appearance. Shows on most platforms with a bright green rounded rectangle or circle surrounding it.

Android previously displayed this as an outlined blue check mark / blue tick.

This emoji is not supported in Twitter names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark.

Check Mark Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “White Heavy Check Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Check Mark Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A checkbox showing a check mark inside the box. Not to be confused with the similarly named Ballot Box With Ballot emoji.

This emoji is not supported in Twitter names, possibly in an attempt to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark.

Check Box with Check was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Ballot Box with Check” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Check Box with Check

emojiDetailList.description:
A thick (heavy) check mark displayed on some platforms in a handwritten style. Generally displayed in black.

Previous versions shown in green on Android , and red on Samsung .

This emoji is not supported in Twitter names , to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark.

Check Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Heavy Check Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Check Mark

emojiDetailList.description:
A large red cross mark, displayed in the shape of a letter X and similar to a multiplication sign .

Cross Mark was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cross Mark

emojiDetailList.description: Cross Mark Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Cross Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cross Mark Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A curled loop, which is shown in black on most platforms. Displayed as a blue ribbon on Samsung devices.

Similar to the Double Curly Loop but with only a single loop.

Curly Loop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Curly Loop

emojiDetailList.description:
Two curly loops, which represent a reel-to-reel tape recorder. Used as a symbol for voicemail on many phones.

A variation of this logo is used by Free Dial , a toll-free telephone number by NTT in Japan.

Double Curly Loop was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Double Curly Loop

emojiDetailList.description:
Used in traditional Japanese music such as Noh or Renga , to indicate the start of a song. More specifically, the part alternation mark is displayed where the singer’s part begins.

This symbol looks sort of like a lopsided capital M; or a rollercoaster track showing a dip, and then a drop off to the right.

Part Alternation Mark was approved as part of Unicode 3.2 in 2002 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Part Alternation Mark

emojiDetailList.description:
Used in a similar manner to a regular * asterisk character but tends to be shown in a similar vertical alignment to a • bullet point. The eight spoked asterisk has both a ✳︎ text and ✳️ emoji presentation available on most platforms.

Eight-Spoked Asterisk was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Eight Spoked Asterisk” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eight-Spoked Asterisk

emojiDetailList.description:
A star with eight points, that is commonly shown in orange, and for some reason, with only four points.

See the glossary for information on the term black in unicode character names.

Eight-Pointed Star was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Eight Pointed Black Star” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Eight-Pointed Star

emojiDetailList.description:
Used a decorative bullet-point, the sparkle has both a ❇︎ text and ❇️ emoji presentation available on most platforms.

Sparkle was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Sparkle

emojiDetailList.description: Copyright was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Copyright Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Copyright

emojiDetailList.description: Registered was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Registered Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Registered

emojiDetailList.description:
A trademark symbol, the letters TM displayed after a word that is trademarked.

Trade Mark was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Trade Mark Sign” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Trade Mark

emojiDetailList.description:
A hash key, sometimes referred to as a pound key in the United States. Most commonly used online to make a hashtag (or hash flag ) on social media sites.

The Keycap Number Sign emoji is a keycap sequence combining # Number Sign and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Number Sign was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Number Sign

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Asterisk emoji is a keycap sequence combining * Asterisk and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Asterisk was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Asterisk

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Zero emoji is a keycap sequence combining 0 Digit Zero and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Zero was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Zero

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit One emoji is a keycap sequence combining 1 Digit One and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit One was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit One

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Two emoji is a keycap sequence combining 2 Digit Two and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Two was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Two

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Three emoji is a keycap sequence combining 3 Digit Three and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Three was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Three

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Four emoji is a keycap sequence combining 4 Digit Four and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Four was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Four

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Five emoji is a keycap sequence combining 5 Digit Five and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Five was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Five

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Six emoji is a keycap sequence combining 6 Digit Six and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Six was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Six

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Seven emoji is a keycap sequence combining 7 Digit Seven and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Seven was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Seven

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Eight emoji is a keycap sequence combining 8 Digit Eight and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Eight was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Eight

emojiDetailList.description:
The Keycap Digit Nine emoji is a keycap sequence combining 9 Digit Nine and ⃣ Combining Enclosing Keycap . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Keycap Digit Nine was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 and added to Emoji 3.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap Digit Nine

emojiDetailList.description:
The number 10 on a square with rounded corners, designed to look like a keycap.

Keycap: 10 was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Keycap Ten” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Keycap: 10

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing the capital letters A, B, C and D. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle capital letter input.

Input Latin Uppercase was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Capital Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Input Latin Uppercase
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Input Symbol for Latin Capital Letters

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to toggle lowercase letter input.

Input Latin Lowercase was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Small Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Input Latin Lowercase
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Input Symbol for Latin Small Letters

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing the numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable symbol input, as opposed to alphabetical or symbol input.

Input Numbers was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Numbers” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Input Numbers

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing the following glyphs: 〒 (Japanese postal mark), 𝅘𝅥𝅮 (music note), & (ampersand, or sometimes an @ symbol) and % (percentage sign).

Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable symbol input, as opposed to alphabetical or numeric input.

Input Symbols was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Symbols” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Input Symbols

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol showing the lowercase letters a, b, c and d. Intended to be used on a software keyboard, or other input screen to enable alphabetical input, as opposed to numeric or symbol input.

Input Latin Letters was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Input Symbol for Latin Letters” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Input Latin Letters

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol representing Blood Type A. Displayed as the letter A on a red background.

A Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter A” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: A Button (Blood Type)
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter A

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol representing Blood Type AB. Displayed as the letters AB on a red background.

AB Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared AB” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: AB Button (Blood Type)

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol representing Blood Type B. Displayed as the letter B on a red background.

Sometimes used online to replace the letter C at the start of words in reference to the Bloods street gang's practice of turning words like cool into bool . This has expanded in some instances to starting any word with the letter B, or more specifically, this emoji which makes it more 🅱️lear that a letter has been replaced.

B Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter B” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: B Button (Blood Type)
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter B

emojiDetailList.description:
CL is what shows on the CL ear button of some older mobile phones.

CL Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CL” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: CL Button

emojiDetailList.description:
The word cool , shown enclosed in a square. This generally displays in a shade of blue, or blue-gray on most platforms. Used as a text decoration.

Cool Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Cool” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Cool Button

emojiDetailList.description:
The word free , shown enclosed in a square.

Free Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Free” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Free Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A lowercase letter i , enclosed in a rounded square or circle. Implemented in apps or websites to indicate that help or further information is available.

May be used as a logo for tourist information signage in a town or city.

Information was approved as part of Unicode 3.0 in 1999 under the name “Information Source” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Information

emojiDetailList.description:
The letters ID in a square.

ID Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared ID” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: ID Button

emojiDetailList.description:
The letter M in a circle, commonly used in to identify a Metro (subway, underground train) station in a city area.

Circled M was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Latin Capital Letter M” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Circled M

emojiDetailList.description:
The word new , shown enclosed in a square.

New Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared New” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: New Button

emojiDetailList.description:
The letters NG , shown enclosed in a square, which are an acronym for the words No Good .

The origin of NG refers to bloopers shown during or after the credits of a live television show in Japan (known as NGs ), but can be used in any field as a form of shorthand for no good.

NG Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared NG” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: NG Button

emojiDetailList.description:
A symbol representing Blood Type O. Displayed as the letter O on a red background.

O Button (Blood Type) was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter O” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: O Button (Blood Type)
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter O

emojiDetailList.description:
The letters OK , shown enclosed in a square. Meaning Okay , denoting approval. The opposite of the Squared NG Emoji .

OK Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared OK” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: OK Button

emojiDetailList.description: P Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter P” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: P Button
emojiDetailList.unicodename: Negative Squared Latin Capital Letter P

emojiDetailList.description:
SOS is the description for the distress signal in Morse Code . This emoji means SOS or “emergency”.

SOS Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared SOS” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: SOS Button

emojiDetailList.description:
The word up with an exclamation point after it, shown enclosed in a square. Originally intended to denote leveling up in a game.

Up! Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Up with Exclamation Mark” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Up! Button

emojiDetailList.description: Vs Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Vs” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Vs Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Means “Here” in Japanese, referring to a destination.

Japanese “Here” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Katakana Koko” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Here” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Translates as meaning complimentary, or free of charge. For example, a drink that is given "on the house" to a regular customer.

Japanese “Service Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared Katakana Sa” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Service Charge” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Means “moon” or “month” in Chinese.

Japanese “Monthly Amount” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6708” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Monthly Amount” Button

emojiDetailList.applenames: Japanese Sign Meaning “Not Free of Charge”
emojiDetailList.description:
This emoji means to own or posses .

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Not Free of Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6709” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Not Free of Charge” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This character translates as meaning a finger or toe pointing to indicate a certain direction.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Reserved” Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6307” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Reserved” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Denotes a “good bargain” in Japanese.

Japanese “Bargain” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Circled Ideograph Advantage” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Bargain” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Symbol for a sale, or bargain prices in Japan (“cut prices”). Literally translated, this character means to cut or divide.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Discount” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-5272” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Discount” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This means to lack , or have none of something.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Free of Charge” Button was approved as part of Unicode 5.2 in 2009 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7121” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Free of Charge” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This Emoji means “prohibit, restrict or forbid” in Japanese.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Prohibited” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7981” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Prohibited” Button

emojiDetailList.description: Japanese “Acceptable” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Circled Ideograph Accept” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Acceptable” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This Emoji has two meanings.

One meaning is “request” in Japanese. An alternative meaning is “monkey” in the Chinese zodiac.

It is commonly used in Japan to denote an application form or contact information for inquiries.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Application” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7533” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Application” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Means “agreement” in Japanese. More literally, it means to unite, or join together.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Passing Grade” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-5408” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Passing Grade” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This 空 character means empty and available in Japanese. This is used in the context of an empty parking space or a vacant hotel room.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Vacancy” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-7a7a” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Vacancy” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Translated from Japanese, this means "congratulations" or "pray for happiness".

Japanese “Congratulations” Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Ideograph Congratulation” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Congratulations” Button

emojiDetailList.description: Japanese “Secret” Button was approved as part of Unicode 1.1 in 1993 under the name “Circled Ideograph Secret” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Secret” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
Means “work” in Japanese.  This Emoji used to mean “open for business” and precedes business hours.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “Open for Business” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-55b6” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “Open for Business” Button

emojiDetailList.description:
This emoji means “full” in Japanese, usually used to denote “full capacity” such as a gas/petrol tank on a car or pre-paid phone card.

CJK Ideographs are characters used in Chinese, Japanese and Korean languages. Their writing systems all completely or partly use Chinese characters .

Japanese “No Vacancy” Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Squared CJK Unified Ideograph-6e80” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Japanese “No Vacancy” Button

emojiDetailList.unicodename: Diamond Shape with a Dot Inside

emojiDetailList.description:
A radio button user interface element, used in form fields with two or more choices. Differs from a checkbox , in that only one response can be selected.

This emoji generally shows the on/enabled state for the radio button, with a smaller circle inside a larger outer circle.

Radio Button was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Radio Button

emojiDetailList.description:

Chequered Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Chequered Flag

emojiDetailList.description:

Triangular Flag was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name “Triangular Flag on Post” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Triangular Flag

emojiDetailList.description:

Crossed Flags was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Crossed Flags

emojiDetailList.description: Black Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving Black Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Black Flag

emojiDetailList.description:
A white flag, shown waving on a post. Traditionally used as a sign of surrender, the meaning of this flag as an emoji is less defined.

White Flag was approved as part of Unicode 7.0 in 2014 under the name “Waving White Flag” and added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: White Flag

emojiDetailList.description:
A flag with six colors of the rainbow, generally including red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple. Commonly used by the LGBT movement as a gay pride flag , or simply pride flag and seen at Pride events .

In February 2019 misinformation was spread about a so-called "anti-lgbt emoji" which can be created using a combining character to show a black and white glyph like 🚫 on top of the rainbow flag . This is possible with any emoji on supported platforms, in the same way keycaps are combining characters.

The Rainbow Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏳 White Flag , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and 🌈 Rainbow . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Rainbow Flag was added to Emoji 4.0 in 2016.
emojiDetailList.title: Rainbow Flag

emojiDetailList.description:
A flag with horizontal pale blue and pale pink stripes with a single white stripe in the middle, used as a Transgender or Transgender Pride flag and commonly seen at Pride events .

Approved in early 2020, some platforms added support while in draft status (Twitter, WhatsApp, Facebook). Coming to major operating systems by the end of 2020.

The Transgender Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏳 White Flag , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ⚧ Transgender Symbol . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Transgender Flag was added to Emoji 13.0 in 2020.

🚩 New in 2020 : now on Android 11 . Coming soon to iOS 14.2 .
emojiDetailList.title: Transgender Flag

emojiDetailList.description:
A skull and crossbones displayed on a black flag, used on pirate ships, also known as a Jolly Roger .

The Pirate Flag emoji is a ZWJ sequence combining 🏴 Black Flag , ‍ Zero Width Joiner and ☠ Skull and Crossbones . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Pirate Flag was added to Emoji 11.0 in 2018.
emojiDetailList.title: Pirate Flag

The Flag: Switzerland emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇨 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter C and 🇭 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter H . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

emojiDetailList.description:
The flag for Taiwan (officially Republic of China ), which may show as the letters TW on some platforms.

This Taiwanese flag is hidden from the emoji keyboard on iOS devices when the region is set to China mainland or (as of iOS 13.1.2) Hong Kong or Macau.

Chinese-model iPhones will not display this emoji and will instead show a missing character tofu (☒) in place of the flag, as will iOS devices with region set to China mainland . Hong Kong and Macua only hide this emoji from the emoji keyboard .

The Flag: Taiwan emoji is a flag sequence combining 🇹 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter T and 🇼 Regional Indicator Symbol Letter W . These display as a single emoji on supported platforms.

Flag: Taiwan was added to Emoji 1.0 in 2015.
emojiDetailList.title: Flag: Taiwan
